West German youths with flare guns spent their time firing at it, and frequently hitting it. The obsolete East German flag hanging below it was tattered by night's end. A 24-year-old East Berliner who refused to give his name sat in a lawn chair in front of Brandenburg Gate, surrounded by thousands of jubilant pro-unity celebrants. He passed out pamphlets while wearing a black ski mask. Unity was too costly and unfair to Germans in both sides, it said. ``People here have been giving me trouble,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Souter to Take Seat on Supreme Court Next Week
DOC.TEXT: David Souter of New Hampshire will take his oath next week as a Supreme Court justice with the nation watching how he'll vote on abortion and other contentious social issues. The Senate voted 90-9 Tuesday to confirm Souter, 51, as the 105th member of the high court in the nation's history. The court immediately announced that Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist will swear in Souter next Tuesday morning, just before the Supreme Court begins hearing the second week of arguments in its 1990-91 term. The first major case Souter will hear concerns a sex-bias dispute. At issue is whether employers may exclude all women of childbearing age from some hazardous jobs, and the court's decision could affect millions of women. Issues of sex discrimination, race discrimination and especially abortion rights were at the core of opposition to Souter within and outside the Senate. The handful who voted against him and many voting for the nomination worried aloud that he would side with the court's conservatives and overrule Roe vs. Wade, the 1973 ruling that legalized abortion. To many Democrats who voted for Souter, his record on these social issues was troubling but his testimony encouraging, even though he refused to be pinned down, especially on the politically hot abortion decision. Sen. Herb Kohl, D-Wis., a member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said there appeared to be ``two Judge Souters.'' ``The Judge Souter who testified before our committee did not seem locked to the past,'' and that was the one he was voting for, Kohl said. He added that he hoped the Senate had not been deceived. ``He's about the best we can expect, from my perspective, from this administration,'' Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., said of President Bush's first Supreme Court nominee. But the National Abortion Rights Action League said the Senate ``made a dangerous leap of faith'' that could lead to the defeat of abortion rights and a return to ``back-alley abortions.'' Souter toasted the vote with champagne in Concord, N.H., and pledged to return the nation's confidence in him. ``I have been given much and much will be expected of me in return, and I will make that return to you and I will make it in the fullest measure that I can,'' he said. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., and other Democrats who opposed the nomination, said they would not give Souter the benefit of the doubt. Souter could ``solidify a 5-4 anti-civil rights, anti-privacy majority'' on the court, said Kennedy, repeating the argument he made as the only member of the Senate Judiciary Committee to oppose the nomination. In addition to Kennedy, those voting against Souter, all Democrats, were Alan Cranston of California, Daniel Akaka of Hawaii, Brock Adams of Washington, Bill Bradley and Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey, Quentin Burdick of North Dakota, John Kerry of Massachusetts and Barbara Mikulski of Maryland. Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., did not vote. Biden warned Bush that the next nominee might not get confirmed if the president moved further to the right. ``I want to express the hope that the administration will not learn the wrong lesson'' from the lopsided Senate vote on Souter, Biden said. A more doctrinaire conservative ``could well fall outside the sphere of acceptability,'' he said. Souter, who lives in rural Weare, N.H., near Concord, is a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School and a Rhodes Scholar. After law school, Souter returned home to practice and soon began working in the judicial system of his home state, working his way up to attorney general, trial judge and then the state Supreme Court. Last April, he was confirmed by the Senate to the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston. Souter will fill the seat vacated by the retirement of Justice William Brennan in July. He almost certainly will vote more conservatively than the liberal Brennan, and conservatives were pleased. ``He's just exactly the kind of person with a broad background that we need on the Supreme Court,'' said Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. ``I think he showed that he is a person of fairness. He's willing to listen. He's a person of independence.''

DOC.HEAD: Aspirin May Prevent Migraines, Researchers Say
DOC.TEXT: An aspirin every other day may help prevent migraines among some of the millions of Americans who suffer theexcruciating headaches, scientists reported today. The findings in the Journal of the American Medical Association are from the same study that found aspirin effective in preventing a first heart attack. The researchers found that a group of men who took one aspirin every other day reported 20 percent fewer migraines than a similar group that took a dummy tablet. Headache experts called the research results encouraging. But they said aspirin could offer, at best, only a partial solution to the migraine puzzle. Nevertheless, ``there's enough evidence here that health-care practitioners should consider aspirin for migraine treatment,'' said Julie E. Buring, leader of the team at Boston's Brigham and Women's Hospital that reported the findings. An estimated 20 percent of American adults suffer migraines. Headache experts say there is no known single cause of migraines. The severe headaches, often accompanied by nausea, appear to be triggered in some patients by certain foods and also seem related to stress and a lack of regular sleep, meals and exercise. Buring and her colleagues analyzed five years of data from the Physicians Health Study, a project involving about 22,000 U.S. male physicians that began in 1982. The project is devoted to studying the effects of aspirin and beta carotene, an orange pigment found in certain fruits and vegetables, on heart disease, migraine and cancer. Of the approximately 11,000 doctors who took aspirin, 661 reported migraines at some time after the study began compared with 818 of those who took the aspirin placebo. The researchers did not analyze the data regarding beta carotene and migraine, Buring said in a telephone interview. She said the aspirin portion of the study ended in 1988 when the researchers felt compelled to report a finding that those on the aspirin regimen had a 44 percent lower risk of developing a first heart attack. Aspirin may help prevent migraines for the same reason it helps prevent heart attacks, Buring said: In low doses it hinders the formation of clumps of blood platelets, which cause blood clots. The effect disappears at higher doses. When platelets unite, they send into the bloodstream a substance called serotonin that is also released shortly before a migraine attack in most sufferers, Buring said. By hindering the release of serotonin, aspirin may prevent the chain of events that culminate in a migraine, said Buring, herself a migraine sufferer. In an accompanying editorial, Dr. D.J. Dalessio of Scripps Clinic and Research Foundation of La Jolla, Calif., suggested doctors incorporate aspirin into their treatment of men who suffer migraine attacks at least weekly. Doctors have had some success treating migraines with medications including anti-inflammatory and antidepressant drugs, said Dr. Robert S. Kunkel, head of the headache section at the Cleveland Clinic Foundation in Cleveland. But aspirin would be preferable, said Dr. Alexander Mauskop, who runs a headache clinic at the State University of New York Health Science Center in Brooklyn. ``It certainly would be cheaper because aspirin costs about a penny a pill,'' he said. ``And it would have the additional benefit of preventing strokes and heart attacks.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Protests Brown's Budget Stand
DOC.TEXT: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder accused Democratic National Chairman Ron H. Brown of breaking a promise to oppose tax increases that would hurt the middle class. In a letter to the party chairman, Wilder, a Democrat, said Brown had promised Democrats would fight for tax cuts for middle-class Americans who were hurt most by Republican-backed tax increases in the 1980s. ``You have now repudiated your previous positions and have joined in support of the tax increases you previously said would be unfair to the very people we need to protect,'' Wilder wrote Tuesday. Brown said he would support the budget compromise drafted by congressional leaders and the Bush administration because it is preferable to automatic spending cuts that would go into effect without the tax increases. The compromise calls for increasing taxes on gasoline, liquor and luxury items and reducing Medicare benefits. Laura F. Dillard, Wilder's press secretary, said the governor thinks federal budget negotiators should have looked harder for spending cuts before raising taxes.
DOC.HEAD: Democrats Press President Ford To Repudiate Conservative Word List
DOC.TEXT: A group devoted to re-electing Democratic congressmen wants former President Ford to repudiate a conservative word list designed to give Republicans verbal ammunition in political campaigns. The list, drafted by the Republican political action committee GOPAC, included such words as ``greed,'' ``traitors'' and ``liberal'' to use against Democratic opponents. Words such as ``family,'' ``children'' and ``vision,'' were suggested as appropriate for GOP candidates to use when referring to themselves. Ford serves as honorary chairman of GOPAC. In a letter to Ford, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee decried the word list as ``demagoguery without limits, without content and without honesty.'' DCCC Chairman Beryl Anthony Jr., an Arkansas congressman, said in the letter that Ford should dissociate himself from such tactics. ``As an individual who has devoted his life to public service and the honorable debate of issues, I am sure you will find these activities as disgusting as I do,'' Anthony wrote. ``I also hope you will demonstrate your support for decency in our nation's political life by publicly repudiating this group and its tactics.'' Anthony did not accuse Ford of involvement in producing the GOPAC word list. In fact, a copy of the list was included in the letter to Ford, ``in the event that you have not seen it.'' Ford spokeswoman Penny Circle said the letter arrived at Ford's Rancho Mirage, Calif., office on Monday and that Ford had not had an opportunity to read it. Democrats directed their ire at Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., who is GOPAC's general chairman.

DOC.HEAD: `Twin Peaks' Collapses in Nielsens; `Cheers' No. 1
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The much-heralded season premiere of ABC's ``Twin Peaks'' bottomed out in 41st place in the ratings. ``The Civil War,'' meanwhile, was the most-watched series in PBS history and was seen by an estimated 14 million people each night. In the Sunday night time slot, the two-hour ``Twin Peaks'' finished behind NBC's ``Perry Mason'' movie and CBS' movie ``The Face of Fear.'' The Fox comedy ``Married ... With Children'' beat ``Twin Peaks'' for the night, too. Led by a No. 1 finish for the second consecutive week by ``Cheers,'' NBC won the week with a 12.9 average rating, the A.C. Nielsen Co. reported Tuesday. CBS, which won the opening week of the fall season for the first time in six years, was second with a 12.3. ABC had a 12.0. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes. The combined network share of the TV audience during the fall season's second week was down to 63 percent from 68 percent the previous week. NBC attributed the decline to ``The Civil War.'' PBS said its acclaimed 11-hour documentary had a 9 rating in the nation's 24 largest TV markets. Reruns of Fox's ``The Simpsons'' continued to struggle in head-to-head competition against new episodes of NBC's ``The Cosby Show.'' ``Cosby'' finished in third, while Bart and his family dropped to 73rd. New episodes of ``The Simpsons'' arrive Oct. 11. ABC won the network news ratings for the 38th consecutive week, with an average of 10.0. CBS had an 8.6 and NBC an 8.5. Here are the Top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``Cheers,'' NBC, 19.7; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 19.6; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 18.4; ``Murphy Brown,'' CBS, 18.2; ``Designing Women,'' CBS, ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC (tie) 18.1; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 17.6; ``Empty Net,'' NBC, 17.4; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 17.2; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 17.1.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Leader Calls for Support of Budget Plan
With PM-Budget Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, is urging Americans to support a $500 billion deficit reduction package because ``the nation is more important than partisan differences.'' Mitchell, in a televised speech Tuesday night that followed a similar appearance by President Bush, said the proposal ``holds the promise of restoring a sound economy.'' Just moments before Mitchell spoke, the president called the package negotiated by his administration and congressional leaders ``the best agreement that can be legislated now.'' Mitchell reminded viewers that the two parties still have ``deep differences over values and priorities'' that delayed an agreement for months. ``We prefer a budget that asks more from the wealthy and less from the elderly,'' he said. His remark referred to the Democrats' preference for higher taxes on wealthy Americans as the price for a Bush proposal to reduce the capital gains tax. These differences produced a stalemate and both ites were dropped from the budget agreement. Mitchell's comment on the party divisions drew an immediate reaction from Rep. Jerry Lewis, R-Calif., chairman of the House Republican Conference. In a statement after Bush and Mitchell spoke, Lewis said, ``George Mitchell's partisan shots at capital gains in his response was most disturbing. ``He, more than anyone else, is responsible for the death of capital gains in the budget package.'' But Lewis only had praise for the president, commenting that Bush ``stepped up to the plate tonight and hit the ball clear out of the park. His appeal to the American people will make the difference.'' He called the upcoming votes on the package the ``most important ... of the Bush presidency thus far'' and predicted a last-minute ``surge of support'' will win passage of the compromise. While conservative House Republicans have led the way in opposing the compromise, a liberal Democrat said he also would fight the package. The proposal would raise taxes on gasoline, alcohol, cigarettes, boats and furs while trimming benefits to farmers and Medicare recipients. It also would raise taxes for people who earn more than $100,000. Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga., said the plan places too heavy a burden on the backs of low- and middle-income taxpayers. Defense cuts would be too small and upper-income Americans would not be taxed enough, he said. ``It is a plan without compassion,'' Lewis said. ``It is not right; it is not just; it is not fair.'' Lewis said the proposal ``abandons the constituencies the Democrats have long represented. Democrats cannot afford to turn their backs on working people. We cannot turn our backs on the elderly.'' Mitchell, speaking on behalf of his party, said that when Bush asked Democrats to join in rewriting the White House budget plan, ``we agreed, because the nation is more important than partisan differences.'' Mitchell called the package ``imperfect,'' and said ``neither side got what it wanted.'' And he added, ``We recognize that this budget demands sacrifice from all Americans.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Approves Loan Guarantees For Israel
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III has reached an agreement with Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy that will provide Israel with a $400 million loan guarantee for housing. Baker said late Tuesday that key provisions include Israeli assurances that Soviet Jews would not be settled in Israeli-occupied areas held by the Arabs before the 1967 Middle East war. Presumably that includes the portion of Jerusalem that Jordan held as well as the West Bank, also held by Jordan, and Gaza, held by Egypt. Baker said at a news conference that Israel also would affirm that it is not providing incentives for Soviet immigrants to settle in those areas. Congress approved the loan guarantee three months ago. However, the Bush administration insisted on assurances from Jerusalem that Jewish settlements would not be furthered as a result. Less than 2 percent of the record influx of Soviet Jews wind up on the West Bank or in Gaza, according to the Israeli government. The Bush administration wants Israel to withdraw from most, if not all, of the land in exchange for Arab recognition as part of an overall Middle East agreement. Baker said ``we have a major difference of opinion'' with Israel on settlements. Israel will obtain the $400 million from commercial banks, most of them American, with the U.S. government guaranteeing the loans.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed by Runaway Car
DOC.TEXT: A car driven by a 91-year-old man thought to have had a heart attack careened down a street at up to 80 mph, killing the motorist and three other people in a fiery pileup, police said. Among those killed Tuesday were two children trapped in a burning car, authorities said. One person was critically injured. Police said the elderly man, who had a history of heart trouble, apparently was stricken at the wheel and jammed the accelerator to the floor. Witnesses said the Cadillac lurched forward at the top of steep Noe Valley Street near the city's Castro District and sailed through six intersections. It smashed into seven cars and knocked over utility poles before flipping over. Vanessa Santarsiero, manager of a boutique, said she saw the accident through the store window. ``The guy in the maroon car ... just sailed down the hill really fast,'' she said. ``When he hit a hump in the intersection, then he kind of flew across it, clearing the ground. There was a crash, a screech, and a million things flying.'' The elderly driver was killed, along with the two children and one other person, authorities said. A woman was listed in critical condition at San Francisco General Hospital with burns on the legs and arms. The victims' identities were not immediately released. Police Inspector James Smith said the driver had a history of heart problems and was scheduled to see his doctor. ``We assume he experienced some sort of medical emergency while he was driving,'' he said. Mark Conrad, a store clerk, said he ran out to help upon hearing the screech of the cars and an explosion. Through the smoke, he said, he saw a girl trapped in an overturned car. He said he could hear her cries for help as people tried to reach in to pull her out. ``They were reaching in and their hands got burned, so they had to pull back,'' he said. As they backed off, the car burst into flames. The scene was littered with wreckage in all directions in the afternoon accident. The area is heavily populated with apartment buildings, shops and dozens of restaurants.

DOC.HEAD: Eighteen Arrested For Protesting Lack of Benefits For Women AIDS Victims
DOC.TEXT:
Eighteen demonstrators were arrested after blocking traffic on a busy street to protest rules they say unfairly deny disability benefits to many women infected with the AIDS virus. The AIDS activists said Tuesday the Social Security Administration, in determining eligibility for disability benefits, is ignoring many of the diseases and infections that are common in women infected with the virus. The result is that many women with disabling conditions including gynecological disorders like pelvic inflammatory disease and chronic vaginal infections are denied benefits, the protesters said. These disorders are not on a list of infections and diseases used by the Centers for Disease Control to define AIDS. Much of the list was compiled in the early days of the epidemic when most AIDS victims were white, middle-class, homosexual men. But this definition misses the ailments and conditions common to women infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS, the activists said. Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King said officials awarding disability benefits are not limited by the CDC definition of AIDS. Officials can award up to three months of Supplemental Security Income payments immediately upon request to people who have any of the AIDS-related conditions on CDC's list, pending a final decision on the claim, she said. But Social Security officials also ``can and do'' give this three-month presumptive disability status to people who are sick with HIV infection but have not progressed into AIDS, she said in a statement.
---
DOC.HEAD: EPA Fails To Assure Disinfectants Kill Germs As Claimed, Study
DOC.TEXT: Says

The Environmental Protection Agency fails to monitor the effectiveness of disinfectants and up to 20 percent of the products sold to kill disease-causing germs may not work, according to a government study. In a report released to Congress on Tuesday, the General Accounting Office said the EPA has not inspected the majority of laboratories that test disinfectants and that the agency ``lacks assurance'' methods to prove the germ-killers are valid. The GAO report said estimates by the EPA's own experts are that an estimated 20 percent of all disinfectants fail to kill germs or viruses as they are supposed to, and that tests in some states show that more than 40 percent of the compounds are ineffective. The EPA is directed by law to register disinfectants and to assure that they are effective. But the GAO said the agency depends on test data submitted by manufacturers and that the EPA ``lacks assurance that the test methods and performance standards used... are valid.'' Anne Lindsay, the EPA official who supervises the disinfectant registration, said her agency has monitored labs that do about 40 percent of the testing. She also said the agency is developing a ``re-enforcement strategy'' to assure that manufacturers accurately report test data.
---
DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets Chile's President, U.S. Moves To Improve Relations
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is taking new steps to strengthen relations with Chile's new democratic government by allowing the Overseas Private Investment Corp. to resume operations there. The announcement came Tuesday during the first Washington visit of President Patricio Aylwin since his March inauguration brought democratic rule back to Chile. Aylwin met President Bush at the White House. OPIC is a quasi-governmental organization that facilitates investment by U.S. companies in foreign countries. The White House also disclosed that Bush will travel to Chile during a tour of five South American countries Dec. 2 to Dec. 8. The United States barred OPIC activities with Chile under Aylwin's predecessor, military dictator Gen. Augosto Pinochet, because of concerns about labor rights violations.

DOC.HEAD: Dartmouth Review President Resigns Over Anti-Semitic Quote
DOC.TEXT: The president of The Dartmouth Review has resigned rather than ``wear the albatross of anti-Semitism'' because of the publication of a passage from Hitler's ``Mein Kampf'' in the combative student weekly. ``I joined a paper which embraced the conservative ideals and attacked issues with daring style, often toeing the line of good taste,'' C. Tyler White said Tuesday. ``Publicly insulting and degrading the Jewish faith is neither a conservative ideal, nor is it in good taste.'' The resignation of Tyler and two Review writers came as a petition drive against The Review collected more than 2,000 signatures. A protest rally of students and administrators was planned for Thursday on the Ivy League campus. ``The main message we're trying to get across ... to the nation and the national media is that The Dartmouth Review in no way represents the campus,'' said Brian Ellner, president of the Student Assembly, which represents the 3,200 undergraduates. The newspaper, which is not affiliated with Dartmouth College, has in the past attacked blacks, women and homosexuals and tangled with professors. The latest uproar involved an issue that was distributed Saturday on Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement and Judaism's most solemn day. The quotation from Hitler was inserted unattributed into The Review's masthead: ``Therefore, I believe today that I am acting in the sense of the Almighty Creator: By warding off the Jews, I am fighting for the Lord's work.'' Review editors said the passage was put in by an unknown staffer without their knowledge. The Review called the incident sabotage and offered ``heartfelt apologies to Jews at Dartmouth and to the Dartmouth community at lage.'' But White said the response didn't express the staff's regret or take responsibility for the passage getting into print - ``and now we all must wear the albatross of anti-Semitism.'' College officials joined students in condemning the weekly. President James Freedman and other administrators planned to speak at the rally. ``I think the campus is still in a state of semi-shock over this - in the sense that it is an assault to the entire community,'' said Dean Edward Shanahan. Students have published The Review since 1980 with backing from some of the nation's most prominent conservatives. One frequent target for criticism is William Cole, a black music professor who resigned in August after seven years of being belittled in print as a mediocre teacher. Cole said his effectiveness had been compromised. Cole filed a $600,000 libel suit against the paper in 1983. It was settled out of court for no money two years later. Review staffers also were involved in a sledgehammer attack on shanties erected on campus as part of a protest against segregation in South Africa several years ago. Several staffers were suspended.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei, Dollar Down
DOC.TEXT: Share prices in Tokyo edged down Wednesday after profit taking erased the market's early gains, and the dollar closed marginally lower against the yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, which gained 2,676.55 points Tuesday in its largest single-day rise ever, fell 49.02 points, or 0.21 percent, ending the day at 22,849.39. The index added 331.16 points before falling back in the afternoon. The dollar closed at 136.65 yen, down 0.08 yen from Tuesday's close at 136.73 yen. It opened at 136.33 yen and ranged between 136.21 yen and 136.70 yen. Stock traders said the index lost almost 600 points in the first 30 minutes of afternoon trading on profit taking following Tuesday's jump. They said the index's morning gain reflected optimism following Monday's Finance Ministry announcement to take measures to support the stock market, as well as declining oil prices and positive developments in the Middle East. The stock support measures, aimed at spurring buying and reducing market volatility, included easing restrictions on the purchase of stock on credit and shortening the hours for futures and options trading to curb speculation. Also, Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto hinted Monday of the possibility of easing interest rates temporarily to save the ailing stock market. On the foreign exchange, dealers said falling oil prices triggered the dollar's slip against the yen early Wednesday. But trading became volatile as market players made different interpretations of Hashimoto's remarks, said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. ``Lowering the interest rate encourages yen sales overseas, whereas it is a yen-buying factor (here) because they (lower rates) would help the Tokyo stock market recover,'' she said. Ms. Takeuchi said the rising Nikkei Stock Average and falling oil prices stimulated yen buying among Japanese currency investors Wednesday, but ``nobody is expecting much change from the current level.''

DOC.HEAD: Four Defend the Rights of the Unhip in Court
LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: Four people who say a snooty bouncer at a chic nightclub denied them entry and made them feel ``like scum'' because of their unhip clothing are asking a judge to decide whether that's cool under the law. The four argued Tuesday in small claims court that their civil rights were violated. They want damages of $250 apiece. The four - a lawyer, a termite company operator, an accountant and an accounting manager from the San Fernando Valley - said they were rejected by a doorman at the Mayan, a trendy downtown club that used to be a porno theater. ``I think we were met at the door by a flippant and arrogant doorman,'' Jeff Stolzer said in court. ``They just looked you over like you were scum.'' Municipal Court Commissioner Diana Wheatley said she would issue a ruling later. Sammy Chao, president of the company that owns the Mayan, denied any discrimination and argued that doormen pick and choose who to let in to keep out troublemakers. He denied there was a dress code. Kenneth Lipton, 36, a personal injury lawyer specializing in dog bites, Tess Dubrall, 34, an accounting manager, Stephen Ambrosini, 33, an accountant, and Stolzer, 35, who uns a termite company, claim a violation of their rights under a state law passed in 1959 to end discrimination by businesses. All four waited in vain to get into the club after they rendezvoused there May 19. Lipton wore his evidence to court. He arrived in the outfit he had on that night - dark green dungarees, black loafers and a sea-green shirt with a black design. For his part, Chao wore to court a black, Italian-cut suit with a silk print tie and white shirt. Men routinely let into the club wear loose, baggy suits with shirts buttoned at the collar. Less is more in terms of hemlines for women. The black-robed commissioner was mostly interested in the mechanics of the entry process, which was described as the doorman choosing from a crowd gathered behind a semicircular rope. ``The places I go you can just walk in,'' Wheatley remarked. ``Obviously this is a more popular spot.'' Chao said he hires doormen ``sensitive'' enough to ``see through a person'' and screen out the intoxicated or dangerous. He said there was no discrimination on the basis of race or sex, but that the number of people let in was limited for safety. In addition, room must be saved for private parties and people with reservations, Chao said. ``It's not Disneyland,'' he said. ``If we run a first-come, first-served, we will soon be filled.'' Outside court, Lipton outlined a broader purpose: halting the spread of New York-style club entry policies to California. ``We just don't want the policy to come to Los Angeles and we don't want it to expand - move to movies, bowling alleys. It hasn't been legal since the 1950s,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: German Diplomats Notifying Thousands They Can File Property Claims
With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: German diplomats are trying to get word to thousands of German-Americans who have only 10 days left to reclaim land seized decades ago by East Germany's communist government. Charged with the task are the 10 German consulates scattered in the United States and the German Embassy in Washington. The German consulate in Chicago has mailed hundreds of letters to English and German-language newspapers and radio stations in its nine-state region, where a large concentration of German descendants live. Other consulates, such as the one in Boston, have attempted to spread the word by contacting German clubs and organizations. ``What we are telling people is that they better claim the property as soon as possible,'' said Cornelia Dautel, a German vice consul in Chicago. ``If they wait until after October 13, they will have much legal difficulty trying to reclaim the land.'' East Germany and West Germany were joined Wednesday after months of negotiations. Earlier this year, East Germany passeda law permitting people to reclaim land that was seized after the communists came to power in 1949. The Chicago consulate has received about 200 telephone calls from people who hope to regain property they or their families owned before World War II, Deputy Consul Karl Schon said. Elisabeth Jacoby of the Chicago suburb of Mount Prospect is one of them. A resident of East Germany until she was 18, Jacoby crossed the border into West Germany in 1951. She left behind her parents, her sister and a childless uncle who owned a prominent hotel in Wolmirstedt, a small city 45 miles east of the West German border. The government converted the hotel into a store in the 1960s, then tore down the building in 1972. Almost 40 years after their uncle's death in 1951, Jacoby, her sister and a cousin who lives in West Germany finally have hope of reclaiming the land on which the hotel stood. ``Before the borders came down and everything changed, there was nothing we could do,'' Jacoby said. ``We had given up hope.'' The government controls the land, which is now being used as a parking lot. But the women - as their uncle's only heirs - are entitled to it under his will, Jacoby said Tuesday. ``Both my parents worked in that hotel,'' Jacoby said. ``We feel our family worked very hard for what they had and we should not let the East German government have it.'' Jacoby's claim is one of more than 1 million - most from West German residents - that the East German government has received since it allowed such claims to be filed. The claims will be evaluated by the local governments where the property is situated. Those who prove they are entitled to the property will be compensated for the land or receive title to the property if possible, Schon said. ``It's question of proof,'' Schon said. ``If a person can establish through the real estate register or other records that he is entitled to the property, then the law says it must be returned to him.''

DOC.HEAD: Charges Filed Over Skier's Blindness
DOC.TEXT: A skier suspended from a team for the disabled after coaches questioned her blindness has been charged with misrepresenting herself to sponsors. Julie Wallace, 26, was charged with theft involving less than $1,000 in cash and benefits. Wallace was suspended from the U.S. Disabled Ski Team in January after coaches questioned her blindness and her claims that she had leukemia, earned advanced degrees from two universities and served as a Navy SEAL. She was barred from participating in world competition for the disabled in February. District Attorney Greg Long said Monday the charges were filed after Wallace failed to honor an agreement that she seek counseling and get an eye exam to determine whether she is blind. Wallace has said she has medical proof that she is totally blind and has leukemia and a brain tumor. She is believed to be living in Traverse City, Mich., and will be arrested if she returns to Colorado, Long said. The U.S. Health and Human Services office in Denver also is investigating Wallace's receipt of Social Security payments, Long said.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Submarine Finds Second Half of United Jet's Cargo Door
DOC.TEXT: A cargo door that blew off a United Airlines jet, sweeping nine people to their death, has been brought ashore for examination by safety investigators after being raised from the floor of the Pacific. The Navy submarine Sea Cliff retrieved the final piece of the door Monday from its resting place 14,100 feet down and 90 miles south of Honolulu. The submarine and its support ship returned to Pearl Harbor on Tuesday. The discovery ended a needle-in-a-haystack search of the ocean floor that began when a sonar-scanning submersible found debris from the jet in July. The three-man submarine recovered the bottom half of the door last week. National Transportation Safety Board officials moved the two halves of the door to a hangar at Honolulu International Airport. Investigators want to know why the door tore away at 22,000 feet shortly after the Boeing 747 took off from Honolulu in 1989 for New Zealand with 355 passengers. The crew managed to return the jet to Honolulu. After investigators examine the debris, parts of it will be sent to the Boeing Co. in Seattle for a more detailed review under board direction, said Navy spokeswoman Sandy Stairs. The NTSB determined that faulty design of a locking mechanism probably caused a cockpit light to indicate falsely that the door was locked. But the agency wants to examine the door to confirm its findings and perhaps bring about better safety rules. The agency blamed United, Boeing and the Federal Aviation Administration for failing to corect problems with the door. It asked the Navy to find the door.

DOC.HEAD: Robbers Use Chain Saw to Get Victim's Watch and Rings
DOC.TEXT: Two holdup men used a chain saw to cut off the left hand of an out-of-work migrant farm worker to steal his expensive watch and two rings, police say. ``They did it for the sheer joy of doing it. That kind of random violence is frightening,'' Police Chief Lane Roberts said Tuesday. The victim, a 20-year-old believed to be from Mexico, asked that his name not be released. He was listed in stable condition at Yakima Valley Memorial Hospital. Investigators said they had no suspects. The victim, a newcomer to the area who speaks little English, told police through an interpreter he was with his cousin and was looking for work. The two were at a grocery store Friday night in this poor Yakima suburb and were approached by two men who offered to sell them a chain saw, Roberts said. One of the men pulled a gun and the two victims were forced into their own car and driven to a remote area, where the hold-up men tried to remove the victim's jewelry, Roberts said. The police chief said the man's watch, valued at $1,500, had a special security latch that was difficult to open. ``It's not something where you reach down with your thumb and pop it loose,'' he said. The victim tried to show the robbers how to remove the watch, but they apparently ``saw this as resistance and took the most expedient method to get to it,'' Roberts said. He said one man held the victim down and the other used the chain saw. The robbers then escaped in a vehicle driven by an accomplice, Roberts said. The victim's 39-year-old cousin, who has been in the United States for eight years, was not harmed and drove him to the hospital, the chief said. ``When people are there with a chain saw, you have to wonder if they are not looking for an opportunity to do something bizarre,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: At Europe's New Dividing Line: German Cheers, Polish Fears
With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As Germans poured champagne and exploded fireworks to celebrate unification today, Poles living on Europe's new dividing line looked on with reserve, expressing hope, fear and a little envy. Prior to the celebration, German youths shouting pro-German slogans threw stones at two Polish buses picking up factory workers across the border in Frankfurt an der Oder. Precisely at midnight, fireworks exploded over the German city and the border station commanders saluted the flag of the German Federal Republic. Earlier, the German guards changed out of their gray uniforms and into the dark green uniforms of the West German units. In the waning hours of East Germany's nationhood, shoppers had rushed across the bridge spanning the Oder, which separates Slubice from Frankfurt. Restrictive border regulations were about to take effect at midnight, and thousands of Germans flooded Slubice to shop cheaply in Poland. Throngs filled sidewalks, and lawns turned into parking lots for East German cars. Amid the crush of commerce and bargaining in two languages, some Poles paused to voice their anxiety at the prospect of having a rich, powerful and populous united Germany a few steps away. ``We can't forget these fears until someday Europe becomes united. Look at our history,'' said Andrzej Macewski. The visiting engineer-turned-street trader from Lodz recalled the agony of World War II, in which 6 million Poles died, and the long list of Polish-German conflicts that preceded it. Some residents of Slubice were less concerned. ``I won't speak badly about the Germans. They come here often and they are very nice. They are our neighbors,'' said businesswoman Katarzyna Taczyniec, who owns two clothing shops in town. Jacek Walentynowicz, a Polish worker in a German tire factory, was pessimistic: ``A German and a Pole have never been brothers.'' ``The younger generation is not so sure about that,'' replied Andrzej, a 25-year-old Polish border guard who would not give his last name. He agreed with the new German border commander, Ultun Topp, that the ``outer border'' between Eastern and Western Europe is now the Oder, which is neatly banked by a brick wall on the Frankfurt side and undulates around low sand bars on the Slubice side. Topp said the tighter travel restrictions are needed on the new border because ``we have to control it for all the people in the European Community. But I believe there will come a time when all the visas will fall away, like with Czechoslovakia. I hope so.'' Walentynowicz had come to the border station to learn if he would be able to go to work today without the newly required visa. He was told he would be let across with proof of German employment. All in all, he said, he is indifferent to unification, ``except that I could lose my job.'' Some of the Poles returning from Germany expressed resentment at a policy requiring visas for Poles visiting what had been East Germany and Berlin. In the past, no visas had been needed for Berlin, and only an invitation for East Germany. The many Poles from this region who work in what was East Germany fear they may now lose their jobs. The German youths who threw stones at the Polish buses shattered windows and injured both drivers. Youths wielding sticks pounded two Polish cars waiting to cross the border. ``To me, it seems horrifying,'' said one passenger, Halina Gawronska. ``We welcome them with open arms and then this. We live together. ... How could they?'' ``There was always great friendship, but now we don't know what is going on,'' said a companion, Genewa Kowalska. Anti-Polish attitudes spawned in part by aggressive commerce in both directions across the river and long-held antagonisms. The border along the Oder and Neisse rivers was created after World War II. One-third of Poland is land forfeited by a defeated Germany. Some Germans have never relinquished claims to the former lands. During unification talks, Poland extracted promises from the parliaments of both Germanys that the border would be made final in a treaty between Poland and the united Germany's new government.

DOC.HEAD: Casino Opens in Tiny Reservation Town
DOC.TEXT: Gamblers drawn by $1 million jackpots and pickup trucks as prizes are trying their luck at South Dakota's first Indian casino, the newest hope of prosperity for the hard-pressed Santee Sioux tribe. The casino, in the style of Las Vegas and Atlantic City, N.J., opened Tuesday with slot machines, card games and bingo on a dusty plot of reservation land surrounded by cornfields outside Flandreau, population 2,200. The town is small but the stakes are high for gamblers as well as the Sioux, who stand to earn $750,000 to $1 million in the casino's first year. Some of the slot machines offer a jackpot of $1 million. Others offer new Ford pickups as top prizes. The tribe is the first of nine in South Dakota to receive state permission to open a casino under the National Indian Gaming Act of 1988, based on a 1987 U.S. Supreme Court ruling that once a state allows any form of gambling, Indian tribes can offer the same games, without government restriction. ``It's cheaper than flying to Las Vegas and paying for plane fare and hotels,'' said Sondra Feldman, who played the slots with her husband, Norm. ``I think it'll go over good,'' said Mrs. Feldman, who lives in nearby Sioux Falls. Jim Lewis, who developed the casino for the tribe, said he'll make slightly less than the amount he estimates will go to the Santee Sioux each year. He also wants to develop a supper club and two hotels across from the casino. The casino's bingo section is hooked to the Megabingo network that links bingo operations of other tribes. The network offers a prize of $500,000 every night and $1 million on Saturdays. Thirty-five people were in line when the doors opened at 9 a.m. By noon, Lewis estimated 300 people had gone through the casino. Many in the crowd were retirees. Some people stopped by on their lunch breaks. A check of license plates in the dirt parking lot showed most were from South Dakota, with some from Minnesota. ``I think come this weekend, we should be seeing 3,000 people through the doors,'' Lewis said. Flandreau is one of only two places where gambling is allowed in South Dakota, which will soon join a regional lottery network with neighboring states. Gambling began in 1989 in Deadwood, the Black Hills gold rush town where Wild Bill Hickok was gunned down in 1876 while playing poker. Since May, gambling has brought the town nearly 1,000 jobs and strained streets, parking lots and water and sewer systems. The state Gaming Commission has approved gambling licenses for at least 50 businesses in Deadwood. Casino supporters in Flandreau say it will bring much-needed jobs and economic development. Indians are going through tough times in South Dakota. On nine reservations, unemployment is about 80 percent and alcoholism, drugs and poor health are severe. South Dakota has about 45,000 Indians, more than 6 percent of its population. Some of the gamblers pouring money into the casino's coffers said they wouldn't want one in their hometown. ``It's not too good for the people,'' said Don Cover of Madison. ``It seems the people who can't afford to spend the most money. I think they can come up with other ways to raise money.''

Former National Assembly speaker Carlos Nunez Tellez, who helped plot the Sandinista revolution that overthrew dictator Anastasio Somoza, died Tuesday of heart failure. He was 39. Nunez was one of the nine Commanders of the Revolution of the Sandinista National Liberation Front, the masterminds of the 1979 coup. He and his older brother Rene joined the underground Sandinista movement in 1969, and he rose steadily through the ranks. He was elected speaker of the National Assembly in 1984.

Davey Day, a boxer who briefly held the lightweight title a half-century ago, died of liver cancer Tuesday at age 78. Boxing associations in several states recognized him as the titleholder after champion Lou Ambers wouldn't fight Day, the top-ranked contender in the division. In 1939, Day lost a bout for the welterweight title to Henry Armstrong. Day retired from the ring in 1941 with a 74-7-6 record.

Mayor Walter R. Tucker, who helped make Compton the first city in California to outlaw automatic weapons, died of cancer Monday at 66. Tucker, an early gun-control advocate, pushed relentlessly for the ban, which the Southern California city adopted last year. A dentist by profession, Tucker was elected mayor in 1981 after four years as a city councilman.

David C. Huntington, a retired professor and former chairman of the University of Michigan's art history department, died Saturday of heart failure at age 67. Huntington, department chairman from 1985 to 1988, was credited with helping revive interest in the work of 19th-century American landscape artist Frederick Church.

DOC.HEAD: No Cable for Souter, Watches Senate Debate on Friend's TV
With PM-Souter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: David Souter can't get cable TV for the black-and-white set at his farmhouse, so he watched himself become the Supreme Court's newest justice at a friend's law office. The soft-spoken judge toasted the moment with champagne and was cheered by friends after the Senate approved his nomination 90-9 Tuesday night. ``I have read in more than one place remarks by members of the Supreme Court who have said that nothing prepares a person to assume the responsibilities of that office,'' he told reporters. ``I believe very strongly that I am going to feel the same way.'' Souter, a 51-year-old bachelor of spartan tastes, drove himself the 12 miles from his farmhouse in his native Weare to the Concord law office of his friend, Tom Rath, to watch the Senate debate. In a parking garage, reporters watched as he struggled with an electronic meter that refused to acknowledge his quarters. ``I'll tell you I've certainly got a lot of witnesses that I tried to put money in the meter,'' he joked. ``So if I get a ticket, you guys are witnesses.'' Souter appeared stunned into silence after the vote and about 20 minutes of celebration and calls from President Bush, Vice President Dan Quayle and Justice Anthony Kennedy, until now the high court's newest member. Souter was driven a block to the Statehouse and ducked into Gov. Judd Gregg's office. He later emerged to address reporters and state employees. ``Both the president's nomination and the Senate's confirmation are wholly beyond the scope of any thanks I could give to them,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: NJ Candidates Try to Tie Opponents to Florio's Tax Hike
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 2nd graf, ``Many Democrats xxx to CORRECT seven months to five
DOC.TEXT: Republican candidates in New Jersey are trying to capitalize on taxpayer anger by linking their opponents to Democratic Gov. Jim Florio and his $2.8 billion tax package. Many Democrats, meanwhile, are trying to distance themselves from the governor who pushed through the state's biggest tax hike after just five months in office. In New Jersey's 12th Congressional District, Democrat Marguerite Chandler's radio ads start with an attack on Florio instead of her GOP opponent. State Sen. Richard A. Zimmer, who also is trying to tap into discontent with the state's Democratic administration, responded with a reminder that Mrs. Chandler just four months ago congratulated the governor for his courage in tackling the budget deficit. His campaign ads warn that Mrs. Chandler could do what Florio did: promise no new taxes and then flip-flop once elected. Florio has blamed the state's budget woes on former Republican Gov. Thomas H. Kean, claiming he was forced to break a campaign promise against raising major taxes because he didn't know how bad things were. Republicans watched their gubernatorial nominee, Rep. James Courter, go down in a landslide last fall. Now they are predicting that Florio's tax package could revive their prospects for recovery. ``There is going to be a price to be paid by every Democrat who ran around New Jersey last year calling for the election of Jim Florio as governor of New Jersey,'' said Robert Franks, the state Republican chairman. Democrats concede the issue has caught on to some degree. ``Will the tax issue have an effect? Yes, it's probably going to have at least a marginal effect in every race,'' said Stephan DeMicco, executive director of the New Jersey State Democratic Committee. The question is whether the GOP can make the issue stick on Eection Day. ``Republicans surprisingly have not been able to make a coherent argument that Democratic candidates for Congress should be held accountable for the actions of a Democratic governor,'' said Richard Roper, director of the Council on New Jersey Affairs at Princeton University. Roper, who advised the Florio campaign last year, said that in the U.S. Senate race, long-shot GOP challenger Christine Todd Whitman has been unable to force Democratic incumbent Bill Bradley to speak out about the Florio taxes. ``We are distancing ourselves from the particulars of the tax package because Sen. Bradley had nothing to do with it,'' said Nick Donatiello, Bradley's campaign manager. Roper said tax anger should influence the race in Florio's old House district, where Democratic nominee Robert Andrews is perceived as Florio's chosen successor. ``I do think it's likely the Democratic candidate in south Jersey's 1st District may suffer as a result of his association with the Florio organization in Camden County,'' Roper said. Franks said GOP polling has detected resentment against Florio in his former backyard. ``People in his home area feel very much betrayed in terms of his rhetoric during the campaign and the product he delivered,'' Franks said. Democrats also should not discount the power of the grass-roots anti-tax movement in the 3rd District along the Jersey Shore, Franks said. In that race, Republican challenger Paul Kapalko is trying to link incumbent Democrat Frank Pallone Jr. to Florio. Pallone, however, is running as an anti-tax candidate. Roper foresees no Democratic casualties from the GOP's anti-tax strategy. ``The people who are up for re-election on the Democratic side, especially for the U.S. Senate, are extremely popular and are not likely to be painted with the Florio tax brush,'' Roper says. But the GOP is betting on its anti-Florio strategy, offering local candidates cable TV spots admonishing voters that if they want to send Florio a message this fall, they should vote Republican.

DOC.HEAD: Accountant Finds Manuscript of Mozart Works
DOC.TEXT: An accountant looking through an old safe at a Baptist seminary has found a lost manuscript of two famous Mozart piano works. ``I thought, gee, this couldn't be real, these are in an archive in the Louvre or somewhere in a museum,'' Judy DiBona said Tuesday. The 14-page original manuscript of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's ``Fantasia in C Minor'' and the ``Sonata in C Minor'' will be auctioned Nov. 21 in London. Sotheby's auction house said it is worth between $940,000 and $1.4 million. The whereabouts of the brown-ink manuscript had been unknown since the 1915 death of its American owner, William H. Doane of Cincinnati. Found with it were lesser compositions by Franz Joseph Haydn, Johann Strauss the Elder and others. They are expected to fetch a total of about $110,000 at the same sale. Manfred Brauch, president of Eastern Baptist Theological Seminary in Philadelphia, said the manuscripts had been listed in insurance records since 1984. But the insurance company was not aware of the potential value, he said. Ms. DiBona, accounting manager at the sister Eastern College in nearby St. Davids, found the Mozart manuscript in a vault within a vault in July while looking for historical records. ``I hummed it and played it with my fingers - I'm a pianist,'' she said. ``I can't express the feeling of joy to be the first one to touch these manuscripts in years.'' Doane, a composer of hymns and a philanthropist, left the manuscripts to his widow. They were passed to his daughter, who in 1950 donated them with funds to build a chapel and music rooms at the seminary, Brauch said. ``Scholars have not seen this Mozart manuscript since the early 19th century,'' said Stephen Roe, a Sotheby's expert on music manuscripts. ``It went through several hands and crossed the Atlantic to Doane's collection in 1889. ``The two works have been played regularly by great pianists since Mozar's time and he himself performed the `Fantasia' in 1789. They contain some of his most moving music in the minor key,'' Roe said. Eugene K. Wolf, professor of music at University of Pennsylvania, was asked to authenticate the manuscript. ``It was immediately apparent that this was the lost manuscript,'' he said. Wolf, a specialist in 18th century instrumental music, said the manuscripts ``were in two manila envelopes that merely said `sacred music' on the outside. That's not likely to stir your interest.'' The works were written in 1784 and 1785 when Mozart was in his late 20s. They are usually performed together. Wolf said the manuscript has great interest for scholars. ``It contains two sets of variations on the main theme, one of which has never been known before,'' he said. ``It tells us about Mozart's compositional process.'' Brauch said the manuscript will be displayed at the seminary Oct. 15. That evening, the two works will be be performed at the seminary chapel.

DOC.HEAD: Hand Nearly Severed by Hatchet
DOC.TEXT: A police officer following a bloody trail from the street into a woman's kitchen arrested her on charges of nearly hacking off the hand of a man she believed had molested her granddaughter, police said. Geraldine Jackson, 44, was jailed on charges of assault with intent to maim in the attack on Wardell Leverette, 47. A police officer found Leverette was lying in a street early Tuesday, bleeding profusely, police Agent Alene Jenkins said. ``The officer followed the blood trail... where he encountered the suspect. The suspect was cleaning the kitchen. She was mopping the blood in the kitchen,'' Jenkins said. Leverette was listed in good condition at University Hospital. Police said Jackson told them that Leverette, a former boyfriend of Jackson's sister, had fondled her granddaughter and that ``she was going to cut his arm off so he couldn't touch any other children.'' Two hatchets and two knives were found in the house, police said. The girl was examined at University of Maryland Medical Center, where doctors found no physical evidence of abuse, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei, Dollar Down Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Share prices fell slightly today in Tokyo, dashing hopes that the market's record recovery the day before had signaled a turnaround from a nine-month decline. Meanwhile, the dollar closed at 136.65 yen, down 0.08 yen from Tuesday's clos of 136.73 yen. It opened at 136.33 yen and ranged between 136.21 yen and 136.70 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, which gained 2,676.55 points Tuesday in its largest daily gain ever, fell 49.02 points, or 0.21 percent, ending the day at 22,849.39. Today's trading was moderate with 600 million shares changed hands on the first section. The market's key index closed the morning session 331.16 points higher, but that was the end of an afterglow left by government support measures that triggered Tuesday's surge, traders said. They said the index lost about 600 points within the first 30 minutes of afternoon trading as profit takers dumped issues. Masahiro Umemori, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co., said Tuesday's rise ``would not set a new trend, although expectations about easier monetary policy reassured investors.'' ``I think the market has not hit bottom. It's going to fall some more,'' he said. On Tuesday ``many investors were confused by the sudden changes in the market and were not quite sure what they should be doing.'' In the first nine months of this year, the market has lost 17,932.37 points, or 46.1 percent, from last year's close at 38,915.87. The losses are equivalent to $2.1 trillion. ``The market will continue to seek its bottom for awhile,'' said Kazu Nomura, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. ``The market's environment is so bad and pessimistic. Investors have no buying incentive.'' On Monday, Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto announced a series of measures aimed at spurring buying and reducing market volatility. The measures include easing restrictions on stock purchases on credit and shorter hours for futures and options trading to stymie speculators. Hashimoto also mentioned the possibility of easing monetary policy temporarily. Some analysts say an easier monetary policy for the sake of revitalizing the stock market should be only a temporary measure. Over a longer period, a looser monetary policy amid higher oil prices and the tight labor market could ignite inflation, they say. Nikko Securities chief trader Yoshio Ogawa said the index would have risen farther if a computer breakdown had not halted 45 minutes of morning trading. ``Quick recovery only in terms of the index's gains is no good. The market should digest both buying and selling at the same time and rise back little by little,'' Ogawa said. Traders said rising oil prices and some positive developments in the Gulf crisis, including a recent release of some French hostages from Iraq, contributed the Nikkei's morning increase. The index's afternoon plunge was fueled by large-scale selling by foreign brokerages following a false rumor about fighting in the Gulf, said Nomura of New Japan Securities. Japan is highly vulnerable to unrest in the Gulf because it imports virtually all its oil, with 70 percent of it coming from the Middle East. Meanwhile, an economic forecast released by the Research Institute on the National Economy, a privately funded think tank, predicted that stock market declines will inflict only minor damages on the Japanese economy. ``Losing a bubble is rather a plus to the Japanese economy in the long run,'' it said. ``A series of stock market plunges paved the way for growth with balance between actual economy and financial markets.'' On the foreign exchange, dealers said falling oil prices triggered the dollar's slip against the yen earlier today. Lower oil prices helped the yen gain slightly against the dollar and the European currencies early today, but rumors of fighting in the Middle East discouraged the yen buying in the afternoon session, dealers said. They said investorsavoided major moves ahead of testimony later today by U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan and Friday's release of U.S. jobless rate. Chemical Bank dealer Minori Takeuchi said market players were hoping to get clues of the Fed's policy on interest rates, which have been widely expected to fall. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 8.310 percent, up from Tuesday's 8.185-percent close. Their price ended lower at 82.32 points from 82.81. Bond dealers said a rumor, also false, that a U.S. fighter jet was shot down in the Gulf sent bond prices lower.

DOC.HEAD: European Cooperation Summit Ends on Note of Hope, Concern
DOC.TEXT: A 35-nation conference of foreign ministers ended with statements of concern about the volatile gulf region, but hope of a treaty to limit conventional arms in Europe. The members of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE) said they were joining the United Nations in condemning Iraq's seizure of Kuwait. A statement from the conference said the Aug. 2 invasion ``jeopardizes the just and peaceful world order to which more cooperative European relations are making an important contribution.'' The conference, which ended Tuesday, included officials from 33 European countries, Canada and the United States. Participants also accepted the U.S. position that an arms reduction treaty should be settled before a planned European-North American summit to be held in Paris Nov. 19-21. Talks on the treaty are under way in Vienna. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, whose countries lead the Vienna talks, said prospects are good for an accord. The two planned to meet today before Shevardnadze returns to Moscow. The arms talks have been on a fast track since they opened in March 1989 between negotiators for the 16 nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the seven of the now-crumbling Warsaw Pact. They were designed to bring both sides to equal ceilings in troops and conventional weapons from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains. The two-day CSCE session in New York was the first held in the United States. The conferences began in 1975 in Finland. ``The objectives set out in Helsinki in 1975 have been realized to a degree unforeseen even a few years ago,'' said Tuesday's communique. ``Ministers agreed that the role of CSCE must be enhanced to respond to new opportunities for cooperation.'' Referring to today's entrance on the world stage of a reunified Germany, Baker said ``a new era is beginning for Germany, for Europe and, indeed, we hope for the world.'' Baker said a proposed permanent secretariat location for the CSCE could be possible in Eastern European. Prague, Czechoslovakia, has become a leading candidate for the site.

DOC.HEAD: Clear Skies in the East, West; Rain in Midwest and Snow in Colorado
DOC.TEXT: Clear skies prevailed over much of the nation today, but rain was forecast in the Midwest and Pacific Northwest and snow was expected in Colorado. Temperatures along the East Coast were expected to be in the 60s and 70s in the north to the 80s farther south, with sunny skies forcast for most of the region. Sunny weather was also forecast for much of the West, with highs in the 60s in the Pacific Northwest and the 80s in California. Highs in the 90s were forecast for the Southwest desert and much of Texas and Florida. Strong winds were expected across the Mississippi Valley and the Great Lakes region. Rain was also forecast from the Great Lakes area all the way south into Oklahoma and Texas, with heavy rain in parts of Texas. Forecasters said the higher elevations in Colorado could get as much as 3 inches of snow. The high temperature for the nation Tuesday was 98 degrees at Meridian, Miss.
