DOC.HEAD: The California Raisins: A Last Tango?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, `You'll see ...' to CORRECT to `she' sted `he.' Also moved for AMs; also in financial report.
DOC.TEXT: The animated raisins that danced off the vine and into the hearts of American consumers are sitting out the next TV commercial, yielding the advertising spotlight to a new clay character. The California Raisin Advisory Board and its advertising company, which since 1986 have used award-winning Will Vinton Productions for memorable ``Claymation'' television ads, said Tuesday they have chosen a new studio. ``There are some slightly different things we wanted to try,'' said Louise Ure, vice president of Foote Cone & Belding, an advertising studio that handles the board's commercials. ``It's just that there are other options out there, more clay animators.'' The shade-wearing raisins that strutted to ``I Heard it Through the Grapevine'' - and appeared on T-shirts and dozens of other products - will be succeeded by a commercial by Sculptoons, a San Francisco studio whose owners are former animators with Portland, Ore.-based Will Vinton. The new spots will feature an animated clay version of actor Carl Ballantine, who appeared as Gruber in the 1960s TV series ``McHale's Navy,'' said Tom Gasek, co-owner of Sculptoons. ``Ballantine'' will play the raisins' manager. Ure said California raisins will appear in the commercials, which are expected to air next month, but he declined to discuss details. Gasek, however, said the raisins wouldn't be singing or dancing. ``You'll see a raisin phone, a raisin lamp, things like that,'' she said. Will Vinton Productions, which won an Academy Award in 1975 for its first animated short, ``Closed Monday,'' was disappointed but not disturbed by the decision. ``We feel kind of strange not doing the new commercial, but it's not hurtful to us; we normally do between 20 and 30 commercials for various clients, so one commercial'' won't make much of a difference, said Robert Phinney, vice president. Another of the studio's creations is the ``Noid'' character seen on Domino's Pizza commercials. He and Ure - whose company seeks bids from various studios for each raisin ad rather than contracting with one firm - said their companies had a good relationship and hoped to work together again. Will Vinton's seven dancing raisin commercials enjoyed critical and practical success since the clay figures' September 1986 debut. The spots won four Clio awards for advertising excellence and helped boost sales of raisins, a $500 million industry in the state's Central Valley. Over a 3{-year period ending last year, U.S. consumption rose nearly 20 percent, said Linda Wood, spokeswoman for the California Raisin Advisory Board. California farmers sold more raisins in 1989 than in any other year except 1984, when growers dropped the price about 30 percent, Ure said. ``It took everyone by surprise,'' she said of the commercials' success. ``We thought it had great promise but we were absolutely astounded by the way the American people embraced the dancing raisins. ... ``There's a certain charm to the characters, and the music is great. It is so reminiscent for people of a great time in our lives. ... It made people think about raisins a lot more.'' The TV spots also spawned dancing raisin T-shirts, lunch boxes, beach towels and other products. ``You name it, we had it. We had about 300 items,'' Wood said. The number of raisin products has now dropped to about 10, but sales of the fruit itself are holding steady, Wood said.

DOC.SECOND: PM-BRF--Gold Tooth Deaths, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0491,0128
DOC.HEAD: Teens Fight Over Gold Tooth: Two Dead, Two Wounded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RESTORES dropped `said' to lead.
DOC.TEXT: Two teen-agers were shot to death and two were wounded in a fight over a gold tooth that had dropped from a boy's mouth, police said. An unidentified 16-year-old boy was arrested in the shootings at an apartment complex Tuesday, police said. He was not immediately charged. Witnesses told police that a group of teen-agers became violent when a gold false tooth fell out of a teen-ager's mouth. Another boy picked up the tooth and refused to return it to the owner, police said. A wounded 15-year-old was listed in stable condition at a hospital. Another 15-year-old was treated for minor wounds and released.

DOC.HEAD: Somber Ceremony At Holocaust Memorial For United Germany
DOC.TEXT: Germany's top diplomat in Israel laid a wreath today in memory of the 6 million Jews slain in the Holocaust after assuring Israel that his reunited country would never reject responsibility for its Nazi past. The somber ceremony at the Yad Vashem memorial to the Jewish victims of the Nazis underscored the sadness and worry felt by many Israelis over the merging of East and West Germany. The speaker of Israel's Parliament, Dov Shilansky, himself a concentration camp survivor, called on Israelis to recite the ``Kaddish,'' a Hebrew prayer of mourning. ``Today the murderers from both sides are unified,'' he said on Israel radio. ``Germany has a stain on its clothing that cannot be removed.'' Polish-born Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, whose parents died in the Holocaust, met briefly at his office with German Charge d'Affaires Heimo Richter before the ceremony at Yad Vashem. Richter handed Shamir a letter from Chancellor Helmut Kohl, restating Germany's commitment to maintain ``friendship and cooperation'' with Israel, Shamir spokesman Avi Pazner said. Shamir told Richter he was ``disappointed there was no mention of the Holocaust'' in the German unification treaty, Pazner added. But the premier also sent ``good wishes to Kohl because this is a day of much significance to the German people,'' Pazner said. Shamir later published a statement urging Germany ``to do its utmost, by all possible means, political, educational and legal, to make sure that what happened in the past will not recur, and that anti-Semitic and neo-Nazi phenomena will be combatted.'' Richter, speaking later to the gathering of about 100 dignitaries at Yad Vashem, said: ``Our one essential message is we remain aware of our historic responsibility. The crimes committed by the Germans and in the name of Germany will never be forgotten.'' Richter symbolically re-lighted an eternal flame in memory of Holocaust victims and laid a wreath in his country's name.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Reaches 127 In Tarmac Collision
DOC.TEXT: Chinese authorities said today that at least 127 people were killed and more than 40 seriously injured when a hijacked plane crashed into two parked jets at this southeastern city's airport. The Xinhua News Agency said that in addition to 90 Chinese, the dead included one American, 30 Taiwanese, four people from Hong Kong and two from Macao. The U.S. Embassy declined to identify the dead American. But Scottie Gilbert of Alexander City, Ala., said she believed her daughter, Mary Anna Gilbert, was killed in the crash. Ms. Gilbert had been traveling with the only known American survivor. A Boeing 737 belonging to China's state-owned airline slammed into the two parked jets at Canton's international airport early Tuesday and exploded in a ball of flames. One of the parked jets was empty. The other, a Boeing 757, was packed with passengers and bound for Shanghai. ``Many people were injured badly and burned,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We have more than 40 seriously injured people now.'' He said 80 out of the 103 people on board the Boeing 737 died and 47 of the 124 people aboard the Boeing 757 were killed. Quoting air traffic controllers, the official said the hijacker appeared confused about where he wanted to go. ``At one time he said Hong Kong, then he said Taiwan,'' the official said. ``We are investigating whether he was a terrorist.'' The hijacking and crash came as China hosts its first major international sporting event, the Asian Games. Security forces nationwide have been on alert to prevent any incidents that might embarrass the government. The hijacker, a 27-year-old man, was killed in the crash and his remains have been recovered, officials said. Reports reaching Hong Kong said he sneaked into the cockpit after the plane took off from Xiamen, a southern Chinese port, by offering the cabin crew some flowers. Survivors told of a huge explosion. Chinese officials said the pilot was allowed to handle the situation ``as he saw fit.'' Early today, relatives of some Chinese passengers yelled at Chinese officials and demanded information about their loved ones during a news conference at the China Hotel. ``They aren't telling us anything,'' said one middle-aged Chinese man. ``It's been 16 hours and still they tell us nothing.'' Chinese authorities released a manifest of the Boeing 737's passengers this afternoon. One of the survivors was Erin Lynne Thomas of Oklahoma City. Ms. Thomas suffered a broken shoulder, head injuries and third degree burns over 5 percent of her body, said her doctor, Zhao Weiming. He was treating wounds on Ms. Thomas' legs this morning when tears came to her eyes. ``I need rest,'' she said. She declined to speak further. Ms. Thomas and Ms. Gilbert had been sitting together, officials said. The plane, Flight 8305 of the Civil Aviation Administration, was hijacked after taking off from Xiamen. The plane flew to Canton, where it circled the airport for about 40 minutes before crashing. Chinese officials, Western diplomats and witnesses provided conflicting accounts of the disaster. A Western survivor said there was a struggle in the cockpit of the hijacked plane as it landed at the airport, causing the craft to careen into the other planes. Other unconfirmed reports said the hijacker detonated a bomb as the plane landed. The accident was the worst publicly acknowledged air disaster in China. In 1982, a civil aviation Trident crashed in the southern city of Guilin, killing 112 people. China rarely disclosed disasters before the 1980s.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS PORT HURON, Mich.-dated 3rd item in rdp to CORRECT that Bacall ex-wife sted wife of Robards.
DOC.TEXT: Tony Award-winning actress Lauren Bacall says the theater is still her first love, but Broadway just isn't the same anymore and she'd rather work in smaller venues outside New York. The former wife of actor Jason Robards complained during a talk at Town Hall here Monday that Broadway's emphasis on reviving old hits in recent years has limited opportunities for actors. ``I'm tired of revivals. I would rather be on stage in Chicago or in a good repertory theater in Seattle than be doing some of the things available on Broadway,'' she said. Miss Bacall, who won Tonys for ``Applause'' and ``Woman of the Year,'' credited her late husband Humphrey Bogart for her success. He starred opposite her in her first movie, ``To Have and Have Not,'' in 1944. ``Bogie was the best teacher I had,'' she said. ``He showed me the ropes. Until I met him, I believed everything I read.''

DOC.HEAD: Teacher With AIDS Who Won Right to Keep Job Dies at 45
DOC.TEXT: Vincent Chalk, the teacher who won a landmark ruling guaranteeing job security for public employees with AIDS, has died. He was 45. Chalk died Tuesday at Saint Mary Medical Center after a three-year bout with AIDS, said his attorney, Marjorie Rushforth. He was admitted to the hospital Thursday. Chalk taught hearing-impaired students at Venado Middle School and University High School in Irvine. ``Vincent settled for every person with AIDS who had a federally related paycheck their right to maintain their employment in spite of an AIDS diagnosis,'' Ms. Rushforth said. When Chalk reported to his superiors in 1987 that he had AIDS, he was removed from the classroom and given an office job. Chalk sued the Orange County Department of Education to be reinstated to teaching. In November 1987, the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overturned a lower court ruling and allowed Chalk to resume teaching. Pearl Jemison-Smith, chairwoman of the Orange County HIV advisory committee, said Chalk ``did for schoolteachers with AIDS what Ryan White did for students with AIDS.'' She was referring to the Indiana youngster who waged a successful battle against AIDS discrimination in public schools. Ryan died April 8. Chalk is survived by his companion, John Woesner, his parents and two sisters.

DOC.HEAD: 207 Western Companies Sold Chemicals, Technology To Iraq, Report Says
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraq built its extensive arsenal of chemical and biological weapons with the aid of more than 200 Western companies, including more than a dozen in the United States, a research agency reports. A report released by the Simon Wiesenthal Center says at least 207 companies sold Iraq chemicals and advanced technology needed to produce and deploy toxic agents, which could be used against U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf. Sales by U.S. companies were approved by the government, but those by German companies often were illegal, the report said. ``We know there is a possibility of a war. What we do not know is we are fighting against ourselves,'' Wiesenthal Center founder Rabbi Marvin Hier said at a news conference. ``If Americans are killed, the people responsible are not those in Iraq, but those in the West, who gave them the technology,'' Hier said. Because of the Third Reich's use of poison gas to kill Jews and others during the Holocaust, the German government had a particular reponsibility to prosecute those involved in illegal sales to Iraq, Hier argued. ``It's not fair to judge today's generation of Germans on the past,'' he said. ``It is fair to judge the current administration on its willingness to sell chemical weapons to Saddam Hussein.'' The 55-page report was compiled for the center by Middle East Defense News, a Paris-based newsletter. The Wiesenthal center, a private foundation, investigates issues related to the Holocaust and tracks Nazi war criminals. Renate Friedmann, spokeswoman for the German consulate in Los Angeles, said her government was cracking down on companies that conducted illegal business with Iraq. But she said some sales involved seemingly innocuous chemicals that did not become lethal until combined with other substances. Among the suppliers cited in the center's report was the U.S. Centers for Disease Control, which sent a deadly virus called West Nile Fever virus to an Iraqi scientist, not knowing it might be used for military purposes. Chuck Fallis, spokesman for the CDC in Atlanta, said the center sent strains to Basrah University in response to a request from an Iraqi researcher who spent three months in 1985 at the CDC's lab in Fort Collins, Colo. Fallis said the center had no indication the virus was used for sinister purposes. The Wiesenthal center's report also said that Hewlett-Packard sold computers that were used in rocket development. Hewlett-Packard spokeswoman Marlene Somsak said the company relied on the U.S. government for guidance in making equipment sales to Iraq. Hier urged sharper controls on legal sales of chemicals and technology. He also said that governments should apply criminal penalties to executives of companies that make illegal sales rather than simply fine the company. The report says that Iraqi chemical weapons plants are capable of producing from 1,400 to 2,500 tons of lethal agents per year. Iraq's stockpile trails only those maintained by the Soviet Union and the United States, the report said. The document was based on previously published articles, anonymous sources and two previously unpublished confidential reports of the West German government regarding arms sales to Iraq and Libya, Hier said.

DOC.HEAD: Small Bomb Explodes Outside U.S. Ambassador's Residence
DOC.TEXT: A small, homemade bomb exploded early today at a rear gate to the U.S. ambassador's residence, causing minor damage and no injuries, police and an embassy spokesman said. Ambassador William Swing was home when the explosion occurred at 1 a.m., said Larry Schwartz of the U.S. Information Service. No group claimed responsibility, he said. ``It's a total surprise,'' Schwartz said. ``It's never happened before.'' He said the device was near a rear gate that can be approached from the road. The gate is outside a wall around the residence in the exclusive Waterkloof Ridge area of Pretoria. The U.S. Embassy is in downtown Pretoria. Schwartz said there was slight damage to the gate. Police said a gate post and guardhouse were damaged, and that flying debris broke a window in a house across the street. The incident came nine days after President F.W. de Klerk met President Bush in Washington. Right-wing whites were upset by de Klerk's statement in the United States, where he said apartheid would be dismantled and South African blacks, presently disenfranchised, would be given equal voting rights. Right-wing whites, who favor strict apartheid, also are angry with the United States for the limited sanctions it has imposed on South Africa to protest apartheid.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslavia Appeals to End Conflict Between Two Biggest Ethnic Groups
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia today appealed to its two biggest ethnic groups to end a conflict that is undermining the country's stability. Two policemen were reported wounded in a showdown with Serbian militants. Yugoslav leaders ordered Serbian militants in the republic of Croatia to remove barricades, disband, and return automatic weapons seized from police armories last week. The nation's leaders also demanded the Croatian republic withdraw special riot police from Serbian-dominated areas of Croatia, one of six Yugoslav republics. The Serbian minority proclaimed autonomy within the republic Monday, and its barricades have stopped road and rail traffic in Croatia's eastern sections. ``The situation in many areas with mixed national population has seriously deteriorated,'' a statement by Yugoslavia's collective presidency said today, adding there are threats of ``nationalist conflicts with tragic consequences.'' Serbia is Yugoslavia's largest republic, and Croatia is the second-largest. The traditional conflict between the two republics has been exacerbated since a center-right coalition defeated the Communists in Croatia and took control of the republic earlier this year. Serbs, who make up 500,000 of Croatia's 5 million people, charge the new government is discriminatory. Croatian authorities charge the Communist government of Serbia is whipping up ethnic tensions to destabilize Croatia. The Yugoslav presidency also ordered Croatia to release ``illegally detained Serbs.'' At least 27 people have been arrested since the arms were taken. Three Croatian policeman have been wounded in clashes with Serbian protesters since Friday. Two were wounded Tuesday at a roadblock near Knin, a Serbian-dominated city of 10,000 in Croatia. The official Yugoslav news agency Tanjug reported today that the two were stopped by Serbian militants at a roadblock and ordered to surrender their weapons. The police refused and tried to leave, but the militants fired on them, wounding them slightly, Tanjug said. On Friday, a Croatian policeman was wounded in clashes with Serbian protesters in Petrinja, another city south of the Croatian capital, Zagreb. On Tuesday, Yugoslav leaders blocked the move for a self-sufficient defense force in another republic, Slovenia, and ordered the federal army to remain in the defiant region. The presidency said the nation's stability was treatened by the constitutional amendment passed Friday by the Slovenian Parliament saying the republic was solely responsible for its defense. Traditional animosities and political rivalries between republics with democratically elected governments and Communists are pulling the federation apart along ideological and ethnic lines. Slovenia also ousted its Communist leadership in an election earlier this year. Slovenia and Croatia want the nation changed into a loose confederation of sovereign states. The two groups have had ethnic disputes dating from Yugoslavia's birth in 1918. Yugolavia's collective presidency, made up of representatives from each of the country's six republics and two provinces, is formally the highest body in the land. It is also in charge of the armed forces.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Most Affected by Increase in Asthma Deaths
DOC.TEXT: Asthma deaths, once declining, have made ``an alarming reversal'' and have risen steadily in the United States with blacks and the poor among those most affected, researchers say. ``The message we got ... was very clear. (Asthma deaths) are going up, and they're going up for the youngest of children,'' said Dr. Kevin Weiss, the lead researcher in a study reported in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. The researchers also found that the Chicago metropolitan area and New York City were leading the deadly trend. Because of asthma's growing severity in inner cities, Weiss said, the National Institute for Allergies and Infectious Diseases soon will announce a major study aimed at understanding the disease's severity in urban areas. Researchers could not fully explain the increased death rates. The suspicions are that it's a combination of lower access to medical treatment and a worse environment in urban areas, Weiss said in a telephone interview Tuesday. Weiss, who works at George Washington University Medical Center and the National Institutes of Health, and co-author Dr. Diane K. Wagener of the National Center for Health Statistics wrote that previous research tended to blame the increase largely on diagnostic changes. But they said that explanation alone doesn't suffice. Asthma, which afflicts an estimated 9.9 million people in the United States, ``affects children, blacks and the poor disproportionately,'' the researchers wrote. ``For example, asthma hospitalization rates and mortality are more than twice as high among blacks as whites,'' they reported. The researchers noted that from 1968 almost through the 1970s, the nation's asthma mortality rates declined. Yet, they wrote: ``Since the late 1970s, there has been an alarming reversal. It seems that rates are increasing faster among younger children, aged 5 to 14 years, than among adolescents and young adults, aged 15 to 34 years.'' An accompanying editorial called the findings ``worrisome because they come at a time when morbidity and mortality from many chronic diseases are decreasing, when we think we have a fairly sound understanding'' of asthma, ``and when we believe we have more effective drugs for its management.'' The asthma death study examined government data on deaths of 5-to 34-year-olds from 1968 through 1987 in all 48 states except Hawaii and Alaska and in the District of Columbia. Asthma deaths rose steadily from 1978 through 1987, the most recent year data were available. The 1987 rate was 4.2 per million population, while the 1968 level was 4.0 per million. The highest mortality rate in 1987 was among non-white males - 13.5 deaths per million and almost five times higher than the level for whites of both sexes. When combined, New York City and the six-county Chicago metropolitan area accounted for 21.1 percent of the asthma deaths studied, suggesting those areas ``are driving the U.S. trend'' in rising asthma mortality, the researchers wrote. ``We don't know why,'' Weiss said. ``All we can say now is, we finally found a place where we can do some deep, in-depth studies.'' Dr. Frank Speizer of Harvard Medical School, who was not involved in the studies, blamed the increased hospitalizations of blacks on ``the inadequacy of our health-care system.'' But Speizer, who is researching respiratory diseases, said the trend might speak well of doctors who now better realize that asthma patients often need hospitalization.

DOC.HEAD: Heart Patient Revived With Plumber's Helper
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `The doctor...', to CORRECT spelling of precordial.
DOC.TEXT: It won't fit in a doctor's bag but the lowly household toilet plunger has proved its medical mettle. A doctor says a San Francisco heart patient was revived twice by family members who reached for the plumber's helper. Dr. Keith G. Lurie of the University of California-San Francisco Medical Center related the incidents in a letter in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. He said a 65-year-old man with severe heart disease collapsed while watching television one evening. His son, poorly trained in cardiopulmonary resuscitation, tried unsuccessfully to revive the man by mouth-to-mouth resuscitation and chest compression. Lurie said the son then remembered that his mother had resuscitated her husband six months earlier with a toilet plunger. So the son got the plunger and used it to plunge his father's chest for 10 minutes until paramedics arrived. By that time, the patient had begun to move and breathe on his own, Lurie said. The doctor speculated that the plunger delivered a ``precordial thump,'' just as medical experts would have, and served as an effective chest compressor. Lurie said the plunging also may have helped draw air into the patient's lungs. He said the son suggested that toilet plungers be placed next to all beds in the hospital's coronary care unit. ``We recommended that he take a basic CPR course but had to admit it's hard to argue with success,'' Lurie wrote.

DOC.HEAD: World Welcomes United Germany, But Anxiety Tinges Historic Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 5th pvs, `Japan and...' to UPDATE with Asian reaction. Pickup 6th, `In New...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: World leaders today showered congratulations on the new Germany. But in Europe, the continent with a giant new power and also long memories, signs of anxiety tinged the historic day. ``We face the future as friends, allies and partners,'' Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said in a message today to Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany. But she said in a British television interview this week, ``Germany will be very dominant in Europe, so it will be up to the rest of us not to allow it to dominate. Others of us have powerful voices.'' Many European newspapers referred today to World War II and some included German words from the Nazi cry of the 30s: ``Ein Volk, Ein Reich, Ein Fuhrer - one people, one state, one leader.'' But others focused on the realization of a dream - what Norwegian Foreign Minister Kjell Magne Bondevik called ``the end of the postwar division of Europe.'' Japan and other Asian countries welcomed German unification, which Japanese Emperor Akihito called ``a historic turning point in ushering in the new world.'' In New York, U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, ending a 35-nation meeting Tuesday on European cooperation and security, declared: ``A new era is beginning for Germany, for Europe, and indeed we hope for the world.'' From Moscow, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent Kohl congratulations Tuesday. He paid tribute ``to all those in my country and in your country who ... did not yield to prejudice and fears, but persistently worked for the future, making this peaceful and worthy solution of the `German issue' possible.'' And President Francois Mitterrand of France, who like Mrs. Thatcher has reservations about German dominance, told Kohl: ``We have come a long way together. We are going to continue ... Tell those close to you, tell all Germans of the solidarity of France.'' Even the world's current pariah, Iraq, weighed in with a message to the ``friendly Germany people.'' The Foreign Ministry in Baghdad said Germany's postwar division was ``to serve the strategies and selfish interests of the major powers,'' the official Iraqi news agency reported. Germany's top diplomat in Israel, Heimo Richter, laid a wreath today in memory of the 6 million Jews slain in the Holocaust and assured Israel that his reunited country would never reject responsibility for its Nazi past. Everywhere, television coverage of Germans celebrating into the early hours and singing their national anthem dominated news bulletins, while newspapers heralded the rebirth of the nation with banner headlines. European editorial comment laced memories of the Nazi devastation of Europe in World War II with unease about the speed of unification and relief that Germany is anchored firmly in NATO and the 12-nation European Community. ``The emergence of a fat, self-centered Germany, free from the military threat from the East, is a more potent danger than that of the lean and angry nation of the Thirties,'' London's conservative Daily Telegraph said in an editorial. In France, the leftist daily Liberation said, ``Germany united is the victory of European reason.'' But it added, ``On Oct. 3, 1990, forgetting is forbidden ... Neither the memory of Auschwitz nor that of democratic and peaceful unification should be hidden away.'' In Italy, the conservative Milan daily Il Giornale, headlined its editorial ``Ein Volk, Ein Reich, Ein Kohl.'' In the Netherlands, the liberal De Volkskrant, an Amsterdam daily, wrote that ``it would be counterproductive to the further development of Europe already to begin treating Germany with suspicion.'' Others dismissed completely the fears of German dominance. ``If anything, the immediate danger is the opposite one: of a Germany gazing obsessively at its own navel,'' commented London's respected Financial Times. European royalty sent congratulations. ``I know that the British people rejoice with you,'' said Queen Elizabeth II. Dutch Foreign Minister Hans van den Broek said in a radio interview today that ``Germany will have to play a major role in ensuring ... security on the entire European continent.'' President Mario Soares of Portugal said: ``I have no fear ... because it (unification) is made under the aegis of democracy ... and democratic countries are not aggressive.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Begins Countdown for Saturday's Launch of Shuttle Discovery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `We're ready..', to substitute more recent quote. SUBS 7-8th grafs, `Sending Discovery...', with 3 grafs to add first reference to Meeks, add detail on minor damage sustained Tuesday by Ulysses. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `It will...'.
DOC.TEXT: NASA began the countdown today for this weekend's launch of Discovery on a mission officials hope will get the shuttle program back in motion and help restore the space agency's credibility. The shuttle is scheduled to lift off at 7:35 a.m. EDT Saturday with five astronauts and the plutonium-powered Ulysses probe, which will explore the sun. The countdown clock started ticking at 3:30 a.m. ``We're looking very smooth at this point,'' NASA test director Terry Willingham said several hours after the countdown began. ``Everybody's looking forward to a good launch. It's been a long, dry spell.'' NASA has not launched a shuttle since April because of dangerous hydrogen leaks afflicting Columbia and Atlantis. Discovery is the only shuttle in which hydrogen leaks have not been found and is also the last shuttle to have flown. Discovery's cargo on that last flight - the Hubble Space Telescope - proved a public relations disaster for NASA. It was not until after the $1.5 billion telescope was in orbit that officials learned its primary mirror was flawed. Sending Discovery up and safely deploying Ulysses ``will be a boost for morale and a boost for NASA,'' said NASA project manager Willis Meeks. A generator containing 23.7 pounds of plutonium-238 was installed Tuesday in the probe, tucked inside Discovery's cargo bay. Ulysses will use electricity generated from the decaying plutonium during its five-year journey in space. While hooking up the generator, a worker accidentally sheared off the head of one of four bolts on a small mechanical device used to shift the generator to full power in space. Engineers decided three bolts were enough to secure the device, Willingham said. It will be the second time a shuttle has transported plutonium. The Jupiter-bound Galileo spacecraft contained twice as much when it was carried aloft by Atlantis last October. An Energy Department team of nearly 100 people will be on hand to monitor radiation in case an accident. Activists afraid a Challenger-like accident would scatter the deadly plutonium over Florida and result in untold cancer fatalities asked a judge on Tuesday to halt the launch. A hearing is scheduled for Thursday in Washington before U.S. District Judge Oliver Gasch, who refused to stop last year's launch with plutonium. The activists said NASA is downplaying the threat of cancer and that the space agency's inability to fix Columbia's hydrogen leaks calls into question its competency. NASA replied in court papers that it conducts ``an elaborate and exhaustive safety review'' before a flight. Space agency officials insist the chance of a plutonium release is extremely small and would pose little health risk. NASA tried four times in four months to launch Columbia before stopping two weeks ago to turn its attention to Discovery, which must lift off by Oct. 23 or wait 13 months for the planets to be in the right alignment again. Ulysses will speed toward Jupiter and use the planet's gravity to be whipped into orbit around the sun. The probe will explore the sun's poles in 1994 and 1995. The mission is a joint effort of NASA and the European Space Agency, which supplied the $250 million satellite. NASA's share, estimated at $500 million, covers the launch and mission.

DOC.HEAD: Malawi Accused of Massacre of 20
DOC.TEXT: A human rights group, describing Malawi as despotic and brutally repressive, said today that police there killed more than 20 protesters in a previously unreported massacre. The shootings occurred March 18 in Lilongwe, the southern African country's main city, according to the New York-based group Africa Watch. Police fired on stone-throwing demonstrators angry at the authorities' failure to prosecute a businessman who killed one of his employees accused of theft, according to Africa Watch. ``More than 20 protesters'' were killed, including passers-by, and many were injured, said the group. It was not immediately possible to get confirmation of the incident from sources in Malawi. Africa Watch detailed the deaths in a 116-page report entitled ``Where Silence Rules: The Suppression of Dissent in Malawi.'' The report, scheduled for publication Oct. 10, was obtained today by The Associated Press. The report examines what Africa Watch describes as a quarter century of human rights abuses under president-for-life Kamuzu Hastings Banda. It accuses Western governments of ignoring the situation ``for the sake of their own interests in Malawi.'' Malawi has been widely considered a stable Western ally, but Africa Watch said that ``stability has been bought at a terrible cost of human lives snuffed out or forced to endure years of detention without trial.'' ``But whereas totalitarian Eastern Bloc regimes received regular denunciation for human rights abuses, Banda's Malawi receives Western aid,'' Africa Watch said. Africa Watch claims part of the reason for the West's tolerance of Malawi's government under Banda - who has ruled the small, hilly nation since 1964 - is because of ``generally good treatment'' of hundreds of thousands of Mozambican refugees who have fled there in recent years. The report lists Banda's idiosyncracies and eccentricities. Under Banda, Malawi has instituted laws that impose prison sentences on men who wear their hair over their collar or wear flared trousers, and on women who wear skirts shorter than knee-length or pants. Banda, who is estimated to be in his 90s, favors three-piece suits and homburg hats. ``Unfortunately, these eccentricities have often made Banda look like a mere comic opera autocrat and masked the deadly seriousness of his repressive rule,'' said Africa Watch. It accuses his government of regularly arresting people it considers a threat under security laws that allow them to be held without trial indefinitely. Among those detained are the nation's leading poet, Jack Mapanje, and the nation's sole neurosurgeon. Under Banda, Africa Watch said, a leading economist and a prominent journalist, three Cabinet members, a minister of Parliament and members of the Jehovah's Witnesses faith have been assassinated. It said political prisoners regularly are beaten, but criminal prisoners often die after being stripped naked, chained to the floor and denied food or given reduced rations. Africa Watch called on Western nations to pressure Malawi to end its human rights abuses by tying future military or economic aid to the improvement of its human rights record.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Agency Orders Audit of Bone Marrow Donor Center
