DOC.HEAD: Gallery Official: `At No Time Did We Consider Mapplethorpe Exhibit Obscene'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with today's testimony. Picks up 13th graf pvs,`Beatrix Mary...'.
DOC.TEXT: Officials at the gallery that displayed Robert Mapplethorpe's photographs thought the exhibit would be exempt from obscenity laws but tried to get legal protection before the show anyway, a board member testified today. ``At no time did we consider it obscene,'' said Stuart Schloss, legal counsel for the Contemporary Arts Center. ``It was a serious artistic exhibit.'' He testified that gallery officials thought the artistic merit of the exhibit made it exempt from Ohio's obscenity laws, though they expected they would get complaints from the public. Schloss said, however, that the board took the precaution of filing a lawsuit before the exhibit asking the Hamilton County Municipal Court to rule whether the exhibit was obscene. The suit, intended to forestall any prosecution, was never heard and was dismissed April 6. The judge ruled the plaintiffs had no standing to file such a suit. The following day, the exhibit ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment'' began its seven-week public run here. The same day, a Hamilton County grand jury returned misdemeanor indictments charging the gallery and its director, Dennis Barrie, with pandering obscenity and using children in nudity-related material. The defense had said that the case might go to the jury later today after testimony from Barrie. In other testimony today, art critic Owen Findsen of The Cincinnati Enquirer testified under subpoena from defense lawyers. He said that based on his 20 years as a Cincinnati art critic, he thought the Mapplethorpe exhibit contained artistic merit. The Enquirer had tried to quash the subpoena for Findsen at a hearing in court Tuesday, but Judge David Albanese refused to set aside the subpoena. In testimony Tuesday, art critic Jerry Stein of The Cincinnati Post also testified that he thought the Mapplethorpe collection had artistic merit, while an art historian testified that Mapplethorpe took photographs to show the beautiful and the tortured aspects of his life. Robert Sobieszek, historian and curator at the George Eastman House photo museum in Rochester, N.Y., told jurors that the seven photos under attack as obscene have as much artistic merit as the rest of the 175-photo exhibit, which included portraits and floral arrangements. ``The story was of a very full and rich artist who was interested in documenting what was beautiful and elegant on the one hand and tortured and troubled on the other,'' Sobieszek said in videotaped testimony played for the jury. On Tuesday, Prosecutor Frank Prouty asked Sobieszek if communities are ``at the mercy'' of curators who try to impose their view of art. ``That would be a very harsh way of saying it,'' Sobieszek said. If convicted, Barrie could get up to a year in jail and a $2,000 fine. The gallery could be fined up to $10,000. Mapplethorpe, a homosexual, began work on the show after he was diagnosed with AIDS. He died of the disease in March 1989 at age 42. The seven photos show the genitals of two children, a man urinating in another man's mouth and anal or penile penetration with various objects. Beatrix Mary Nevill of London and Claryssa Dalrymple of New York, mothers of the children in the separate photos, said in depositions that Mapplethorpe took the pictures and exhibited them with their consent. ``It did not occur to me that there could be anything in the photograph that would offend anyone,'' Ms. Nevill said of her daughter's photo. ``I think it is a very charming photograph.'' The U.S. Supreme Court's test of obscenity is whether the dominant theme of the artwork appeals to prurient interest, whether the work is offensive based on community standards and whether it lacks serious artistic or political value. Defense attorneys noted the exhibit drew 80,000 people in Cincinnati, wich they say indicates the photographs meet community standards.

DOC.HEAD: Five Villagers, Two Policemen Killed
DOC.TEXT: Separate attacks by Tamil rebels left five Sinhalese villagers and two policemen dead, military officials said Wednesday. The villagers were hacked to death Tuesday by a squad of rebels at Wahalkada village in the northern Anuradhapura district, officials said. During the killings, other rebels besieged the police station, preventing officers from aiding the villagers. The slain villagers included three women - two of them pregnant - and a boy, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Six villagers were injured. Two policemen were killed and six were injured in a rebel ambush on a patrol Tuesday night at Arantalawa village in eastern Ampara district, officials said. At least 14,000 people have been killed since rebels from the minority Tamil community started a violent campaign in 1983 claiming they are discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese.

DOC.HEAD: Rising Oil Prices Boost Factory Orders, But Industrial Sector Weak
DOC.TEXT: Rising oil prices from the Persian Gulf crisis helped push up the value of orders to factories for manufactured goods 1.8 percent in August, the government reported Wednesday. Analysts said the oil-inflated boost disguised the weakness in the industrial sector. ``To me, the number excluding petroleum is consistent with our view that the economy is sliding and slipping into a recession,'' said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist with the Norwest Corp. in Minneapolis. ``It continues to show the industrial sector is going nowhere and may be sinking a little bit,'' added Bruce Steinberg, senior economist with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York. ``There's nothing in the report to say we're not having a recession.'' The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and non-durable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $244.6 billion, but added that ``most of the increase is attributed to the petroleum refining industry, which had substantial price increases during the month. Excluding petroleum, orders increased 0.6 percent.'' Sohn said ``energy prices went up even more dramatically in September and orders then will be even more exaggerated.'' He suggested the reports should be examined excluding petroleum costs and ``my expectation is that orders will continue to soften.'' Overall non-durable goods orders, which include petroleum, advanced 4.4 percent to $117.1 billion in August including a $3 billion boost in the petroleum and coal category. Non-durable orders had edged up just 0.2 percent in the month prior to the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Orders for durable goods - big-ticket items expected to last more than three years - fell 0.5 percent to $127.5 billion after rising 2.7 percent in July. The drop in August orders was a slight downward revision from the 0.8 percent decline first reported last week. The often-volatile defense orders also jumped following the Iraqi invasion, up 14.4 percent to $8.6 billion after declining 5.1 percent a month earlier. Excluding defense, orders were up 1.4 percent. But orders for non-defense capital goods, a barometer of business plans for expansion and modernization, indicated a cautious investment attitude. Orders plunged 10.2 percent to $35.8 billion, erasing a 10.1 percent advance in July. Among durable goods, electrical machinery orders were up 2.9 percent to $20.9 billion after rising 1.5 percent in July. Transportation orders rose 1.8 percent to $35.4 billion after a 4.6 percent gain a month earlier. Excluding transportation, orders were up 1.8 percent. ``Within transportation, increases in motor vehicles and parts and shipbuilding and tanks more than offset a decline in aircraft and parts,'' the report said. Registering losses were non-electrical machinery, down 5.0 percent to $21.4 billion following a 3.5 percent gain, and primary metals, which fell 2.3 percent to $11.5 billion after a 2.7 percent rise. Shipments, which also were influenced by petroleum, rose 3.4 percent to $245.9 billion. Excluding petroleum, shipments were up just 2.3 percent. Unfilled orders, which were not affected by energy, declined l0.2 percent to $518.7 billion. The order backlog has been relatively unchanged since May, the department said. Inventories edged up 0.2 percent to $373.9 billion but, excluding petroleum, were unchanged from July.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
Queen Says Jordan Still Receives Iraqi Oil
DOC.TEXT: Jordan's Queen Noor said Wednesday her country continues to accept oil from Iraq despite U.N. sanctions against Baghdad because a total cutoff in supplies would cripple her nation. The American-born wife of Jordan's King Hussein also appealed for economic aid for her country which she said is on the brink of financial disaster because of the Persian Gulf crisis brought on by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Noor said Jordan has reduced its dependence on Iraqi oil - it formerly received 90 percent from Iraq and Kuwait - and is looking for new suppliers. Moreover, she said Jordanians are not paying hard currency for the Iraqi oil, which is in repayment for Iraq's past debts to Jordan. Jordan supports the U.N. sanctions and condemns Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, she said. Sh said Iraqi oil shipments to Jordan must be viewed in the ``proper context'' of Jordan's tight economic straits. ``The crisis has dealt us an economic blow,'' she said. In addition, Jordan has sent some humanitarian supplies - food and medical equipment - to Iraq as allowed by the U.N. Security Council. In a wide-ranging question-and-answer session at the Brookings Institute, the 39-year-old Noor, who grew up in the nation's capital, said she sought to clear up any misunderstandings about Jordan's position on the gulf crisis and draw attention to the economic problems brought by the situation. Some Western diplomats contend Jordan has not done enough to help cripple Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, and Saudi officials have chided King Hussein for what they say is a failure to condemn Iraq with enough force. Jordan expects to lose $4.1 billion as a result of the sanctions against Iraq, its neighbor and formerly its most active trading partner, Noor said. The country's gross domestic product may fall $50 million this year, in part because some 350,000 Jordanians have returned to their homeland where unemployment has doubled. Their remittances have dried up. Noor said the international community has pledged help but the country has ``yet received not much more than promises.'' Jordanian officials have said if the international community wants Jordan to strictly observe economic sanctions, it must provide aid. Coupled with the economic crisis is the influx of refugees who have fled to Jordan from Kuwait and Iraq. ``Eighty percent of the three-quarters of a million evacuees have traveled to Jordan,'' Noor said. ``Large numbers continue to enter, and, evidently this problem will continue to be with us for some time,'' she said. The U.S. Committee for Refugees, a private group, estimates 564,000 have fled to Jordan from Iraq. Some 32,000 remain, but the others have been repatriated, the group said. Noor reiterated her husband's opposition to having foreign forces in Saudi Arabia and other gulf states. While Jordan condemns Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the annexation is an Arab problem demanding Arab solutions, she said. Jordan would be willing to commit military troops to defend the region if they were deployed under the banner of the Arab league, she said. Saying she was speaking as a Arab, Noor said her countrymen believe the United States and other Western nations are applying a ``double standard'' by refusing the impose the same kind of sanctions against Israel that have been slapped on Iraq. The U.N. Security Council has condemned Israel for seizing Arab lands in 1967, but has never enforced sanctions. She also called for international efforts to prod Iraq, Israel and other Middle Eastern nations to eliminate any chemical and nuclear weapons they may possess. On a personal note, Noor said the gulf crisis has had ``devastating consequences'' on her family life. Nevertheless, she said she hoped her four children would be able to learn compassion and responsiblity from the current situation.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Cholesterol-Lowering Surgery Saves Lives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Heart attack patients who undergo an intestinal operation to lower their cholesterol significantly reduce their risk of suffering another heart attack or dying from heart disease, a study shows. The surgery, called a partial ileal bypass, reroutes the bowel to bypass about one-third of the small intestine. This reduces the amount of cholesterol that is absorbed into the bloodstream. Dr. Henry Buchwald of the University of Minnesota, who directed the study, said this surgery should be consdered as a possible treatment for people with high cholesterol who cannot bring it down enough by changing what they eat. An important drawback, however, is diarrhea, which afflicts virtually everyone to some degree after having the operation. Other possible side effects include a higher risk of gallstones, kidney stones and intestinal obstruction. The study is called the Program on the Surgical Control of the Hyperlipidemias, or high cholesterol. It was conducted in Minneapolis, Los Angeles, Philadelphia and Little Rock, Ark., and published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. Despite the wide acceptance of cholesterol lowering, doubts remain about whether it actually helps people live longer if they alrhe desert to Jordan in search of relief, only to be trapped in a 100-mile long caravan of refugees, baking in the sun with little help available,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, who presided at the hearing. Eagleburger said the people who left Iraq and Kuwait impose a severe burden on such countries as Jordan and Turkey. He acknowledged that conditions in some camps were hard at first but said there had been no deaths from starvation or epidemic. ``In Jordan, the worst camps have been closed and the residents have been moved to new camps with adequate sanitation and shelter,'' he said. ``In Turkey, the only victims of hunger and disease are newly arrived displaced persons who developed their conditions while still in Iraq.'' He added that the most critical element in the emergency may be the effort to get people back home. The largest number of these are Egyptians, he said, but gave no further breakdown by nationality.

DOC.HEAD: `Cradle of Rebellion' Celebrates End of East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Ilse Mueller on Wednesday gently placed a little red candle next to Leipzig's St. Nicholas Church, considered by many the birthplace of East Germany's quiet revolution. ``This is to remember all the people persecuted during those 40 years,'' Ms. Mueller said of four decades of Communist oppression. The gritty industrial city was the cradle of East Germany's peaceful popular revolt last fall that later swelled into the drive for unification. To celebrate the merger Wednesday, thousands of its residents shopped and drank as the heart of the city was turned into a huge open-air market. Western business people cashed in on the official holiday by trucking in stalls that offered everything from leather jackets to candy. But it was a time for reflection as well, especially for tens of thousands in Leipzig who helped free their country by going to the streets to demand an end to totalitarianism. Those weekly Monday marches began at the Lutheran church and then spread along downtown streets to the headquarters of the once-feared secret police. Demonstrators chanted ``We Are the People!'' - a phrase that quickly became a nationwide motto for pro-democracy groups. The day of reckoning came Oct. 9, 1989, almost exactly one year ago. News reports at the time said Communist leader Erich Honecker was considering ordering troops to shoot at the more than 70,000 demonstrators that night, hoping to end the pro-democracy movement. ``The whole city was tense, the hospitals even had extra blood brought in case there was a disaster,'' said Sven Hornig, 25, one of the marchers who gathered at the church that night. Miraculously, there was no bloodshed. Leipzig dignitaries, including famed conductor Kurt Masur, and local party officials intervened to prevent violence - breaking the authoritarian hold of Honecker's government. Honecker was ousted from power nine days later. Since then, St. Nicholas Church has become something of a shrine. On Wednesday, hundreds of tourists and residents milled around on the cobblestone square where the old church stands. ``I marched on Oct. 9,'' said one drunken Leipziger, trying to keep his balance on a bar stool on Sachsen Square. ``For 10 marks, I will tell you all about it.'' Like many Leipzigers, he was proud of his role in changing German history, but the solidarity that brought that change is gone. Many leftists and artists in Leipzig oppose the dissolution of East Germany, saying the nation could have been salvaged as a new democracy. More conservatives Germans say unity was the only answer. ``At the time (last fall), we were all limiting our demands to democracy because no one knew how bad the economy was,'' Hornig said. ``There would have been a total collapse and chaos without unification.'' Leipzig hopes to take advantage of its role in changing Germany to become one of Europe's most important cultural and trade centers. It already has impressive musical and stage offerings and an annual trade fair. But many of the city's buildings are nearly in ruins after 40 years of Communist neglect. Right-wing extremism is rising in tandem with joblessness and despair among many Leipzig youths. After church bells pealed German unity at midnight Tuesday, about 100 masked neo-Nazis demolished cars, smashed windows with clubs and fought with police. Six people were injured, and many of the radicals were arrested. The unrest in Leipzig presents a united Germany with a new challenge: to meet the hopeful expectations of those who took to the streets to bury East Germany.

DOC.SECOND: PM-2 Live Crew Trial, 3rd Ld, 3rd Add, a0572-587-602-604-606,0424
DOC.HEAD: URGENT
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.: group's album.
DOC.TEXT: Assistant State Attorney Leslie Robson argued that the right to free speech is not absolute, saying: ``The First Amendment does not give you the right to say what you want, when you want and where you want. With rights and freedom come responsibility.'' As the jurors began deliberating, alternate juror Sheryl Salomon, who sat through the trial but was not needed on the final panel, said she would have voted for acquittal. ``I was very offended by it, especially the lyrics, but I have to question whether there is not artistic value,'' she said. ``It's music, it's still music.'' In the final day of testimony Tuesday, a psychologist testified that the group's music may be degrading or humorous, but it's not sexually stimulating. Merry Haber, a clinical psychologist in Miami who has been in practice for 25 years, testified in Freeman's defense that she saw no evidence rap music aroused prurient interest, an essential part of the U.S. Supreme Court definition of obscenity. ``I have heard people tell me that they may put music on to create a mood - a little Johnny Mathis and a little wine - but I have never heard anybody say they were turned on by rap music,'' Ms. Haber testified. She said she gave the album to about 15 of her patients to get their opinions. The women found it degrading, and both sexes said it was somewhat humorous. All deemed it boring rather than sexually stimulating, she testified. Broward County Judge Paul Backman has told jurors they should find the album obscene if it appeals to ``morbid, shameful interest in sex'' and violates the standards of average residents of Broward County. The lyrics include graphic descriptions of intercourse and sodomy and have been criticized as promoting violence against women. Supporters of the Miami-based group say criticism of the black rappers smacks of censorship and racism. Another defense witness, Greg Baker, music critic from the Miami weekly New Times, disagreed that rap music is boring. ``It was trendsetting. It's the biggest revolution in music since rock 'n' roll itself,'' he said. John Leland, a music critic for New York Newsday who is considered a leading authority on rap music, also testified on Freeman's behalf that rappers ``were able to make exciting, vibrant music that really drove people nuts. It provokes strong, emotional reactions from people in the audience.'' ---

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Narrow Search for Marfan Syndrome Gene
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Scientists are closing in on the gene that causes Marfan syndrome, an inherited disorder that can make people tall and thin and cause fatal heart disease. An estimated 25,000 to 30,000 people in the United States have Marfan syndrome. Many victims are unusually tall, and the disease is relatively common among basketball players. Abraham Lincoln was also thought to be a victim. Finnish scientists said they believe they have found the general location of the gene. This is an important step toward pinpointing and understanding the precise defect that underlies the condition. Finding the gene should help doctors diagnose the disorder before or soon after birth. However, even with this new understanding, experts say the prospect of curing Marfan syndrome is still remote. ``For the foreseeable future, the discovery of the cause of Marfan syndrome will be of primarily psychological benefit to patients,'' Dr. Reed E. Pyeritz of Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore wrote in an editorial published with the study. The disease can cause a wide variety of symptoms, but the most serious is weakness of the heart. Victims may suffer leaky heart valves or die of a ruptured aorta. The latest report was based on a genetic analysis of five families with the disease in Finland. It was conducted by Dr. Leena Peltonen and colleagues from the National Public Health Institute in Helsinki and published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. The findings have been widely known in medical circles for several months, and efforts are under way to see if the same genetic pattern shows up in other families with the disease. The Finnish researchers narrowed down the location of the defective gene to chromosome 15, one of the strings of genes that contain all of the blueprints for making a human. When they find the defective gene, scientists will then be able to figure out what it does normally and how it causes disease when it malfunctions. Some experts believe the crucial gene may turn out to be one that controls the body's production of fibrillin. This protein is a building material of microfibrils, the fibers that make skin and blood vessels stretch.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Head Says Budget Plan A Start, More Needed Soon
DOC.TEXT: Tax increases and spending cuts in the 1991 bipartisan budget pact probably won't produce the $500 billion in deficit reductions needed over five years, the head of the General Accounting Office said Wednesday. Comptroller General Charles Bowsher told a Senate panel that the deal reached by the administration and congressional negotiators is a first step in reducing the deficit but more tax increases will be needed in one to three years. ``It's a start - and I think we badly need a start,'' Bowsher said. ``The budget is out of control and we badly need a plan to get started.'' Bowsher, whose GAO is an investigative agency of Congress, said the size of the deficit problem had been understated. He estimated a trillion dollars would be needed over seven years or so. He spoke before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee at a hearing on the administration's response to government management failures. He was questioned about the budget plan by Sen. Herbert Kohl, D-Wis. Bowsher said the pressures for deficit cutting imposed by the Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget law have prompted the administration and Congress to arrive at unrealistic estimates of future deficits. Even if this plan is enacted, he said, similar measures would be needed again. ``I'd be surprised if you didn't have to do it at least in three years and maybe in the next year or two,'' he said. Bowsher and Assistant Comptroller Richard L. Fogel said the federal government's capacity to manage itself is deteriorating because of a failure to invest adequately in management systems, computers and salaries for employees. As an example, he cited the Internal Revenue Service, which he said is failing to collect $100 billion a year in taxes. He said less than 1 percent of returns are being audited and that a decline in IRS capability is one reason for the decline over time of corporate tax collections. He said ``a good part'' of that uncollected tax money could be obtained if the government used funds to modernize IRS computer systems. Kohl asked Bowsher what message to the American people was implicit in the bipartisan budget proposal. ``We can't run our shop so we have to go out and get more money from you,'' Bowsher replied.

DOC.SECOND: PM-2 Live Crew Trial, 5th Ld - Writethru, a0614,0754
DOC.HEAD: Store Owner Found Guilty Of Obscenity In Sale of 2 Live Crew Record
