DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE IMMIGRATION ROLL CALL - 3 TAKES
Director Says Gallery Was Committed to Showing Mapplethorpe Work
Laserphoto staffing
With AM-2 Live Crew Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The art gallery director who is on trial for showing homo-erotic photos by Robert Mapplethorpe testified in his own defense Wednesday that he never wavered in his commitment to display the works. Dennis Barrie, on trial with the Contemporary Arts Center on obscenity charges, said he and the gallery's board had talked about the controversy an exhibit of the photos had triggered in Washington, D.C. The government-supported showing of Mapplethorpe's photos was canceled last year in Washington amid a debate over federal funding of art. The National Endowment for the Arts now requires grant applicants to certify that the awards will not be used for work that might be considered obscene. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., pressed for the policy. Barrie, however, said the board strongly supported going ahead with the exhibit. ``This was an exhibition of high quality. It had been seen in other cities and was by a well-known artist,'' Barrie testified under questioning by his lawyer, H. Louis Sirkin, in Hamilton County Municipal Court. Seven photographs in the 175-photo exhibit are at the center of the trial. Five show graphic sex acts involving men, and two show children whose genitals are exposed. Barrie said he was not asked to alter the exhibit in any way and would not have considered doing so. Under cross-examination by Assistant City Prosecutor Frank Prouty, Barrie restated the gallery's commitment to display the photos. ``I thought we had every right and every reason to bring this exhibition to this city,'' he said. Prouty showed Barrie Mapplethorpe's five photographs of explicit sex acts and asked Barrie to comment on them. ``He knew about light. He knew about shadow. ... As difficult as the subject matter may be, you see the ability of the man working through. He was brilliant with a camera,'' Barrie said. The gallery board's legal counsel, Stuart Schloss, testified earlier Wednesday that the board tried to get legal protection before the show. The board filed a lawsuit asking the court to rule whether the exhibit was obscene. The case was never heard and was dismissed the day before the April 7 public opening of ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment.'' On April 7, a Hamilton County grand jury viewed the exhibit and returned misdemeanor indictments charging the gallery and Barrie with pandering obscenity and using children in nudity-related material. If convicted of both misdemeanor charges, Barrie could be sentenced to one year in jail and fined $2,000. The gallery could be fined $10,000 for conviction on both counts. Prosecutors argued that they needed only to show that the photographs were displayed in public, leaving it to the jury to determine whether the photographs were obscene. Schloss testified that gallery officials thought the artistic merit of the exhibit made it exempt from Ohio's obscenity laws. ``At no time did we consider it obscene,'' Schloss said. ``It was a serious artistic exhibit.'' Owen Findsen, an arts reviewer for The Cincinnati Enquirer, and Jerry Stein, arts critic for The Cincinnati Post, testified Tuesday and Wednesday that they thought the exhibit had artistic merit. The U.S. Supreme Court's legal test for an obscenity determination asks whether the dominant theme of the artwork appeals to prurient interest in sex, whether the work is patently offensive based on contemporary community standards, and whether the work lacks serious artistic or political value. Defense witnesses have described the exhibit as a retrospective of the professional life of Mapplethorpe, who died of AIDS in March 1989 at age 42. The exhibit drew more than 80,000 people before its seven-week engagement ended May 26. It went on to Boston where it opened despite protests and 103,000 tickets have been sold. The Boston show closes this week.

DOC.HEAD: Undergrad Athlete's Genetic Discovery Puts Him in Heady Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 3rd graf and the 17th, beginning ``This is,'' to CORRECT spelling of McKusick. A version moving on the sport wire.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The Washington University Bears' second-leading receiver will miss the Oct. 20 football game against Colorado College because of a previous commitment. Chris Warlick, a senior biology major, is going to be the only undergraduate in the country to address more than 5,000 top medical specialists at the American Society of Human Geneticists' national convention in Cincinnati. ``It's certainly distinctly unusual for this to occur,'' said Victor McKusick, a professor of genetics at Johns Hopkins. ``I can't remember any in the recent past.'' The title of Warlick's work: ``Isolation of a Yeast Artificial Chromosome Clone D14S26 Near a Gene for Familial Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy and Identification of Two New Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism Probes at this Locus.'' ``He's a very smart guy and he has a great career ahead of himself as a scientist,'' said Helen Donis-Keller, professor of genetics at Washington University's school of medicine. ``The work that he's doing is of great interest in the scientific community these days.'' That's not so odd at Washington University, a Division III school which has a reputation for producing scholars. There are no athletic scholarships, so Warlick and his teammates play for the love of the game. Practice starts at 4 p.m., at least an hour later than for most teams, because many players have labs late in the day. And even at that time, Coach Larry Kindbom has become accustomed to starting practice with about three-fourths of his squad. Last week, Warlick had an 80-yard touchdown catch, and he has 15 receptions for 255 yards and three touchdowns on the year. ``I wish I had a couple of years left to play, but it's not conducive with my future plans,'' he said. Warlick is a B-minus student, struggling with calculus and organic chemistry. ``Two killers - thank goodness they're of no practical value,'' he said. Put him in a laboratory and everything changes. In the summer of 1989, Warlick began working in a genetics lab at the school's medical center. This spring, the lab was part of a project that also involved several other labs around the country in a continuing attempt to map human genes. Warlick's main focus was an area of a chromosome near a marker for a hereditary heart ailment, familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. It's a disease with no outward symptoms that can strike quickly and fatally. Warlick discovered two markers on the chromosome that could help narrow the search for the gene that causes the disease. His discoveries will soon become permanent fixtures on the updated human genetic map, and will bear his initials - CW1 and CW2. ``It's excitng,'' McKusick said, but added: ``I wouldn't call it earth shattering.'' ``This is the type of approach being used all over the place for identifying the gene defect in particular diseases,'' such as cystic fibrosis, McKusick added. But Warlick's discovery is so complex that he has trouble boiling it down in layman's terms. He hopes to be involved in furthering this study but doesn't want to miss out on any student experiences. ``College is probably the last chance you have to experience these extremes and I'm taking advantage of it while I can,'' he said. He's an adopted son of Ernie Warlick, a tight end for the National Football League's Buffalo Bills in the 1960s, but until last season had not played the sport since age 10 because he was undersized. Now he's 6-foot-4 and 180 but it was academics that got him into Washington University. He ranked eighth in his high school class in Williamsville, N.Y., and turned down Dartmouth and Johns Hopkins to accept a full-tuition scholarship awarded to talented college-bound blacks. Coach Kindbom said three freshmen on the team turned down athletic scholarships to attend Washington U. ``Football is a very important part of their lives, but they want to do more than get locked into a situation,'' he said. ``We're talking about people who taste nothing but success, or else they wouldn't be here.''

DOC.HEAD: For Germans, Gorbachev is the Man of the Hour
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf, `Germany will ...' to UPDATE with Gorbachev visit planned.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Germans in East and West have made it clear that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is the man of the hour for clearing the way for unification of the two countries. Since last year, talks with ordinary Germans have revealed a deep-seated admiration for the Kremlin reformer seeking to overhaul more than seven decades of Communist thinking. And as the two German states merged at midnight Tuesday, political leaders praised the man who boldly broke with the Soviets' traditional refusal to even consider unification. ``We thank President Gorbachev,'' Chancellor Helmut Kohl said in a unification-eve television address to the nation. ``He recognized the nations' right to pursue their own path.'' ``Without this decision, we would have not experienced the day of German unity so soon,'' Kohl added. In fact, a heavy outlay of deutsche marks helped Gorbachev swallow his national pride and clear the way for unification. Germany will pay the Kremlin $9.5 billion toward the cost of removing the Soviets' 360,000 troops from former East German territory. Even more aid is likely in years to come. Late Wednesday, a German government spokesman said Gorbachev will visit Germany next month to sign a German-Soviet friendship treaty. He is likely to receive a hero's welcome from grateful Germans. Many Germans, despite their near hero-worship of Gorbachev, worry that he will not hang on to power. That concern reportedly spurred Kohl to quicken the pace of unification, before a power struggle in the Kremlin could send things back to square one. Gorbachev's change of mind on Germany was an abrupt switch for the Soviet people, who for years cited their 20 million dead in World War II as the grounds for their suspicion - and often hatred - of the Germans. Previous Soviet leaders exercised their dominance over East Germany's then-Communist regime to block any talk of unification. During a formal state ceremony on Wednesday, German President Richard von Weizsaecker also paid tribute to Gorbachev. ``Many people, among them we Germans, have reason to be thankful,'' von Weizsaecker told the several hundred guests. The German lawmakers from East and West gave Berlin Mayor Walter Momper a long round of applause at the same ceremony, after he singled out Gorbachev for praise. Gorbachev visited then-West Germany in June 1989, receiving a hero's welcome as people cheered and basked in what became known as ``Gorbymania.'' Gone were the chilly meetings of West Germans and Soviets, with the new-style Kremlin leader winning friends wherever he went. Even then, few could guess that just four months later, Gorbachev would make another German visit with even more important consquences. In early October, Gorbachev came to Berlin and bluntly told then-Communist boss Erich Honecker to get on with a reform policy. ``Life punishes whoever comes late,'' Gorbachev told the 77-year-old Honecker, using a Russian proverb that most Germans have since memorized. The message was clear: the Soviets would no longer support the fossilized East Berlin regime that was then shaken by an exodus of thousands of refugees. Less than two weeks later, on Oct. 18, Honecker was ousted in a move that led to the breathtaking pace of unification. As the lights went out on the sovereign East Germany and the mighty new country took center stage, outgoing Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere thanked Gorbachev as well. De Maiziere said Gorbachev cleared the way for East Germany's peaceful revolution by refusing to prop up ``an anti-reform system with the force of weapons.'' That revolution in turn led to unification.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Puts Popularity On The Line With Budget Package
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: ``Blame me,'' President Bush invites nervous Republicans as he searches for votes to pass an unpopular package of tax increases and spending cuts. The budget deal may be painful now but the alternative probably is a deep recession that could doom Bush's re-election hopes in 1992. Bush has put his popularity squarely on the line for an agreement that has sent election-minded congressmen diving into foxholes. The deal will hurt everyone, with higher taxes on gasoline, cigarettes, liquor and wine and increased health care costs for the elderly in Medicare. ``It's like drinking a gallon of castor oil,'' said Sen. John Warner, R-Va., ``but we're going to do it.'' Maybe so, but Republicans lawmakers - led by House Whip Newt Gingrich and other members of the GOP leadership - have deserted their president in droves. They are particularly angry over Bush's reversal on his no-new-taxes pledge, robbing Republicans of the same popular campaign cry that propelled Bush into the White House. To win back the dissidents, Bush made a televised speech to the nation asking Americans to take some bitter medicine to restore the health of America's economy. He warned that if the agreement does not pass, ``our economy will falter, markets may tumble and recession will follow.'' Presidential warnings of a dire economic future are only part of a strategy that also includes arm-twisting sessions with Republicans at the White House and private appeals in telephone calls. Bush's high-profile stand is intended to give politicians a ready excuse for digging deeper into taxpayers' pockets. ``Say the president encouraged you to do it,'' Bush said. ``Blame me, because I know what's best for our country. But I don't suspect it's politically popular.'' While all 435 House seats are up for grabs, Bush is not running for re-election this year. His political life is not on the line, so it's probably better for Bush to take his licks now. ``They've analyzed the economic situation and realize it's only going to get worse,'' said University of Virginia political scientist Larry Sabato. ``It's better to make a corrective move now than closer to his re-election year,'' Sabato said. ``It's better (for Bush) to have a recession now than in 1991 or 1992.'' With his high popularity ratings, Bush can afford to take a hit. His ratings have been bumping along as high as 80 percent, buoyed by approval of his handling of the Persian Gulf crisis. ``The Persian Gulf gives him some shield, some protection,'' Sabato said. ``Presidential popularity becomes impervious to damage in foreign crises.'' Bush insists he is not making his decisions on the basis of the election calendar. ``It's, I guess, about as complicated as a period as we've had since I've been president,'' Bush said, referring to the twin problems of the budget and the gulf. ``But I'm not looking at it in terms of re-election. ... The American people are entitled to something a little bit more broader-gauged than that.'' Both sides in the budget battle are playing the underdog. For the White House, that would make a victory seem to be an even bigger triumph. From Bush's opponents, it is a message that Bush doesn't need every GOP vote. Curiously, Bush is not demanding complete Republican loyalty on what he says is a vote to avoid economic catastrophe. There is no threat of White House retaliation, no warning of political punishment. Bush even holds open the possibility that he could make a campaign appearance for someone who votes against the budget agreement. ``I can't bring myself to be recriminatory,'' the president said. ``I wish all of them (Republicans) would support me strongly and lay aside some of the passions that one of the other of them have on a specific issue,'' Bush said. ``That probably isn't going to happen, if I believe what I'm hearing on the television. ``So now what I've got to do is get 50.1 percent, and then we're home.'' Sabato, the political scientist, says that in withholding threats against rebellious Republicans, Bush is simply making a virtue out of necessity. ``Bush is not dumb enough to go up against the anti-tax wing of the Republican Party too hard,'' Sabato said. ``That's probably half his party.'' ---
DOC.HEAD: Editors Note: Terence Hunt has covered the presidency since
DOC.TEXT: 1981 and is the AP's chief White House correspondent.

DOC.HEAD: Former Met Star Dies
DOC.TEXT: Eleanor Steber, who began singing solos as a child in West Virginia and went on to become a prima donna at the Metropolitan Opera, died Wednesday. Miss Steber died of congestive heart failure at the Attleboro Nursing Home in Langhorne, Pa., according to Martha Moore Smith, her personal representative. Her age, widely misreported throughout her career, was 76, said publicist Randall Fostvedt. Miss Steber became a soloist at age 5, in a Wheeling church - but forgot the words to the song. The soprano was confident by the time she debuted at the Met in 1940 as Sophie in ``Der Rosenkavalier.'' ``Thank heaven, all thought of its being my debut left my mind entirely and I was caught up in the swell of the music,'' she later recalled. As her voice matured, she undertook heavier roles such as Donna Anna in ``Don Giovanni.'' In all, she sang 404 Met performances in 33 roles - French, Italian and German - through 1966. But she was known especially as a Mozart interpreter, portraying such heroines as the Countess, Fiordiligi, Pamina, Donna Elvira and Constanze, the latter at the Metropolitan premiere of ``The Abduction from the Seraglio,'' in 1946. ``Mozart led to everything else,'' she said in a 1987 interview. ``It naturally led to Strauss. You learn how to sing through singing Mozart and you can then do Bellini, Donizetti. Mozart was a purist.'' She appeared throughout the world: in recitals and musical comedies; as featured soloist on television's ``Voice of Firestone.'' Her 1940s weekly radio hour blended classical and pop. Sir Rudolf Bing, then Met general manger dismissed her without explanation in 1963, three years after a New York Times article proclaimed her ``indispensible'' to the opera company. She returned, at the Met's behest, in 1966 to sing Minnie in ``Girl of the Golden West.'' She headed the voice department at the Cleveland Institute of Music from 1963 to 1973, then taught at the Juilliard School of Music. In 1975, she established the Eleanor Steber Music Foundation to help the careers of young singers. ``I'm offered old-lady parts in musicals,'' she complained in 1980. ``Why don't they write a show about Tugboat Annie and ask me to do it?'' Plans for a memorial service were incomplete Wednesday. Survivors include a sister, Lucille Leslie of Newtown, Pa., and a brother, William C. Steber of State College, Pa. Her two marriages ended in divorce.

DOC.HEAD: Worldwide Welcome for United Germany
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: World leaders warmly welcomed a united Germany into the international community Wednesday, but echoes of past wars and concerns about the balance of power tempered some European enthusiasm. ``A new era is beginning for Germany, for Europe and indeed, we hope, for the world,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III declared in New York. President Bush proclaimed German-American Day in the United States. In Moscow, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev paid tribute to the ``peaceful and worthy solution of the `German issue.''' He cited ``all those in my country and in your country who, overcoming sorrows, remembering losses and honoring the dead, did not yield to prejudice and fears.'' The unification ``symbolizes Europe's historic turning point in the direction of establishing a new order,'' said Toshiki Kaifu, prime minister of Japan. The Japanese newspaper Asahi Shimbun said: ``Very few Europeans seriously suspect a danger of Germany once again provoking war.'' It noted ``the keen awareness the Germans have exhibited of their war responsibility and by their peaceful behavior ... over nearly half a century.'' West Germany's emergence as an economic power and the potential strength of a united Germany unsettle some Europeans, including Britain's Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. ``Germany will be very dominant in Europe, so it will be up to the rest of us not to allow it to dominate. Others of us have powerful voices,'' she said in a British television interview this week. But in a message to German Prime Minister Helmut Kohl, she told the German people: ``We face the future as friends, allies and partners.'' For Germany's neighbors to the north, ``This is the first time in centuries that Denmark can view the coming togetherof a stronger German state with calm and sympathy,'' said the conservative Copenhagen daily newspaper Berlingske Tidende. ``The re-establishment of German unity takes place with the full understanding of all the country's neighbors,'' the newspaper said. ``It is in Germany's own interest as well as a common hope that it succeeds.'' Commentators in Poland counseled Poles to view German unification with joy instead of distrust, but not to drop their guard. ``We do not turn a blind eye to the past,'' Ernest Skalski wrote in Poland's largest newspaper, Gazeta Wyborcza. ``We do not ignore troubles resulting from this difficult proximity, but we count on a better future and we wish it to our neighbors,'' he said. In Warsaw, President Wojciech Jaruzelski said in a message to German President Richard von Weizsaecker: ``I trust that Germany's unification will be one of the most important signs of a new era in the history of our continent, free of burdens that caused misfortunes and tragedies in the past.'' In Israel, senior German diplomat Heimo Richter laid a wreath at the Yad Vashem memorial to 6 million Jews slain in the Nazi Holocaust and gave Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir a letter restating German friendship. Shamir said he was disappointed it made no reference to the Holocaust. French President Francois Mitterrand, also concerned about German dominance, told Kohl: ``We have come a long way together. We are going to continue ... Tell those close to you, tell all Germans of the solidarity of France.'' The French leftist daily Liberation, said: ``Germany united is the victory of European reason.'' But it warned: ``On Oct. 3, 1990, forgetting is forbidden: forgetting the distant past as well as the recent. Neither the memory of Auschwitz nor that of democratic and peaceful unification should be hidden away.'' Romanian President Ion Iliescu told Germany, ``I am convinced that unification will give a great impulse to the traditional ties between Romania and Germany.''

DOC.HEAD: NRC Names Task Force To Review Plant's Evacuation Plans
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission named a task force Wednesday to review emergency evacuation plans at the Pilgrim nuclear power plant in Plymouth, Mass. The task force would be charged with determining ``whether the NRC should reconsider its finding that there is reasonable assurance that adequate measures can and will be taken in the event of a radiological emergency at Pilgrim,'' according to an NRC release. The NRC move follows a report issued in July by the commission's inspector general that criticized the way the agency staff handled emergency preparedness planning two years ago when the plant was being readied for restart. James M. Taylor, the NRC's executive director for operations, said the decision to assign a task force to examine Pilgrim's emergency planning comes in response to ``the many critical comments'' made at a public meeting last month in Plymouth, according to the NRC release. The announcement also comes a day after Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., announced that a House investigatory panel would hold a hearing in Plymouth on Oct. 22 on the NRC's handling of emergency preparedness issues. In his July report, NRC Inspector General David C. Williams said commission staffers gave the NRC false information by declaring that residents near the Pilgrim plant could be protected in an emergency. The scathing 15-page report concluded that the commission staff said Pilgrim was safe to operate without looking in detail at evacuation plans. The report accused staffers of relying on unconfirmed information provided by the plant's owner, Boston Edison Co. The misleading statements were made in October and December 1988 just before the NRC approved the reopening of the Pilgrim plant. The plant had been shut down since April 1986 due to chronic management and mechanical problems. Following the inspector general's report, Edison officials insisted that residents around Pilgrim would have adequate protection in an emergency based on current plans.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Frenchmen Held Hostage in Iraq Arrive in Amman
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nine Frenchmen held hostage in Iraq were released in Baghdad on Wednesday and arrived in Jordan with the private French group that secured their release. French President Francois Mitterrand, meanwhile, arrived in Abu Dhabi, the first stop on his two-day Persian Gulf visit to meet regional leaders and inspect France's troops. His arrival came just hours after the nine former hostages arrived in Amman aboard a regularly scheduled Iraqi Airways flight. ``I am very happy that I have been released but a lot of people remain in Iraq and Kuwait,'' said Jean-Yves Bobin, who had been detained in Kuwait. ``We hope they can be freed soon and that all things will develop toward a peaceful solution.'' The nine, who received their exit visas from Iraq on Tuesday, were to return to France later Wednesday, French Foreign Ministry officials at Amman's airport said. Iraq agreed to release the hostages during a visit by a five-member French delegation headed by Gilles Munier, who heads the private Association for French-Iraqi Friendship. He called the hostages' release a ``generous gesture'' by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and appealed for a softening of France's hard-line policy toward Baghdad since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Munier is a member of the National Front, the ultraconservative French political Party headed by Jean-Marie Le Pen. Diplomatic sources in Baghdad said Le Pen himself might visit Iraq to seek the release of more Frenchmen. About 300 French nationals are among the thousands of Westerners being held in Iraq and Kuwait to deter any attack by the U.S.-led military forces in the Persian Gulf region. The release came just two days after Iraq said it was willing to hold contacts with the French government in an attempt to resolve the crisis peacefully. Mitterrand suggested last week at the United Nations that the resolution of the gulf crisis might be followed by initiatives to solve the problems of Lebanon and the Palestinians. But Mitterrand has reiterated the West's insistence that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait and free all hostages before negotiations take place. Mitterrand's visit to the Middle East was the first by a Western leader with forces stationed in the region to protect Saudi Arabia and other gulf states from Iraq. After meeting leaders and reviewing French troops in Abu Dhabi, he was to visit Saudi Arabia for talks with King Fahd and possibly visit ground troops deployed at a forward staging area in the kingdom. France is beefing up its ground forces to 4,000 men in Abu Dhabi and Saudi Arabia, including a regiment of Foreign Legionnaires. France now has 13,000 men plus a dozen warships in the region or on their way, the largest overseas deployment of French troops since the Algerian war. Mitterrand said Sept. 6 that he intended to visit the gulf. It was the same day he announced a major increase in French forces in the region in response to a raid by Iraqi troops on the French ambassador's residence in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Says Case Remains a `Massive Whodunit'
DOC.TEXT: The case of five slain college students remains ``a massive whodunit'' that may not be solved any time soon, the area's chief state prosecutor says. About 150 members of a joint task force are still at work, trying to learn who was responsible for the late August killings, in which one victim was decapitated, State Attorney Len Register told The Gainesville Sun for an article published Wednesday. ``It might take a lot longer than we hoped,'' Register said. He said the case is still wide open and the suspect list remains fluid. ``Occasionally we'll pick up some suspects and we've been able to eliminate other suspects,'' Register said, without naming any either way. ``A fair inference is that this is still a massive whodunit. This is not to say that we're not making progress,'' he said. The task force is following up about 5,000 tips logged in since the murders, he said. Register revealed few details. Task-force members say they don't want to release information that might be needed for a successful prosecution. Register also refused to talk about laboratory tests. He said 700 items from crime scenes and searches are being analyzed by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement. Sources told The Sun last week that lab tests failed to place suspect Edward Lewis Humphrey at the three crime scenes and pointed to someone else. Humphrey, jailed in lieu of $1 million bail on a charge he beat his grandmother, goes on trial Monday in Melbourne on that charge. Register said investigators have not ruled out the possibility that more than one person committed the crimes, but he seemed to put no emphasis on that theory. ``I think it would be irresponsible if we close out any scenario,'' he said. Increased police patrols will continue and Gainesville residents should maintain safety measures, he said. ``College is a carefree time in your life, and under these circumstances, that makes it a dangerous situation,'' Register said. The bodies of the five college students were found in their off-campus apartments Aug. 26-28.

DOC.HEAD: Many Calls to Hill Oppose Budget Accord
With AM-Budget, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bssh's televised suggestion that citizens call their congressional representatives to support the tentative budget agreement caused phones to ring all over Capitol Hill on Wednesday. Many calls, however, were from people opposed to the plan. A staff member who answered the telephone in the Washington office of Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., started laughing when asked if the office was getting a lot of calls. Gingrich, No. 2 Republican in the House, was on the budget negotiating team but opposed the agreement and refused to participate with the president in announcing the settlement. ``At 10 o'clock this morning in our Morrow, Ga., office we had 143 calls against it and 20 for it. And we'd only been open since nine,'' said the Gingrich aide. She said the Washington office had had 91 calls against the budget and 22 for it by the same time. Rep. Pete Geren, D-Texas, said constituents were ``all calling their congressmen a whole lot more than yesterday - but they're all calling to say, `Vote against it.''' In House Speaker Tom Foley's office, the phone was ringing non-stop. One visitor said he overheard an exasperated receptionist say ``Well, you'll have to vote against the president too, then!'' before hanging up. A spokesman for Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee, said calls to his office were evenly mixed. Calls to the office of the House Ways and Means Committee chairman, Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, also were running even. An aide to the Illinois Democrat said most of the calls were coming from individuals and not representatives of special-interest groups, and from all over the country, not just Rostenkowski's district.

DOC.HEAD: Group Carries on Campaign After Candidate's Death
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a committee trying to get a deceased judge elected says that ``in this case, the dead man is a better candidate.'' Sam Fouquet of Guymon is heading the Texas County committee trying to make sure that the late Judge Frank Ogden is the winning candidate on Nov. 6. ``We feel like the man running against Judge Ogden isn't of the caliber we'd like to have serving this particular area,'' Fouquet said. Ogden and Josh J. Evans are on the general election ballot for the district judgeship for Beaver, Cimarron, Harper and Texas counties. Ogden died in August after he had filed for re-election. Should Ogden be elected, a vacancy would be declared and the state Judicial Nominating Commission would advertise for applicants. Three names would be submitted to the governor, who would then appoint a new judge to serve Ogden's term. Evans has called efforts to get people to vote for Ogden ridiculous.
DOC.HEAD: Candidate: Woman Seeking Multiple Abortions Should Face Public Degredation
DOC.TEXT: A Republican candidate for the state House says women who seek multiple abortions should have to justify their plans before a panel and should be publicly humiliated in newspapers. ``If you had five abortions, then we will do something to make sure everyone in the world knows you've had five abortions,'' said Robert Bechta, a candidate for the House who runs a home security business in Stafford. Under Bechta's plan, women who exceed a certain number of abortions would have to explain their actions before a medical panel. Such cases would also be publicized in newspapers, even if the state had to pay for the space, Bechta said. ``Public degradation, I think, would probably be the best way'' of deterring people from having multiple abortions, he said. Bechta's opponent, Democratic incumbent John D. Mordasky, opposes all abortions, except in cases of rape, incest or risk to the mother's life. Abortion rights activists were angered by Bechta's proposals. ``Of all the anti-abortion tactics we've heard about in the last five years, this one takes the cake for being the most outrageous and is almost comical if it weren't so serious,'' said Alice Kirkman, a spokeswoman for the National Abortion Federation in Washington, D.C. ``It sounds like the Romanian truth squads,'' she said.
DOC.HEAD: Richards, Williams Trade Jabs Over Blind Trust
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial candidate Ann Richards criticized Republican Clayton Williams' offer to place his holdings in a blind trust if elected governor. ``His sudden interest in distancing himself from his personal businesses is nothing more than a cynical gesture to divert attention from the very serious charges of insurance fraud that have been made against his bank,'' said Mary Beth Rogers, Richards' campaign manager. The Williams campaign called Richards' criticism ``rank hypocrisy.'' Williams spokesman Gordon Hensley said Richards' supporters urged Williams to place his $100 million business empire into a blind trust and then when he agreed they criticized him. Several state agencies are scrutinizing Williams' ClayDesta National Bank of Midland for allegedly requiring customers to buy expensive credit life insurance to get car loans. Williams has dismissed the probes as politically motivated. Williams defended his proposed blind trust. Under a blind trust, officials give up control and knowledge of their businesses to separate their private and public affairs.
DOC.HEAD: Annunzio Sought Home Loan Bank Board Job for Son-in-Law
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Frank Annunzio has acknowledged he once tried to get a son-in-law a position with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, a published report says. Annunzio of Illinois is the second-ranking Democrat on the House Banking Committee and chairman of its financial institutions subcommittee. He wrote to Richard T. Pratt, chairman of the bank board, in 1983 seeking a position for his son-in-law, Kevin Tynan, the Chicago Sun-Times reported in Wednesday's editions. Tynan did not get a job. The letter, written on Annunzio's congressional stationery, was obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request filed by the Sun-Times. Annunzio told the newspaper he sought a non-paying position on the federal home loan advisory council for Tynan. ``I did no more for Kevin than I do for dozens of other constituents a month,'' Annunzio said. The letter said, ``I would also like to point out that if a position is available that pays some remuneration for his services, it would be most appreciated. I shall be grateful for any consideration extended to Kevin.'' The remuneration he wrote of referred to possible expenses, Annunzio told the Sun-Times. Tynan is now Annunzio's campaign manager.

DOC.HEAD: Ava Gardner Book: George C. Scott `Beat Me'
DOC.TEXT: The late actress Ava Gardner says in her autobiography that former lover George C. Scott drunkenly beat her and she aborted two babies fathered by husband Frank Sinatra. Miss Gardner, who died from pneumonia early this year in London, makes the revelations in ``Ava: My Story,'' which arrives in bookstores this week. Her films include ``The Killers,'' ``Whistle Stop,'' ``One Touch of Venus,'' ``Show Boat'' and ``On the Beach.'' She met Scott in 1964 on the set of ``The Bible.'' ``The trouble that Abraham and Sarah were having on the biblical front was nothing compared to the storm between George and me that was about to break behind the scenes. ... When George got drunk he could go berserk in a way that was quite terrifying,'' she wrote in the Bantam book. In one fight between the two at the Beverly Hills Hotel, she said Scott smashed bottles to make weapons. ``He was kneeling across me, waving the jagged edges of glass in front of my face with one hand and hitting me with the other. Telling me he loved me, and smashing a fist into my eye. `Marry me, do you hear what I'm saying?' followed by another blow.'' She concluded her reflections on Scott by saying: ``Even today, if I so much as see him on television, I start to shake all over again and have to turn the set off.'' A spokesman for Scott, Sean Mahoney, said, ``Mr. Scott has not had an opportunity to read the book and thereby has no comment on its contents.'' Miss Gardner wrote that during her marriage to Sinatra, her third husband, she discovered she was pregnant while making John Ford's 1953 release ``Mogambo.'' She chose to have an abortion. ``MGM had all sorts of penalty clauses about their stars having babies,'' she wrote. ``If I had one, my salary would be cut off. So how could I make a living? Frank was absolutely broke and would probably continue to be (or so I thought) for a long time.'' She said Ford tried to talk her out of the abortion. ```Ava,' he said, `you're married to a Catholic, and this is going to hurt Frank tremendously when he finds out about it.' '' She proceeded with the abortion without Sinatra's knowledge. He was aware of a second abortion performed a few months later, the book said. Other husbands were Artie Shaw and Mickey Rooney. She described Rooney as a womanizer, but also ``charming, romantic and great fun'' in the early stages of their relationship. A prominently mentioned male friend in the book is the late tycoon Howard Hughes. The book is the result of 90 tapes recorded by Miss Gardner over a two-year period. She completed the last tape a few months before dying in January.

DOC.HEAD: Historical Society Looking for a Few Good Scarecrows
DOC.TEXT: Bridgewater wants to scare away its birds, just for old times' sake. The Bridgewater Historical Society is starting a scarecrow contest it plans to hold annually, and entrants can let their imaginations run wild, said an organizer, Pat Schramm. The scarecrows can be the old-fashioned kind, stuffed with hay, propped up with a rake and topped off with a wide-brimmed hat, or the high-tech versions, made with wire framing and stuffed with nylon pantyhose. The contest is aimed at reviving a piece of history and may even have some educational value for the town's younger residents, Schramm said. ``A lot of younger children have never even seen a scarecrow,'' Schramm said. Mary Allen, president of the historical society, said when she was growing up in Bridgewater in the 1920s the scarecrow was a common sight, put out by farmers to keep birds away from seeds and crops. A rag often was draped around the scarecrow and tied in the middle, leaving some of it hanging in the wind. The flapping made it look just human enough to frighten away the birds, she said. The contest is open to the town's 1,600 residents, who have until Oct. 24 to display their scarecrows. Prizes will be given for various categories, including the funniest and the scariest scarecrows.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Make New Soybean Meal Purchase
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union bought an additional 150,000 metric tons of U.S. soybean meal under a long-term grain agreement between the two countries, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. Officials said private exporters sold the meal for delivery through Dec. 31. The current agreement, including a three-month extension, will expire at that time and a new five-year pact will take over. The new sales were made by unidentified private exporting companies, which are required to report large sales to the department. No selling prices or further details were released. Meal prices at Midwest processors have been around $180 per ton of 2,000 pounds each, according to USDA market reports. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds, indicating a value of about $198 per metric ton, or a total estimate of around $27 million. Reports that the Soviet Union was in the market for meal helped boost soybean futures Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Under the current grain agreement, the Soviet Union bought more than 1.37 million tons of soybean meal during the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, along with 342,000 tons of soybeans. Grain purchases during the year totaled 20.3 million tons, including almost 16.5 million tons of corn and 3.8 million tons of wheat.

DOC.HEAD: Runoff Required in Anchorage Mayoral Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: In 6th graf, Anchorage mayoral candidate is cq as former Fairbanks mayor.
DOC.TEXT: Voters in Alaska's largest city split among three candidates for mayor, forcing a runoff this month between two top finishers. In two other localities, voters rejected prohibition of alcohol for personal use. Bethel voters, facing the southwest Alaska region's sixth election related to alcohol use or sale in two years, rejected a ban on alcohol possession by a vote of 541-318. In Barrow, the northernmost community in the state, the prohibition was defeated 55-45. In both Barrow and Bethel, sale of liquor in restaurants, stores and bars already is illegal, as it is in much of rural Alaska. The repeated attempts at alcohol bans are promoted by Eskimo elders weary of suicides and injuries related to rural drunkenness. With all 91 precincts reporting, incumbent Anchorage Mayor Tom Fink and advertising executive Rick Mystrom had 38.6 percent and 38.4 percent of the vote, respectively. Since neither got 40 percent, they must face each other in a runoff election Oct. 30. Red Boucher, a former Fairbanks mayor, lieutenant governor and state legislator, got 21.5 percent of the votes in the Anchorage mayoral race. Fairbanks elected a new mayor Tuesday: Wayne Nelson, manager of a downtown office and apartment building. Nelson got 2,492 votes to city councilman Lowell Purcell's 1,516 votes. In Juneau, a 6 percent wholesale tax on tobacco products was overwhelmingly approved by a final unofficial vote of 4,511 to 2,537. The tax, opposed by the tobacco industry, will add 3 to 4 cents to the price of a pack of cigarettes and raise an expected $36,000 a year.

DOC.HEAD: Metro Manager Moves to Smithsonian
DOC.TEXT: Carmen E. Turner, general manager of the Metro transit system in Washington for seven years, was named Wednesday to the No. 2 post at the Smithsonian Institution. Mrs. Turner, 60, will oversee the day-to-day operations of the world's largest museum and research complex, which includes 15 museums in Washington and New York as well as the National Zoo. The appointment will be effective in mid-December. Her salary was not disclosed. Secretary of the Smithsonian Robert McC. Adams praised Mrs. Turner as an excellent administrator who will take a ``team approach'' in coping with the Smithsonian's looming financial crunch and internal management reforms. Mrs. Turner, who began her career as a government clerk-typist, was named chief administrator of the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority in 1983. Her annual salary is $109,000. Metro is the nation's second-largest subway system and fourth largest bus transit system, with a $615 million annual operating budget and 9,000 employees. The Smithsonian has 6,600 employees and a budget of more than $500 million. She succeeds Smithsonian Undersecretary Dean Anderson, who resigned in July over what Adams called ``differences in approach.''

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Leader Warns Against Enforcing Air Embargo on Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian guerrilla leader on Wednesday warned of retaliation against U.S. targets if Iraqi planes were hit with weapons under the U.N. air embargo against Iraq. In a statement published by Baghdad's official al-Jumhuriya daily, Abul Abbas called the air embargo ``the operation of air piracy by one state against another to serve its narrow-minded interests.'' The comments heightened fears that guerrilla factions linked to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein would unleash a new terrorist campaign against the United States and its allies confronting Iraq in the Persian Gulf. Abul Abbas called the air embargo an ``American decision dictated to the international community.'' The embargo is aimed at tightening the economic squeeze on Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, which Baghdad invaded Aug. 2. ``We will not permit such legislation to be implemented against our people and if any Iraqi aircraft is confronted by such air piracy and should any damage be inflicted on Iraq's civil aviation, we will retaliate,'' he said. He said the U.N. Security Council resolution was ``terroristic legislation which does not serve world peace.'' Abul Abbas, who heads the extremist Palestine Liberation Front now based in Baghdad, did not specify what action would be taken. But he appeared to be talking about hijacking or bombing U.S. airliners, since his warning concerned Iraqi aircraft. Abbas, whose real name is Mohammed Abbas, is one of several radical Palestinian leaders now based in Iraq. Some have specialized in attacks on airliners and airports. Among them are George Habash, leader of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, Nayef Hawatmeh of the Marxist Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, and a group led by Hussein Mohammed Umari, whose nom de guerre is Abu Ibrahim. Abu Nidal's Fatah-Revolutionary Council group is also reported to have moved back to Iraq after a vicious internal feud in which hundreds of his men were killed. Abu Nidal, until recently reported to be in Libya, tops the world's most-wanted list. He has been blamed for scores of terrorist atrocities in recent years, including the December 1985 attacks on Rome and Vienna airports in which more than 20 people were killed. The Popular Front was one of the first to begin hijacking ariliners, in 1970. The group, the second largest faction in the Palestine Liberation Organization, has about 1,000 fighters. The U.S. State Department Saturday warned Americans traveling abroad that they run the risk of Iraqi-sponsored attacks. National security adviser Brent Scowcroft said in Washington Friday that Saddam was ``actively discussing things'' with terrorist leaders in Baghdad. A NATO official said in Brussels last week that Saddam has provided the groups ``with the wherewithal to conduct'' terrorist operations.

DOC.HEAD: Motorcycle Deaths Continue To Decline
DOC.TEXT: Fatal motorcycle accidents have dropped 31 percent since 1985 and 14 percent in the last year alone, a trend due in part to the greater use of safety helmets, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said Wednesday. Other factors include a 19 percent reduction in motorcycle registrations over the last five years and greater emphasis on rider training, the agency said. But Jerry Ralph Curry, the agency's administrator, said the improved figures represent ``progress, not success.'' ``Half of motorcycle rider deaths involve alcohol, a proportion that hasn't changed at all,'' He said. And he said more than 40 percent of the fatalities involve unlicensed or improperly licensed riders. ``We still have a lot of work to do,'' Curry said. Motorcycle rider deaths numbered 4,564 in 1985, dropped to 3,661 in 1988 and declined again to 3,143 in 1989, the safety agency said. It said that nationwide, motorcycle registrations totaled 5,215,941 but had dropped to 4,218,985 by last year.

DOC.HEAD: German-Americans Celebrate, Worry Over Unification
With AM-Germany Bjt
DOC.TEXT: German-Americans applauded their homeland's unification Wednesday but warned it will take long and hard work to improve the economy of the former East Germany. Veterans who had to fight a unified Germany said it was time to forgive - but not forget. An ABC News poll found that 80 percent of 1,002 Americans in a random telephone survey support unification and 79 percent see no threat. Among Americans older than 65, those of fighting age in World War II, eight in 10 approved of a united Germany. People who faced the Nazi Holocaust had a different view. Joel Rubin, who fled the Nazis when he was 12, was the only one of 97 people in his extended family to escape the Nazis during World War II. ``I don't trust them. I cannot trust the Germans,'' he said in Miami Beach, Fla. Others were cheerier. ``I wish I could be there to help celebrate. I'm happy for Germany and for all the people,'' said Lena Bremer, 61, of Freistatt, Mo., who spent her first 20 years in East Germany. The East Germans envy the higher standard of living the West Germans have enjoyed for years, Bremer said. ``I think there will be some jealousy involved,'' she said. ``They (East Germans) think that they were cheated for so many years.'' Patricia Feltes, a Southwest Missouri State University assistant professor of management, said Germans she has talked to favored reunification but know there will be a price to pay for it. ``There's a view by West Germans that East Germans are second-class citizens,'' Feltes said. ``It's wonderful but it will take a long time to accomplish and maybe only the next generation will realize the benefits from this change,'' said Maria Grewe of Gering, Neb. She grew up outside Munich, Germany. ``It's very rewarding,'' said Donald Tillman, president of the German Society of Maryland, whose father and uncles came from Dusseldorf. ``We kind of won the Cold War without shots being fired.'' Men who fought in World War II in Europe have a different viewpoint. ``They have a right to live,'' said John Loughlin, 69, who spent more than a year and nine months in a German prisoner-of-war camp, where he got regular beatings. ``Why hold a grudge?'' Loughlin, who lives at the Rhode Island Veterans Home at Bristol, R.I., said Tuesday. ``You've got to forgive.'' ``Forgive but don't forget,'' said Daniel Sullivan, 80, who served in England and Germany in World War II. ``You might be walking away and get hit on the back of the head.'' Germany's wounds must be healed, said Rhode Islander Beatrice O'Donnell, 81, who was a nurse with the rank of captain at a military hospital in England during World War II. ``The less division we have, the better off we are,'' she said. ``It caused a lot of animosity with that (Berlin) wall up. The hard feelings were magnified by it many times.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress Gives Final Approval to Bill Outlawing Age Discrimination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs `The Supreme ...' to ADD dropped word `not.'
DOC.TEXT: The House gave final congressional passage Wednesday to legislation aimed at reversing the effects of a Supreme Court decision that allowed employers to limit job benefits for older workers. The House voted 406-17 to approve the same version of legislation passed by the Senate on Sept. 24. ``This is a great victory for older workers,'' said Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, chief sponsor of the Senate version, after the House completed action on the bill, which now goes to the White House. The Supreme Court held in a 1989 ruling that employee benefits were not afforded protection under the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967. The measure puts Congress on record as taking the position that the high court's decision went against lawmakers' intent when they passed the landmark age discrimination bill 23 years ago. Several lawmakers had been seeking to reverse the effects of the court ruling more than two years ago in a case pitting June Betts of Cincinnati against the Employees Retirement System of Ohio. At 61, Ms. Betts, a speech pathologist in Hamilton County, Ohio, was disabled with Alzheimer's disease. She was denied disability retirement because she was over 60. The ruling denied her an additional $200 a month.

DOC.HEAD: New Season Only 2 Weeks Old, But New Shows Fading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, ``Fresh Prince ...'' to CORRECT that ``Married People'' tied ``Uncle Buck'' for 37th place.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-New Shows-List
DOC.TEXT: Cancellation notices haven't gone out yet, but NBC's ``Ferris Bueller'' and CBS' ``E.A.R.T.H. Force'' are on the hit list, and ABC's ``Cop Rock'' has been pencilled in, an analyst said Wednesday. Of the new series aired so far in the new season, NBC's ``Fresh Prince of Bel Air'' has the most promise, said Richard Kostrya, a senior vice president of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency. ``It wouldn't want to call it a hit, but it's the strongest of the new entries,'' he said in an interview. The fall season is just 2 weeks old and it will take a few weeks more to see how viewing patterns evolve, he said. The A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings for last week declared ABC's ``America's Funniest People'' the highest-rated new show. It finished at 13th in the weekly rankings. The rest ranged from middle-level to the Nielsen cellar. ``Fresh Prince'' finished in 26th place. It was followed by CBS' ``Uncle Buck'' and ABC's ``Married People,'' which tied for 37th place. CBS' ``The Trials of Rosie O'Neill,'' which placed 40th, is losing its Monday audience lead-in from ``Designing Women'' and may have to be transferred, said Kostrya. The new and old lineup of the Fox network ``is very, very disappointing,'' he said. The new includes shows on the bottom of the ratings rung - Fox's ``D.E.A.,'' ``Haywire,'' the Mark Frost-David Lynch effort, ``American Chronicles,'' and ``Glory Days.'' Based on his analysis of viewing trends so far, he said likely candidates for an early ax by the Big Three networks include NBC's ``Bueller'' and ``Hull High'' and CBS' ``E.A.R.T.H. Force'' and ``Uncle Buck.'' ABC's radical ``Cop Rock,'' which mixes music with drama, was 56th-ranked in ratings in its premiere last week. It's too early to make a call on that showing, Kostrya said, but it appears in trouble because it got a generally older audience than advertisers usually seek. The kind of audience a show gets is a major factor, he added. Although TV writers focus on the number of households tuned to shows each week, he said, advertisers care most about the demographics of the audience watching the programs - viewers' age, sex, incoms, education and so on. The ``key demographic'' is an audience whose members range in age from 18 to 49, he said. Although ABC is third in overall prime time ratings for the young season, he said, ``they clearly are the number one network in the key demographic.''

DOC.HEAD: All New Buses, Vans and Rail Cars Must Be Accessible to Disabled
DOC.TEXT: Transit authorities across the country must now buy only buses, vans and rail cars that are accessible to the disabled, the Department of Transportation said Wednesday. Acting to implement the Americans with Disabilities Act, the department said access for the disabled must be ensured by transit authorities buying or leasing new buses, vans, light rail, rapid rail, commuter rail and intercity rail cars. The requirement is effective immediately, the department said.
