DOC.HEAD: Backhoe Operator Cuts MCI Service to 5 States
DOC.TEXT: A backhoe operator working on the Ohio turnpike severed a cable Wednesday, interrupting MCI Telecommunications long-distance phone service to parts of five states. MCI spokesman Doug Dome said the damaged equipment was a fiber optic cable that carries about 50,000 circuits. He said the cable is one of the major east-west connections and that service was affected in parts of Maryland, Pennsylvania, Indiana, Ohio and Illinois. Dome said that both voice and data circuits were interrupted. Some callers, he said, were redirected to use other long distance services. Spokeswoman Debra Shriver said that area code 216, which includes the Cleveland area, was the most severely affected, but that some service also was lost in York and Pittsburgh, Pa., and in Perryman, Md. Dome said the cable was severed about 9:15 a.m. EDT by a backhoe operator who was working on a bridge on the Ohio turnpike near North Royalton, Ohio. He said that MCI has a major service office nearby and that repair crews were on the scene within 15 minutes. Service was restored circuit by circuit, said Dome, as the fiber optics connections were made in the large cable, and that the cable was ``just about 100 percent restored by 3 p.m.'' AT&T spokesman Jim McGann said some calls were diverted to his company's service, but that the increase in calls was handled with no problems. ``There was no impact on our network at all,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: President Unwinds With Tennis Match
DOC.TEXT: President Bush put down the telephone and picked up a tennis racket Wednesday as he interrupted lobbying for the deficit reduction package to team up with U.S. Open winner Peter Sampras. Bush invited the 19-year-old sensation to the White House court for a doubles match with Rep. Bill Archer, R-Texas, and Matthew Meyer, a friend of Bush's son Marvin. Marvin Bush also played. Bush muttered as he walked on to the court that he was ``glad to be off that telephone.'' He had spent much of the day meeting with congressional Republicans and telephoning them to urge them to pass the $500 billion deficit reduction package. The president played an aggressive net game that helped him and partner Sampras win the first two games - one due to Sampras' deadly serve. But when Bush served the third game, he double faulted and the game was won by opponents. Sampras later told reporters that he and Bush prevailed to win the set. ``I was impressed,'' he said of the president's dogged game. ``The MVP was the president.'' Sampras said he and Bush chatted during the game about the federal budget, the Persian Gulf crisis and tennis. He offered no details, saying he could not remember specifics.

DOC.HEAD: Ghadafy Says Israel Should Be Moved To Europe
DOC.TEXT: The state of Israel should be moved to Europe so that Europeans ``pay the price'' for past anti-Semitic persecution, Libyan leader Col. Moammar Ghadafy said Wednesday. The statement, read to the U.N. General Assembly in Arabic by Libyan Foreign Minister Jadallah Azouz El-Talhy, said the land presently occupied by Israel should become a homeland for Palestinians. ``The establishing of the Jewish state in Palestine was a revenge against Nazism, which tortured the Jews in Europe and the reaction against it,'' according to a translation of the statement. ``However, Nazism came to an end ... If the world is sympathizing with the Jews against their persecutors in the past, Europe is responsible for that and it should pay the price of that by establishing a state for the Jewish people,'' he said. ``The Jewish character of the Jewish state in Palestine should come to an end if the world is serious in establishing peace over the land,'' the statement continued. ``Then this requires the nations of the world to withdraw their recognition of the state, and to make the state of Palestine democratic, without regard to the religion of its inhabitants.''

DOC.HEAD: Klansman-Turned-Senate Candidate Seeks Blacks' Votes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after the 17th, ``Many prominent,'' to update with 8 GOP senators in Washington backing Johnston, from a0673.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Senate candidate David Duke, who once burned crosses to denounce blacks, is now asking for their help, claiming Sen. Bennett Johnston ``has led you down the blind alley of poverty, crime and human misery.'' ``I'm not your enemy,'' the former Ku Klux Klan leader said in a 30-minute television fireside chat broadcast for the first time Tuesday night. ``Your real enemies are liberals like Bennett Johnston who have the assumption blacks can't compete with whites and must be given preferential treatment and must be judged by lower standards. ...'' Johnston said at a news conference Wednesday he didn't want ``to dignify Duke's attack because he's not responsible for what (Duke) says. He just gets up and makes wild charges.'' During the past two weeks, the campaign has been waged almost completely on television. Since the race heated up during the summer, the two candidates have spent almost $2 million, much of it on TV and radio. The primary is Saturday. Under the unique Louisiana system, all candidates run on the same ballot regardless of party. If no one gets more than half the vote, the top two go into a runoff on Nov. 6. Duke, 40, is running as a Republican without the party's endorsement. The big question is whether he will poll enough votes to force Johnston, 58, a Democrat, into a runoff. Three other candidates also remain in the race. The most recent poll, taken by the University of New Orleans about three weeks ago, found that Johnston had slipped from 48 percent to 46 percent, Duke remained at 21 percent, and Ben Bagert, the official GOP nominee, remained far behind at 8 percent. The undecided vote had increased to 20 percent, with the rest refusing to answer questions. Duke, also at a news conference Wednesday, said he expected to get at least 40 percent of the vote and force Johnston into a runoff. Ironically, many of Bagert's fellow Republicans are urging votes for Johnston to keep Duke out of a runoff. Democratic Gov. Buddy Roemer urged voters Tuesday to shun Duke by re-electing Johnston. He said a strong showing by Duke would send the wrong signal to the nation and deter the state's economic development. Johnston, an 18-year incumbent, has spent much of his time recently in Washington for the budget debate. While out of the state, he relied mostly on brief TV spots assailing Duke's past as a klansman, depicting him as a neo-Nazi and outright liar. Some commercials show old film of Duke in his klan robes in front of a burning cross, saluting like a Nazi. Duke, who called the burning cross ad cowardly, used his 30-minute program to apologize for what he calls the stupid mistakes of his youth. On Tuesday, Michael Wahlder, an Alexandria lawyer and a Republican, one of three lesser known candidates, dropped out of the race and urged Bagert to do the same. Two other political unknowns, both Democrats, remain in the race. Many prominent Republicans, especially on the national level, have urged party members to vote for Johnston to avoid a runoff between the incumbent and Duke that would be an embarrassment to the GOP. On Wednesday, eight Republican senators from other states urged re-election of Johnston as a repudiation of what they said was Duke's racism, anti-semitism and hatred. ``All of us would be embarrassed and mortified to have to serve in the United States Senate with David Duke masquerading as a Republican,'' said Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo. Kelly Johnston, deputy political director of the Republican Senate Campaign Committee, said a runoff between Johnston and Duke ``would be the worst possible thing that could happen to us.'' It would allow Democrats across the nation to link any Republican in the November general election to Duke, she said. Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, attended a news conference recently with Johnston, urging Bagert to drop out and throw his support to the Democrat. Bagert, a state legislator since 1968, changed to the GOP after the last election and was urged by the party to run against Johnston. The national GOP drive to support Johnston ``is treachery,'' said Bagert, who was endorsed by President Bush. ``These Georgetown swells with their lunches on pewter plates decided they could sacrifice the Louisiana GOP and renege on their commitment to me.'' In addition to the candidates' ads, the Louisiana Coalition Against Racism and Nazism is running an anti-Duke ad, a parody of the ``Jeopardy'' game show in which questions deal with Duke's past. KTAL-TV in Shreveport stopped running the ad Tuesday after receiving an anonymous bomb threat.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in Idaho; Storms and Floods in Texas
DOC.TEXT: Snow made an appearance in Idaho Wednesday, and floods continued to plague the Rio Grande in Texas. Light snow fell during the morning over the mountains of central Idaho. About an inch of snow accumulated at Dixie and McCall had less than an inch. High winds damaged roofs of some downtown buildings and knocked out power at an elementary school today as severe thunderstorms moved through Cockrell Hill, Texas, just south of Dallas. Several residents reported seeing a tornado, but the National Weather Service and local officials could not confirm the tornado reports. Flood warnings remained in effect along the Rio Grande from Presidio, to near Langtry, Texas. The river was near crest Wednesday morning at Castolon, 4 feet above flood stage. The crest was expected to be 5{ feet higher than flood stage at Presidio on Thursday. By midday, showers and a few thunderstorms extended from south-central Texas across the Southeast into southwest Georgia and Florida. Rain and occasional thunderstorms reached from north-central Texas northward to northern Indiana and western Illinois. Rain also stretched over the Nebraska panhandle, from western Montana into Washington state, and across northwest Oregon with light snow in the higher elevations of Idaho. Heavier rainfall hours included 2.03 inches at Joplin, Mo., 1.45 at Tulsa, Okla., 1.15 at Ottumwa, Iowa, 1.12 at Lamoni, Iowa, and 1.11 at Chanute, Kan. Wednesday morning's low for the Lower 48 states was 23 degrees at Yellowstone, Wyo. Corpus Christi, Texas, hit a record 94 degrees. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 33 and snowing at McCall, Idaho, to 97 degrees at Beeville, Texas.

DOC.BYLINE: Persian Gulf Crisis at a Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:
Saddam Hussein made his first known visit to the oil-rich neighbor he conquered two months ago, meeting Iraqi troops and military commanders in occupied Kuwait on Wednesday. The Iraqi News gency said Saddam toured the streets of Kuwait, which ``appeared flourishing after its return to the mother homeland.'' Kuwait City ``glittered with pride'' at Saddam's visit, said the news agency, monitored in Nicosia. --- Amnesty International issued a report saying that Iraqi troops in Kuwait have tortured and executed scores of people, some for refusing to display pictures of Saddam. The international human rights group said the report was based on information gathered by two representatives who interviewed witnesses and victims in Bahrain. Refugees fleeing Kuwait have said stores and shops have been pillaged, and that Iraq is doing its best to dismantle Kuwaiti institutions. They reported summary executions of resistance fighters. --- A Palestinian guerrilla leader, Abul Abbas, on Wednesday warned of retaliation against U.S. targets if Iraqi planes were hit with weapons under the U.N. air embargo against Iraq. In a statement published by Baghdad's official al-Jumhuriya daily, Abbas called the air embargo ``the operation of air piracy by one state against another to serve its narrow-minded interests.'' --- Yevgeny Primakov, a close adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, visited Amman. He said he had brought a letter for King Hussein that concerns ``efforts to find a settlement for the gulf crisis and other Mideast problems.'' The Soviet delegation was scheduled to fly to Baghdad on Thursday to meet with Iraqi officials. --- Nine Frenchmen held hostage in Iraq were released in Baghdad and arrived in Jordan with the private French group that secured their release. Meanwhile, French president Francois Mitterrand flew to the Persian Gulf for a two-day visit during which he planned to meet regional leaders and inspect French troops. His first stop was the United Arab Emirates' capital of Abu Dhabi. --- On the second day of his weeklong Middle East visit, Japanese Premier Toshiku Kaifu Wednesday said his country would make ``more and stronger efforts'' to find a peaceful way out of the Persian Gulf crisis. On Thursday, he will meet in Amman with Iraq's vice president, Taha Yassin Ramadan. Japan's Foreign Office said the Iraqis requested the meeting with Kaifu and Japan accepted.

DOC.HEAD: Protestors Disrupt Festivities On Unity Day
With AM-Germany
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of leftist radicals marched through central Berlin on Wednesday, throwing stones, smashing windows and pelting police with paint to express their opposition to German unity. More than 20,000 people marched from a square in the western part of the city to a large square in the east side. The theme of the march was that united Germany was experiencing a rise in nationalism and racism. Many of the radicals were demanding that the German state be abolished entirely. The newly combined Berlin police force dispatched hundreds of law enforcement officials to Alexanderplatz, the large square east of the Brandenburg gate that is a favorite place for protests. About 15 to 20 youths broke off from the main group and rampaged through Alexanderplatz. They pummeled passers-by and demolished an outdoor stand selling clothing. Thousands of riot police flanked the protest march and sealed off an adjacent street where a large group was chanting, ``Germany go away,'' ``Germany go to pieces, ``Never again Germany.'' The group was prevented form entering Alexanderplatz where huge festivities were going on to celebrate the unification of the two German states. The protesters, most of them members of West Berlin's radical left-wing scene, rallied into the evening at a large square across the Alexanderplatz. Several protesters scaled flagpoles at the square and removed the newly unfurled West German flags that replaced East Germany's flag, and hoisted the red-and-black flag of the anarchist movement and the former Communist flag of East Germany. Several windows were smashed and police used tear gas against the agitators, who melted away into the crowd of revelers celebrating German unity.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Says There's Little Decline in Industry Pollution
DOC.TEXT: Requirements that industry report toxic chemical releases will force polluters to reduce emissions, but the first two years of data show little decline in pollution, the Environmental Protection Agency said Wednesday. The EPA, in an analysis of the toxic inventory reports for 1987 and 1988, said that while factories reported a 10 percent statistical drop in toxic chemical releases the largest part of the decline was from changes in reporting. For example, some materials that are normally recycled were reported as releases in 1987 but not in 1988. For the facilities reporting the largest decline in pollution between the two years, at least two-thirds of the reduction was ``due to paper changes.'' The EPA said spot checks showed the industry reports were generally accurate, but that thousands of facilities may still not be reporting releases as required by law. The EPA estimated that in 1987 as many as one-third of the companies, or about 10,000, that were required to make reports failed to do so. The chemical industry had the highest reporting record with 88 percent compliance, while the apparel, printing and publishing industries had the lowest compliance record, the agency said. Although the agency does not have compliance data for 1988, EPA and industry officials suggested compliance was likely to be greater because 1987 was the first year the reporting law went into effect and some companies may not have been aware of it. The findings were among an array of conclusions reached by EPA officials in an analysis of two toxic chemical release statistics previously made public. Industry, according to the reports submitted to the EPA and announced in April, released nearly 4.6 billion pounds of toxic chemicals into the air, water and on land in 1988. In 1987, the first year the figures were compiled, the total was nearly 5 billion pounds. Among the other EPA conclusions, some of which had been reported previously, were: -Texas and Louisiana accounted for nearly a fourth of all toxic releases and transfers of toxic materials to disposal sites and 50 facilities accounted for 36 percent of these chemicals. -Cancer-causing chemicals account for about 8 percent of the total. The most frequently released carcinogen - 115 million pounds in 1988 - was dichloromethane, used as an industrial solvent and paint stripper. -Among the 25 chemicals most widely emitted, seven are considered to be ``highly toxic.'' They are ammonia, carbon disulfide, chlorine, zinc, copper, manganese and zinc compounds. -Five percent more facilities submitted toxic release data in 1988 and in 1987, mainly because more plants came under the jurisdiction of the reporting law in 1988. A total of 19,763 indstrial plants submitted reports. The requirement covers plants emitting at least 50,000 pounds of chemicals. EPA Administrator William K. Reilly said he expects that the annual publication of toxic release data will push polluters to reduce toxic chemical releases. The 1989 reports have not been tabulated. ``These data, which are available to any citizen, should be considered to be among the most important weapons in efforts to combat pollution,'' Reilly said. A number of chemical companies, including some of the nation's largest, have said they are pushing for dramatic reductions in toxic releases in the coming years. Clean air legislation nearing completion in Congress also requires such reductions.

DOC.HEAD: Moslems Join Interfaith Organization
DOC.TEXT: Moslems on Wednesday entered into a U.S. interfaith organization for collaboration with Protestants, Roman Catholics and Jews. Rabbi Joseph Glaser, chairman of the board for Religion in American Life, hailed the step as bringing ``our Moslem brothers and sisters'' into cooperative religious work in America. Representing Moslems at the ceremonies were Dawud Assad, president of the Council of Mosques, and Gutbi E. Ahmed, director of the Moslem World League. RIAL coordinates interfaith research and public information activities, including worship directories across the nation, and annual advertising drives encouraging weekly worship and voluntary community service.

DOC.HEAD: More Ethnic Violence in Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: Serbs manning a roadblock wounded two police near Knin, a town in the center of the conflict between Serbs and Croats, Yugoslavia's two largest ethnic groups, Tanjug news agency said Wednesday. Serb leaders are threatening to use force and to ally themselves with Serbs in other republics if Croatia doesn't give in to their demands for full autonomy, developments that could plunge this volatile Balkan nation into a civil war. In Slovenia, to the north, officials said they would ``use all means'' to resist any move by the Yugoslav military to regain command over the region's home guard. Tens of thousands of Slovene reservists were available to prevent any attempt by Yugoslav army units to reassert federal control, Janez Jansa, Slovenia's defense minister, told reporters in the state capital of Ljubljana. The Slovenian legislature voted last week to transfer the state's Territorial Defense militia - up to now under federal command - to local authorities. Yugoslavia's state presidency said Monday it would block Slovenia's move and ordered the federal military to resist any changes in the command structure of Slovenia's home guard. The collective presidency, made up of representatives from each of the country's six republics and two provinces, is the highest body in the land and also is in charge of the armed forces. It demanded on Tuesday that Croatia withdraw its special riot-police units from towns where members of the Serb minority seized an estimated 500 automatic weapons and handguns from police armories. Tanjug quoted the presidency as saying, ``The situation in many areas with a mixed national population has seriously deteriorated . . . and is threatening to result in intranationalist conflicts with tragic consequences.'' The Knin shooting came when two policemen were stopped late Tuesday night at a roadblock about three miles from Knin, about 125 miles south of Zagreb. The rifle-toting civilian guards demanded that the officers surrender arms; the police refused; as they tried to leave, the guards fired and wounded them, Tanjug said. It reported the injuries were not life-threatening. An explosion in Knin late Tuesday wrecked a Croatian news stand, a witness reported. No one was injured. Serbia is Yugoslavia's largest republic, and Croatia the second-largest. The rivalry between Serbs and Croats dates from Yugoslavia's founding in 1918 and heightened dramatically after the center-right government ousted Communists last spring in Croatia's first free elections in over 45 years. The Serbs accuse the new government in Zagreb of discriminating against them. The Croatian government says the unrest was orchestrated by Communist-governed Serbia to undermine democracy in Croatia and rally popular support for Serbia's hardline leaders. Serbs comprise about 10 percent of Croatia's 5 million people. Serbia's 14 main opposition parties said Wednesday they would boycott the region's first free elections in more than 50 years unless the Communists agreed to equal access to the state-run news media and other conditions. ``If they don't want Serbia to remain a sad, single-party dictatorship in today's democratic Europe'' the Communists should call off elections scheduled for Dec. 9, said a statement released by the opposition coalition. The Communists should then negotiate with the opposition and a democratic electoral law would follow, the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists: Oil Companies Fouling Ecuador's Rain Forests
DOC.TEXT: An environmental group charged Wednesday that oil companies are destroying Ecuador's rain forests with toxic waste discharges and oil pipeline spills amounting to more than was spilled from the Exxon Valdez. The Natural Resources Defense Council especially criticized Texaco Inc. and asked it to establish a $50 million fund to undertake emergency cleanups and establish environmental controls to prevent further contamination of the forests. ``The company bears at a minimum a moral responsibility to make appropriate reparations,'' the council said in a report on its 18-month on-site investigation of the impact of oil development on Ecuador's 3.1 million acres of tropical rain forest. Texaco spokesman Dave Dixon said the company was not given a copy of the report and therefore could not comment on specific charges. But, he added, ``In all its operations, Texaco's policy is to operate in accordance with the highest standards of environmental conservation.'' The report was released at a news conference attended by Robert F. Kennedy Jr., an attorney for the group who traveled to Ecuador in July. ``We saw things that in 20 years of going to Latin America I have never seen and (in) seven years of practicing environmental law in this state and being involved in some of the worst toxic sites in the state I have never seen,'' Kennedy said. In contaminated areas of the forests ``children have pus coming out of their eyes from bathing in streams, animals are dead ... adults have rashes covering their bodies,'' he said. The Ecuadoran government has recorded about 30 major oil spills from the Trans-Ecuadorian pipeline from 1972 until October 1989, with an estimated loss of 16.8 million gallons of oil, according to the natural resources council. During that time, the pipeline was operated by Texaco, it said. The Exxon Valdez spilled about 10.8 million gallons of oil into the Prince William Sound in Alaska. The pipeline is particularly vulnerable to spills because it crosses a major Andean fault. In March 1987, earthquakes caused some 5.9 million gallons of oil to spew into the Coca River. Ecuador's rain forests also are being contaminated by poisonous wastes from hundreds of oil wells in the region, the environmental group charged. More than 4 million gallons of these wastes are dumped untreated into unlined pits every day and seep into streams and aquifers, it said. Cleanup efforts are primitive, at best, according to the council. Kennedy said he saw inhabitants of the Cuyabeno Wildlife Reserve cleaning up an oil spill by using their bare hands to scoop oil into plastic bags, which were then buried in pits. The council is the first environmental group to examine the impact of oil development on rain forests, said S. Jacob Scherr, director of the council's international program. Traditionally, he said, environmentalists have worried about the destruction of tropical forests by slash-and-burn farmers, logging, mining and road building. The environmental group also urged Conoco, a subsidiary of Du Pont Co., to cancel its plans to drill oil in the region, saying it ``would risk unnecessary and irreparable injury to the indigenous Huaorani people.'' Ed Davies, president and general manager of Conoco Ecuador, said in a telephone interview from Quito, Ecuador, that the company was working closely with the Huaorani, who number only 1,580, to ensure the oil development does not have a negative impact on them.

DOC.SECOND: AM-2 Live Crew, 2nd Ld - Writethru, a0678,0995
DOC.HEAD: Record Store Owner Convicted of Obscenity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 18th graf, `The jury ...' to UPDATE with reaction from band's DJ; picks up 19th graf, `Jury instructions ...' Deletes three of final four grafs to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: An all-white jury Wednesday convicted a record store owner of obscenity for selling a sexually explicit album by the black rap group 2 Live Crew that had been banned by a federal judge. The panel of five women and one man took only 2{ hours to return the verdict against Charles Freeman, 31. The misdemeanor conviction carries a possible one-year jail sentence and $1,000 fine. Broward County Judge Paul Backman set sentencing for Nov. 2. ``I'm absolutely stunned by the verdict,'' defense attorney Bruce Rogow said. Freeman denounced the jurors as unfair and ignorant of the black community. The departing jurors had no comment. ``I felt that the jury paid very close attention to the evidence,'' said prosecutor Leslie Robson. ``They came back with a verdict that spoke the truth.'' The Miami-based rap group and its album ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' have been at the center of a First Amendment dispute since June 6, when a Fort Lauderdale federal judge ruled their lyrics obscene. The lyrics have been criticized as promoting violence against women. The federal judge's ruling banned the sale of the album in three south Florida counties, but opened a flood of legal cases around the country against the album. Shortly after the decision sales of the 2-year-old album nationwide approached 2 million. ``It's the first time in (U.S.) musical history that a piece of work has been found to be obscene,'' said Trish Heimers, spokeswoman for the Recording Industry Association of America, a Washington-based trade association for U.S. record companies. ``There are not small steps toward censorship, and I would most certainly characterize this as censorship.'' In February, a record store owner in Alexander City, Ala., was acquitted of obscenity for selling the album. ``Is this America?'' asked Robyn Blumner, executive director of the state American Civil Liberties Union chapter. ``These things happen in totalitarian societies where certain ideas may not be expressed upon penalty of law.'' Broward Sheriff Nick Navarro, who led the case, greeted the verdict by saying the system worked: ``This was never a case of censorship but rather one man flouting the law. The First Amendment is alive and well.'' And Donald Wildmon, founder of the conservative American Family Association based in Tupelo, Miss., saw the conviction as a sign of a national trend against obscenity and pornography: ``There's definitely a shift in attitudes in America about this kind of trash.'' Freeman, who is black, was arrested two days after the ruling when he sold the album to undercover police officers at his E-C record store in Fort Lauderdale. Three members of the rap group later were charged with performing obscene material at a nightclub show in nearby Hollywood. Their trial is set Oct. 9. Rogow, who also represents the band members, promised an appeal on grounds that the jury pool did not represent the community and that evidence of adult videotapes and magazines available in the county was improperly excluded. ``What you have is a jury that could not represent all of Broward County,'' he said. ``Certainly it was not a cross-section of the county.'' The jury ``doesn't represent my community,'' Freemanshouted to reporters as he left the courthouse. ``It's unfair. The jury was all white. They don't know where E-C Records is. They don't know a god-damned thing about the ghetto.'' 2 Live Crew was scheduled to perform Wednesday night at a club in Niagara Falls, N.Y. David Hobbs, the band's disc jockey, said the controversy would not force the group to alter its style. ``We feel that we have to do what we have to do, and that's make the same records that we've been making,'' Hobbs said. ``If it wouldn't have been us, it would have been somebody else,'' Hobbs said at a news conference. ``Someone's always going to be the target. It just happened to get pointed at our direction.'' Jury instructions followed a U.S. Supreme Court standard saying material could be found obscene if it has no artistic merit and appeals solely to prurient interests. A tape of the disputed record was played for the jury. ``Obscenity is what this is,'' prosecutor Robson said, waving a cassette tape before the jury in her closing arguments. The trial was the first jury test of U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez's ruling that the group's raunchy lyrics were obscene. Alternate juror Sheryl Salomon, who sat through the 2{-day trial but was not needed for deliberations, said after her dismissal that she would have acquitted Freeman. ``I was very offended by it, especially the lyrics, but I have to question whether there is no artistic value,'' she said. ``It's music, it's still music. Legal arguments focused on First Amendment free-speech protection, but race has been an underlying issue. Defense attorneys objected to the makeup of the 35-member jury pool, which included only one black whose name was not picked when a dozen names were drawn at random as the final group of prospective jurors. ``One person's vulgarity is another person's art,'' Rogow said. ``It's never easy living with the First Amendment. A person can say terrible things violently against the government, against the family, against women and against men, and it's all within the parameters of the First Amendment.'' ``The First Amendment doesn't mean you can say what you want to whom you want and when you want because there's responsibilities along with those rights,'' Robson said. ``One of the things you can't do is you can't sell obscene material.''

DOC.HEAD: Belgian Military Aid Sought to Battle Rebel Invasion
ssociated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The president of Rwanda on Wednesday asked the nation's former colonial ruler for military aid to help battle an invasion led by refugees based in neighboring Uganda. A Belgian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman said officials were studying the plea from President Juvenal Habyarimana, who stopped in Brussels en route from New York. Belgium has about 20 military advisers in Rwanda and more than 1,600 Belgians live there. The central African nation gained its independence from Belgium in 1962. The invasion began Sunday, led by Fred Rwigyema, a member of Rwanda's Tutsi ethnic group who has become the deputy commander of Uganda's army since being exiled there years ago. The Tutsi group lost to the rival Hutu group in a power struggle about 30 years ago. An estimated 87,000 Tutsi refugees live in southwestern Uganda and some have gained senior posts in the Ugandan government, especially the army. Rwandese troops Wednesday appeared to halt the advance of the rebel force seeking to overthrow the government, said a Western diplomat in Rwanda's capital of Kigali. The diplomat said the rebel fighters, which include deserters from the Ugandan army, was estimated at 1,500. Another diplomat, at the U.S. embassy, put the force at from 5,000 to 10,000. Rwanda, a nation of 7.2 million, has an army of 5,000 troops. The rebel advance stalled around Gabiro and Gatsibo, two border towns about 70 miles northeast of the capital and about 25 miles inside Rwanda, the diplomats said. The diplomat said the government mobilized all reservists Tuesday night and the Rwandese were ``fighting for survival.'' A Uganda army spokesman in Kampala, the Ugandan capital, said the invaders killed 12 Rwandese soldiers at the border Monday. U.S. Embassy officials began moving about 200 Americans out of the fighting region Wednesday. Kigali was quiet except for additional troops guarding strategic buildings. Soldiers also manned roadblocks on highways leading into the city. ``The shops are open. The airport is open, and people are working in government offices,'' said the U.S. embassy spokesman. Ugandan authorities issued a statement condemning ``vehemently this act by the refugees who have enjoyed Uganda's hospitality for 30 years.'' President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda was returning Wednesday from New York after attending a U.N.-sponsored summit on children.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Visits Kuwait, His `19th Province'
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein toured the streets of Kuwait City on Wednesday and visited with soldiers who promised to defend the invaded country against ``all evil attempts'' to dislodge them. In his first reported visit to occupied Kuwait, Saddam found a capital that ``glittered with pride'' at his presence, the official Iraqi News Agency said, monitored in Nicosia. Saddam toured the streets of Kuwait, which ``appeared flourishing after its return to the mother homeland.'' Saddam has annexed Kuwait and proclaimed it Iraq's 19th province. The visit appeared to be an effort to counter reports of turmoil overtaking the city since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion. ``On his arrival at the center of the city of Kuwait, the president presided over two meetings of the military commanders and a number of officials attended by Mr. Ali Hassan Al-Majeed, minister of the local administration,'' the Iraqi News Agency said. Al-Majeed, a cousin of Saddam, has Cabinet rank as minister of local governments. Maintaining longtime links with Iraq's secret police, he oversaw Iraq's poison-gas attacks on ethnic Kurds in the north of the country in the fall of 1988 that reportedly killed thousands of people. The news agency said that after the meetings with the officials, Saddam ``made a tour during which he met a number of units of the Iraqi brave armed forces and talked to the fighters.'' The troops confirmed to Saddam ``their ever-readiness for sacrifice for Iraq and the Arab nation and defeating all evil attempts to desecrate our sacred land,'' the news agency said. Refugees fleeing Kuwait have said that stores and shops have been pillaged. There have been reports of summary executions of resistance fighters. Many refugees said they had feared to leave their homes. President Bush has cited such reports in saying that the United Nations might have to provide more action to dislodge Iraq if economic sanctions fail to do so. Military action has been suggested. The presidential visit Wednesday also may be construed in the West as an effort by Saddam to stake a further claim on Kuwait. Western leaders have said repeatedly that Iraq must withdraw Kuwait before any serious dialogue can begin.

DOC.HEAD: Feinstein Criticizes Wilson for Failing to Vote on Souter
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial candidate Dianne Feinstein criticized Sen. Pete Wilson on Wednesday for failing to vote on the confirmation of Supreme Court Justice David Souter. She described the Souter vote as ``the most critical and important judicial appointment of the decade'' and said it was arrogant of her Republican opponent to skip that and other major Senate votes. Wilson was the only senator who missed the Souter vote. His vote wouldn't have made any difference in Souter's 90-9 confirmation, Wilson said in explaining why he didn't interrupt his campaigning in California to return to Washington on Tuesday. Wilson and Feinstein have their first televised debate Sunday. Wilson also was criticized by Robert Fertik, president of Democrats for Choice, a White Plains, N.Y.-based organization whose supporters include 18 members of Congress. ``Senator Wilson says he's an unwavering supporter of abortion rights,'' said Fertik. ``On the most important abortion rights vote of the decade, he didn't even bother to show up.'' Fertik predicted Souter will provide the crucial fifth vote to overturn Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion. Wilson said there is a good chance he might not be present for the expected vote on the deficit reduction compromise of President Bush and congressional leaders. Wilson and Feinstein refused to take a stand on the deficit reduction proposal. Wilson said it's ``undoubtedly true'' that it's the best plan that can be negotiated at this time, but added that he is ``not crazy about it'' because of the tax increases. Wilson said he would stay in California campaigning and preparing for the debate unless his vote is essential. Feinstein described the budget plan as ``the most significant deficit reduction program in a decade.'' ``On the other hand ... it's protecting the rich'' by skewing tax increases to hit the middle class hardest,'' she added.
