DOC.HEAD: Polls Indicate Conservatives Fared Well in Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with exit poll results showing success by conservative candidates.
DOC.TEXT: Conservatives won or led many congressional and gubernatorial elections in an apparent vote of support for rightist President Fernando Collor de Mello, according to exit polls Wednesday. Official ballot counting did not begin until polls closed at 5 p.m. (4 p.m. EDT). But voter surveys showed rightists had captured at least eight of 27 gubernatorial races and a majority of Senate and House seats in the vote. The Liberal Front Party, which had elected just one governor in the 1985 election, won in five states. Collor's tiny National Reconstruction Party made gains across the country, including Collor's home state of Alagoas in northern Brazil. Besides the governorships in all 26 states and the capital district of Brasilia, all 503 seats in the federal House of Representatives and 31 of 81 Senate posts were at stake in the elections, which come five years after the end of Brazil's 19-year military dictatorship. Runoffs will be held Nov. 25 if no gubernatorial candidate receives 50 percent of the valid votes. A majority is not required in other races. In Sao Paulo, the top gubernatorial electoral prize with almostof the Democratic Workers Party won easily in Rio de Janeiro with 57 percent, and Ciro Gomes of the Brazilian Social Democracy Party took a majority in the northern state of Ceara. The militant Workers Party, which was seen as the major rising force in Brazilian politics last year, faded dramatically and was near the lead only in the far-western Amazon state of Acre. A runoff there is likely. Early polls indicated about 12 percent of the 83 million registered voters - from the steamy Amazon to the industrialized southeast - would cast blank ballots to protest Collor's economic austerity policies. ``Politicians have no credibility,'' said Carlos Alberto Gomes, 32, who cast a blank ballot in Rio's middle-class district of Flamengo. ``They promise the world and deliver nothing.'' Sociologist Helio Jaguaribe said voters have ``stopped believing in politicians and lost hope in the renovation of the political class.'' The balloting is the first since a December 1989 vote made Collor the country's first freely-elected president in 29 years. Final results will not be known for more than a week. In remote areas, ballots must be delivered to regional electoral centers by muleback and canoe, and the vote count is largely done manually. The new congress will convene in February 1991 while the new governors take office in March. Thousands of army troops were on the street to ensure order in about 270 of the country's 4,500 counties. Most were posted in backwoods towns where violence has flared between local political factions. Soldiers also were stationed in the northeastern city of Recife, capital of Pernambuco state. Conservative Joaquim Francisco was matched against leftist Jarbas Vasconcelos in a hotly disputed race for governor. Federal police chief Romeo Tuma reported at midday the elections were taking place in a climate of ``total tranquility throughout the country.'' Voting is obligatory for Brazilians 18 to 69. Those who fail to do so pay a $7 fine and are subjected to bureaucratic hassles. Sixteen- and 17-year-olds can also vote but it is not mandatory.

DOC.HEAD: Holdout Embassies in Kuwait Caving in to Iraqi Siege
DOC.TEXT: Foreign embassies trying to hold out in Kuwait are caving in one by one to Iraq's siege tactics, and one European foreign minister said he doubted any foreign missions could remain beyond this week. After invading Kuwait, Iraq ordered the embassies closed and many shut down a few weeks after the Aug. 24 deadline. But many countries, including the United States and Britain, have defied the order and kept their embassies open with skeletal staffs. Sixteen die-hard embassies remain open despite tough conditions. Most have had their electricity and water cut, and many are surrounded by Iraqi soldiers and tanks, their communications and food lines severed. Bowing to the hardships, Spain and South Korea last week withdrew their remaining diplomats from Kuwait City. Spain gave as its reason the superior power of Iraq's army, which surrounded the Spanish Embassy in the days prior to the charge d'affaires' departure Thursday. Madrid nevertheless said it considers its embassy open in principle and rejects Iraq's annexation of Kuwait. The South Korean Foreign Ministry said it ``temporarily'' closed its embassy because of the ``deteriorated situation.'' Belgian Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens said Saturday in New York that most European embassies still open in Kuwait would probably have to close this week. There are fewer than 10 diplomats at the U.S. Embassy, according to a State Department official who refused to go into more detail. The besieged Americans are cut off but have enough food and water, said the official. He would not estimate how long they can hold out ``under the very trying circumstances.'' He would not comment on earlier reports that the Americans were using the embassy swimming pool for drinking water. The British Embassy has only four staff remaining including the ambassador, but two will be leaving soon via Baghdad to conserve supplies for the other two, according to a Foreign Office spokesman. He declined to comment on the food supply, although he said staff at the embassy are ``in good spirits.'' Eyskens said last week that the British Embassy appeared to have more plentiful supplies than others in Kuwait. The French have about a half-dozen diplomats in Kuwait, according to the Foreign Ministry in Paris. ``There's no problem. We're holding on,'' a spokeman said simply. The French government has been reluctant to give details about French citizens who remain in Kuwait. ``They have good morale, and there hasn't been any particular problem recently,'' the spokesman said. Italy has only two diplomats in Kuwait who are surviving ``with their supplies ... . They eat canned food,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Vittorio Surdo said Tuesday. He said morale was high but ``the pressure is increasing.'' The Belgian ambassador and his chief aide, along with a non-diplomatic Belgian couple and their three children in the Belgian Embassy are all right but their food and water are running low. A Foreign Ministry source said he assumed some supplies were getting to the embassy but it was becoming increasingly difficult, probably forcing the embassy to close soon. The Dutch may be the best off among the Europeans. ``There's lots of everything,'' including food and drink, and no Iraqi soldiers outside the mission, a government spokeswoman said Tuesday. The ministry knows of no ``unusual hardships,'' she said. The five Gulf Cooperation Council countries besides Kuwait - Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Qatar, United Arab Emirates and Oman - have refused the Iraqi order to close their embassies, insisting that their diplomats remain accredited to the deposed government of Kuwait. All but the Saudi Arabian missions are known to be staffed, but diplomatic sources in the Persian Gulf said this week that low-ranking Saudi diplomats are there to underscore Saudi support for Kuwait. The Philippine Embassy was reported two weeks ago by a Philippine journalist who visited Kuwait to be crammed with some 3,000 nationals caught when Iraqi troops swarmed into the oil-rich emirate. Foreign Ministry officials in Manila say they do not know how many remain, but say the embassy still has electricity and water. Indonesia's embassy is not closed, although Jakarta has withdrawn its diplomats and left the building under the care of a local guardian whose food comes from Jordan or from the Indonesian Embassy in Baghdad, according to the Indonesian Foreign Ministry. Other embassies that have refused the order to close include Canada, Luxembourg, Senegaland Germany. Kuwait's Cabinet-in-exile, operating out of Saudi Arabia, issued a statement Tuesday condemning Baghdad for its treatment of embassies and diplomats and praising the ``honorable stand'' of those who remained.

DOC.HEAD: Former Rebels, Police Clash in Northern Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: A band of about 20 former Contra rebels attacked a police post in northern Nicaragua and at least four rebels were killed and nine wounded, the Interior Ministry said Wednesday. One policeman also was wounded in the Tuesday raid at Waslala, 125 miles north of Managua, ministry spokesman Frank Cesar said. He said the government assigned a commission to investigate, including observers from the Organization of American States, United Nations and Central American. There have been several attacks recently by intransigent Contras, most notably at Sandinista cooperative farms. People living in the region said by telephone that the former rebels managed to take over the station and forced about 15 police to take refuge in Sandinista army installations. The residents said a five-member military police commission was taken hostage briefly. Cesar said he had no information on that. Another ministry source said about 100 former Contras surrounded La Dalia, another town in the region, early Wednesday. Most of the U.S.-backed Contras turned in their weapons and left camps on the Honduran side of the border under an agreement on transition of power from the leftist Sandinistas to President Violeta Chamorro. Mrs. Chamorro defeated incumbent President Daniel Ortega in Feb. 25 elections. She took office April 25. The government said 30,000 people were killed and 25,000 wounded during nearly nine years of civil war. Former Contras returning to Nicaragua have complained that the Chamorro government isn't fulfilling promises of creating development centers for them. The cooperative farms they invaded were created during the 10 years of Sandinista government. Most have have a small school, health center and some farm equipment. Sandinistas expropriated much of the land from wealthy landowners. Former rebels have been allowed to live at some Sandinista cooperatives but have been rejected at others.

DOC.HEAD: 16 Killed When Bus Fall 100 Feet From Bridge
DOC.TEXT: A bus carrying more than 55 elderly Italian tourists plunged from a rain-slicked bridge Wednesday, killing 16 people and injuring about 30, authorities said. The bus fell about 100 feet, said highway police near Ovada, about 60 miles southwest of Milan. The bus company told the Italian news agency ANSA the accident may have occurred because the 31-year-old driver, who died in the crash, suffered a sudden, unspecified illness. An official in Ovada said bad weather may have been the cause. ``At the moment of the accident, it was raining cats and dogs,'' he said. ``The road was really wet.'' The bus was carrying elderly people from the coastal town of Albissola to Novara, in northern Italy.

DOC.SECOND: AM-2 Live Crew-Reax, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0737,0735
DOC.HEAD: Music Industry Denounces Obscenity Conviction in 2 Live Crew Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT to June sted July.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-2 Live Crew, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The music industry and civil libertarians cried ``Censorship!'' after a Florida store owner was convicted for selling an album by 2 Live Crew, the first time a U.S. jury has deemed a musical recording obscene. ``If the people who run the state aren't careful, Florida in the '90s will become to rock 'n' roll what Mississippi was to civil rights in the '60s,'' said veteran rap publicist Bill Adler of Rhyme and Reason Productions in New York City. ``Is this America?'' asked Robyn Blumner, executive director of the state American Civil Liberties Union chapter. ``These things happen in totalitarian societies where certain ideas may not be expressed upon penalty of law.'' An all-white jury convicted Fort Lauderdale record store owner Charles Freeman, 31, of obscenity Wednesday for selling the album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' by the black, Miami-based rap group on June 8. Two days earlier, a federal judge in Broward County ruled their lyrics obscene and banned the sale of the album in Broward and two other Florida counties. ``It's the first time in (U.S.) musical history that a piece of work has been found to be obscene,'' said Trish Heimers, spokeswoman for the Recording Industry Association of American, a Washington-based trade association for U.S. record companies. ``There are not small steps toward censorship, and I would most certainly characterize this as censorship,'' she said. Band members appeared at a news conference before their show at a Niagara Falls, N.Y., nightclub but they would not discuss the case or their own upcoming obscenity trial in Miami in any detail. ``We feel that we have to do what we have to do, and that's make the same records that we've been making,'' said David Hobbs, the group's disc jockey. ``That's it,'' he said. Hobbs, who spoke for the group, said the musicians feel they were just a convenient foil for the anti-obscenity movement. ``If it wouldn't have been us, it would have been somebody else,'' he said. ``Someone's always going to be the target. It just happened to get pointed in our direction.'' The group's lyrics include sexually explicit language and have been criticized as promoting violence against women, a charge Hobbs rejected. The U.S. Supreme Court has ruled that material could be found obscene if it has no artistic merit and appeals solely to prurient interests. Broward Sheriff Nick Navarro, who led the prosecution case, greeted the verdict by saying the system worked: ``This was never a case of censorship but rather one man flouting the law. The First Amendment is alive and well.'' Donald Wildmon, founder of the conservative American Family Association based in Tupelo, Miss., saw the conviction as a sign of a national trend against obscenity and pornography: ``There's definitely a shift in attitudes in America about this kind of trash.'' Heimers argued that a recording should be judged for both musical and lyrical content, and ``by the very nature of having both, it can't be deemed as obscene. The music, no matter what the lyrics, is not without artistic value.'' She said the music industry was prepared to assist Freeman with financial and legal help. Freeman's lawyer promised to appeal the misdemeanor conviction, which carries a possible one-year jail sentence and $1,000 fine. ``The precedent has been set that it's OK to find music obscene and that is wrong,'' Heimers said. ``Any country that allows the KKK (Ku Klux Klan) to have a TV show on public access should have the 2 Live Crew available.'' ``Obviously we're shocked and dismayed over many elements of the decision, and there's not much in life that shocks me,'' said Michael Greene, president of the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences in Burbank, Calif. Greene criticized ``the extremely narrow view that the judge and jury exhibited'' in convicting Freeman and questioned ``how an all-white, predominantly female jury can determine what does and does not constitute artistic merit in a primarily inner-city, black music form.'' ``Today the victim is a little guy who sells records, but we're sure the target is a black form of music and freedom of expression,'' Greene said.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Will Review Asylum Claims of Undocumented Passengers
DOC.TEXT: Britain on Wednesday granted temporary admission to 156 political asylum seekers who arrived without warning or travel documents aboard a cargo plane from Syria, the Home Office reported. A Gatwick airport spokeswoman said she believed the passengers, including 61 children, were Kurds from Iraq. The Home Office would only say they ``are of Middle Eastern origin.'' A Home Office statement said the arrivals would stay with friends and relatives while their claims for asylum are considered over the next few months. The group arrived Tuesday night aboard an Egyptian ZAS airline DC-9 from the Syrian capital of Damascus. Political asylum applicants must ``usually have to prove they face persecution at home,'' said the statement. Since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Britain has introduced measures to restrict entry of Iraqis, but the refugees' claims will be reviewed according to United Nations policies, said a Home Office spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has used chemical weapons against Kurds in northern Iraq seeking independence. The Kurdish rebellion flared during Iraq's eight-year war with Iran. None of those on the cargo plane had travel documents. The group was initially detained in a lounge at Gatwick, about 25 miles south of London. The Home Office said ZAS was fined $290,000 for transporting passengers without documents. The Gatwick spokeswoman said the pilot informed Gatwick authorities of the passengers only 30 minutes before landing. The plane was on a scheduled cargo flight. British authorities detained the aircraft, but crew members were allowed to book into a hotel, the spokeswoman said. On Tuesday, 76 Romanian vacationers applied for political asylum in Britain. They were part of a group of more than 200 Romanians who flew to Bristol in southern England on Saturday. The asylum-seekers told immigration officials there was still repression in Romania despite the December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was later executed.

DOC.HEAD: Superpowers Pledge Broader Cooperation
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union issued a joint call Wednesday for a stronger United Nations role in peace-making and crisis prevention. The statement reflected the growing cooperation between the two superpowers in the Persian Gulf and in trying to ease tensions in southern Africa and Central America. ``Serious problems still remain,'' the statement said. ``Our search continues for workable soltuions to conflict and instability'' in the gulf, the Middle East, Afghanistan and el Salvador.'' The superpowers affirmed the responsibility of all nations to pay their assessments - something of an embarrassment for both. The Soviets owe $137 million for contributions to peace-keeping forces they have refuwsed to pay. The United States is $462 in arrears on various payments and owes$62.5 million in current dues. The statement was issued shortly after Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze concluded an agreement in principle on a treaty to imposee ceilings on NATO and Warsaw Pact conventional forces in Europe. ``The rapidly changing structure of international relations requires a United Nations that, while remaining faithful to its original purposes, can also respond flexibly and effectively to new challenges as they occur,'' the statement said. As najor contributors to the U.N. budget, the superpowers called for the elimination of duplication in programs while affirming their responsibility to pay assessments.

DOC.HEAD: Former AP, Arizona Republic Newsman Dies
DOC.TEXT: A.V. Gullette, a former Associated Press news executive and business writer for The Arizona Republic, died Wednesday following a short illness. He was 87. Gullette retired from the Republic in 1983, 30 years after joining the Phoenix newspaper. He joined The Associated Press as a reporter in 1937 in Albuquerque, N.M. He was named chief of bureau there in 1947 and held that post when he resigned in 1952. He also had worked for the Omaha World-Herld, the Durango, Colo., Herald, and the Gallup, N.M., Independent and the New Mexico Sentinel. In a column on his retirement at age 79, Republic writer Ira Fine described him as ``one of the most energetic reporters in Phoenix, churning out story after story and outdistancing some colleagues who were decades younger than he.'' ``But perhaps the best measure of Vince's impact is that he is remembered so fondly on the outside for dealing with people fairly and directly,'' the columnist added. Survivors include sons Keith V. Gullette of San Francisco, Vincent Tucker Gullette of Sheraton, Ore., and daughters Billie Lee McKnight of San Diego; Suzanne Rawlings of Nashville, Tenn.; Suzette O'Neal of Mendecino, Calif.; and Jacqueline Gullette, whose hometown was unavailable. A memorial service was planned for 10:30 a.m. Saturday at Shadow Mountain Mortuary in Phoenix.

DOC.HEAD: Now, It's House Democrats Rebelling Against Budget Package
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, bgng: But Bush xxx to include vote estimates.
DOC.TEXT: Liberal House Democrats rebelled Wednesday against the $500-billion deficit-reduction package as President Bush and congressional leaders pushed hard for the plan on the eve of its first vote. Leading House Democrats and Republicans expressed confidence that both sides would round up a majority of votes by Thursday, when the full House plans to vote on an outline of the package of tax boosts and spending cuts. ``That is my intuition, that when the vote comes there will be a majority of both parties,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. But Bush, Foley and House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., worked furiously behind the scenes, meeting privately with rank-and-file members and dispatching top lieutenants to do the same. Democratic leadership aides, speaking privately, offered conflicting assessments of how worried they might be about the prospects. Democrats and Republicans figured on Wednesday nght they were each 40 votes short of what they need and that a considerable number of lawmakers remained uncommitted. A number of liberal Democrats said they would oppose the proposal, complaining about its reliance on $60 billion in Medicare cuts over five years and about the $11 billion in tax breaks it contains for small businesses. ``To cut $60 billion from Medicare means a lot of low-income elderly are going to be faced with difficult out-of-pocket expenses,'' said Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif. ``These people didn't create the deficit.'' After a day of White House lobbying Republicans, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the needed votes still were not in hand, and declined to say how many votes the White House could muster. Bush kept close tabs on the results of lobbying efforts, checking in with Fitzwater at the end of the day for a reading of what the Congress members were telling reporters. Fitzwater told him that ``most say they are considering it, they're listening and they're sympathetic to the argument.'' Twenty-seven more Republicans met with Bush at the White House, the third straight day on which GOP lawmakers were summoned by the president for his sales pitch. One White House official called the operation the Bush administration's biggest lobbying effort yet. ``I was leaning against before. Now I'm firmly undecided,'' said Rep. Bob Livingston, R-La., after emerging from a meeting. Reps. Susan Molinari and Sherwood L. Boehlert, both R-N.Y., said they were more inclined to vote with the president after the meeting, but they wanted an unpopular 2 cents per gallon home heating oil tax dropped. ``It was not any arm twisting. He based all his arguments on facts,'' Molinari said. Bush cancelled a weekend trip to his Maine summer home to stay on top of the budget issue. ``There comes a time when you have to simply make tough decisions, give a little, to get what is best for the country,'' Bush told reporters in a message clearly designed for congressional consumption. He urged members of Congress to vote for the package and then ``blame the president'' when they talk to voters. Meanwhile, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said at a congressional hearing that he supports the deficit-reduction package. Greenspan's views are important since supporters of the plan are looking to the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates to offset any negative economic effects. The package would raise taxes on gasoline, home heating oil, alcohol, tobacco, expensive cars and other luxury items, and on the incomes of the wealthy. It would cut defense spending by close to $200 billion over the next five years while reducing spending on benefit programs by $105 billion. The heating oil provision was being fought by members of Congress from Northeastern states, some of whom said that keeping it in could hurt support for the overall proposal. On Capitol Hill, liberal Rep. Dale Kildee, D-Mich., said he was lobbied by a ``rather pessimistic'' sounding Foley. ``He was really laboring hard for my vote,'' said Kildee, who is leaning against the plan. On the Republican side, No. 3 House GOP leader Jerry Lewis, R-Calif., predicted ``a substantial victory'' for the plan. A Republican aide said 50 of the House's 176 Republicans were now committed to vote for the package. But opposition continued from conservatives unhappy with the plan's $134 billion in new taxes and with spending cuts they consider insufficient. Rep. Newt Gingrich, the chamber's No. 2 Republican leader and a leading opponent, who Tuesday said Bush's lobbying would ensure the package's success, said Wednesday he was no longer sure. Bush, nn a televised address Tuesday night, asked Americans to tell their congressional representatives they supported the plan. But Gingrich, R-Ga., said, ``I've had members walk up to me and say they've gotten so many phone calls from their districts against the package that they don't know if they can stay with it.'' Senate leaders have been more confident about the proposal's prospects there. It was uncertain whether the Senate would vote Thursday or Friday. Whatever the outcome in this week's preliminary votes, lawmakers from both sides said they would not vote for the deficit-reduction package itself - a vote expected in two weeks - unless changes were made. At a morning meeting of House Democrats, leaders begged the rank-and-file members to vote yes on Thursday and to see about alterations after that. Among the skeptics is House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., who said the measure's Medicare cuts were too deep and its tax breaks for companies too generous. Republicans have said the tax benefits - such as one that allows deductions for some money invested in small companies - would help create jobs. ``I can see a tax shelter boom, and the only employment that will I think be created is a boom in tax-shelter packaging,'' said Rostenkowski. Rostenkowski, who said he has not decided how he will vote, is one of the more influential members of the House. His committee must approve the new levies, tax changes and spending cuts.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer For Arson-Murder Suspect To Use Insanity Defense
DOC.TEXT: The lawyer for a man accused of setting a fire that killed 87 people at a social club declared in court Wednesday his intention to use an insanity defense. Defense lawyer Richard Berne said he would use the insanity defense for Julio Gonzalez, who is charged with murder and arson for the March fire at the Happy Land unlicensed nightclub. Gonzalez returns to state Supreme Court in the Bronx Nov. 15, when reports of psychiatric evaluations performed on him by both sides will be turned over to the court and a date will be set for his trial. Gonzalez, 36, allegedly set the blaze with a dollar's worth of gasoline after a fight with his ex-girlfriend, who worked at the club.

DOC.HEAD: Knight Foundation Awards $2.3 Million in Grants to 10 Schools
DOC.TEXT: The Knight Foundation awarded $2.3 million in grants Wednesday to 10 colleges and universities. The grants, awarded under the foundation's Excellence in Undergraduate Education Program, were the third in a series announced by the foundation, which has given nearly $7.5 million to 31 schools in two years. ``Better education is a necessity in today's world,'' said Creed Black, foundation president. ``We want to make a difference in the quality of higher education, particularly at the undergraduate level at private liberal arts schools where additional support is needed.'' The foundation awarded $163,000 to Agnes Scott College of Decatur, Ga., $368,000 to Converse College and Wofford College, both of Spartanburg, S.C., and $250,000 each to Allegheny College of Meadville, Pa., Barry University of Miami, Benedictine College of Atchison, Kan., Dickinson College of Carlisle, Pa., Morehouse College of Atlanta, Mount St. Mary's College of Los Angeles, and St. Mary's College of Notre Dame, Ind.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Visits Occupied Kuwait; Iran Declares Hands-off Policy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with new material nnd editing, UPDATING with Iran to shy clear of any confrontation, Iraqi official arrives in Jordan, UPDATES Soviet and Japanese visits in Amman, Bush administration wants new regional coaltiion to balance Iraqi threat. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AMM1
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein on Wednesday made his first known visit to Kuwait since Iraq captured its oil-rich neighbor Aug. 2. Another neighbor, Iran, said it would keep out of any military confrontation between Iraq and U.S.-led multinational forces in the region. Elsewhere in the Middle East, visiting French President Francois Mitterrand, Japanese Prime Minister Toshiku Kaifu and Soviet envoy Yevgeny Primakov all sought a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. But new terror threats emerged. Palestinian guerrilla leader Abul Abbas warned he would attack U.S. aircraft if Iraqi planes were hit with weapons as part of the U.N. air embargo against Iraq. In Washington, Bush administration officials told Congress Iraq is likely to remain a long-term threat, and sales of billions of dollars in U.S. weaponry to Saudi Arabia are crucial to a new regional coalition to balance that menace. Iraq, facing an international force on its border with Saudi Arabia after invading Kuwait, suddenly made peace with Iran last month after eight years of war and two years of deadlocked peace talks. Saddam wooed Iran to side with him. Tehran joined world demands that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait, but also urged the expulsion of foreign forces from the region. On Wednesday, Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati said on Tehran TV that Iran wants a peaceful settlement and ``force should be the last possible resort for solving this crisis, but Iran will not participate in this in any way.'' His remarks, monitored in Cyprus, indicated Iran was distancing itself from Iraq, following suggestions it could circumvent a U.S.-led embargo and send Iraq food and medicine. Reports from Washington said Iraq also asked Tehran to help export its embargoed oil. The London-based Amnesty International meanwhile issued a report saying Iraqi occupation troops tortured and executed scores of people in Kuwait, some for refusing to display pictures of Saddam. Refugees have said stores and shops were pillaged, and that Iraq was out to dismantle Kuwaiti institutions. They reported summary executions of resistance fighters. The Iraqi News Agency gave a different portrait. It said Saddam toured the streets of Kuwait, which ``appeared flourishing after its return to the mother homeland.'' The news agency said Saddam met with Iraqi troops and presided over two meetings of military commanders. Iraq has annexed the emirate, declaring it Bahdad's 19th province. Kuwait city ``glittered with pride'' at Saddam's visit, said the agency, monitored in Cyprus. Mitterrand flew to the Persian Gulf for a two-day visit during which he planned to meet regional leaders and inspect French troops. After he left Paris, the Defense Ministry announced France was sending eight Mirage F1 fighter planes to Qatar to protect that small country and the United Arab Emirates, its neighbor. His first stop was the Emirates' capital of Abu Dhabi. He reached there hours after nine French nationals held hostage by Iraq flew out of Baghdad on an Iraqi plane and arrived in Amman, Jordan, bound for Paris. They were accompanied by the chairman of the private French group that arranged their release. Iraq is believed to still hold about 300 other French nationals hostage, as well as thousands of other Westerners. France now has 13,000 men plus a dozen warships in the gulf region, the largest overseas deployment of French troops since the Algerian war. Primakov, a Mideast expert and close adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, met King Hussein and other senior Jordanian officials on Wednesday in Amman. He said he brought a letter for Hussein that concerns ``efforts to find a settlement for the gulf crisis and other Mideast problems.'' The monarch has tried to play the role of mediator in the gulf crisis. The Soviet delegation was due to fly to Baghdad Thursday for talks with Iraqi officials. Late Wednesday, however, Iraqi Deputy Premier Taha Yassin Ramadan arrived in Amman. It was not known if this would change Primakov's plans. In New York, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said the delegation would like to meet Saddam and that it also hoped to arrange ``normal conditions'' for withdrawal of the 5,000 Soviet citizens remaining in Iraq. Before Kuwazit was invaded, the Kremlin was Baghdad's main weapons supplier and France was its next largest supplier. Moscow, however, joined the United States in demanding Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait, which Baghdad invaded in a dispute over land, oil and money. Japan's Kaifu also arrived in the Jordanian capital Wednesday for talks with Hussein on aid to Jordan and on peaceful efforts to solve the crisis. Kaifu met Wednesday night with Crown Prince Hassan, who briefed him on the economic losses Jordan has sustained because of its adherence to the U.N. embargo on Iraq, Jordan's largest trading partner. Kaifu said earlier in the day, the second day of his weeklong Middle East visit, that Japan would make ``more and stronger efforts'' to find a peaceful way out of the Persian Gulf crisis. He is to meet in Amman on Thursday with Iraq's vice president, Taha Yassin Ramadan. Shigeo Takanaka, deputy spokesman for Japan's Foreign Office, said the Iraqis requested the meeting. He said Kaifu ``plans to impose on Mr. Ramadan the importance of solving the crisis in the gulf in accordance with U.N. Security Council resolutions.'' The resolutions demand withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait, restoration of its ousted government and freedom for the thousands of Western hostages in both countries. They also impose air and sea embargoes on Iraq. On Wednesday, Abul Abbas , who masterminded the 1985 hijacking of the Italian liner Achille Lauro, called the air embargo ``the operation of air piracy by one state against another to serve its narrow-minded interests.'' He acccused the United States of masterminding it and declared, ``We will not permit such legislation to be implemented against our people and if any Iraqi aircraft is confronted by such air piracy and should any damage be inflicted on Iraq's civil aviation, we will retaliate.'' The threats came in a statement published by Baghdad's official al-Jumhuriya daily. Abul Abbas, who heads the extremist Palestine Liberation Front, did not specify what action would be taken, but he appeared to be talking about hijacking or bombing U.S. airliners.

DOC.HEAD: China, Singapore Establish Diplomatic Ties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT China has relations with five ASEAN members, sted six
DOC.TEXT: China and Singapore established diplomatic relations on Wednesday, their first official link since the Communists took over China in 1949. Foreign ministers Wong Kan Seng of Singapore and Qian Qichen of China sealed the agreement with a handshake and toast at a signing ceremony at U.N. Headquarters. China contains more than a billion people. Singapore, an island on the Malaysian peninsula, has 2.6 million. China has ties with five of the six members of ASEAN - the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, a regional grouping of non-communist countries. Brunei does not have relations with China. ``This will produce very positive influence on resolving regional conflicts and maintaining peace and stability in the region, particularly on the settlement of the Cambodian problem,'' Qian said at the signing ceremony. ASEAN has involved itself in trying to help resolve the Cambodian conflict. China is the chief ally and weapons supplier for the Khmer Rouge, the strongest guerrilla army fighting the Vietnam-installed government in Cambodia. China has cooperated with the four other permanent members of the Security Council - the Unied States, Soviet Union, Britain and France - in drafting a peace plan for Cambodia. Under the plan, the Cambodian government and three guerrilla factions would form a transitional government until the United Nations organized new elections. U.N. officials and peacekeepers would supervise or run the key government ministries in the interim, to allay fears that one party would gain the upper hand. A spokesman for Singapore's U.N. Mission said, ``We have always said that we would establish diplomatic relations after Indonesia has done so; Indonesia did so a few months ago.'' Indonesia had blamed China for a takeover attempt by Communists that was crushed in 1966. The official spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Alabama Doctor H. Ray Evers Dies
DOC.TEXT: H. Ray Evers, a doctor whose unconventional treatments kept him at odds with the medical establishment as he moved from town to town, has died of respiratory complications at age 77. Evers died Tuesday in El Paso, Texas, where he moved when Alabama medical officials barred him from practicing medicine and ordered his clinic in Cottonwood closed in June 1989, his son, Michael, said Wednesday. Evers operated a medical facility in Juarez, Mexico, just across the border from El Paso, the son said. A native of Repton, Evers graduated from Vanderbilt University Medical School in 1938 and, after serving a residency in New Orleans, he opened a medical practice in Andalusia in 1940. He founded Andalusia's Columbia General Hospital in 1952. In 1964, Evers claimed credit for developing holistic health care, in which a patient is treated physically, mentally and spiritually. He also was a proponent of chelation therapy, which attemps to cleanse the circulatory system by removing arterial plaque through the kidneys. His unorthodox treatments created controversy with the medical establishment and he moved his operation every few years, going from Andalusia to Atlanta to Belle Chase, La., Montgomery, the Bahamas, Cottonwood and finally Mexico. In 1986, the Alabama Medical Licensure Commission revoked his medical license when a cancer patient at his Cottonwood clinic died after being treated with a salve.

DOC.HEAD: ACLU Gets Judge To Halt Bible Readings in School
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge said Wednesday a fifth-grade teacher's daily Bible readings to her class violate the Constitution and must be stopped. U.S. District Judge John H. Moore II granted a preliminary injunction sought by the American Civil Liberties Union on behalf of the parents of a 9-year-old at Emma Love Elementary School in nearby Nassau County. They complained that teacher Martha Mitchell started each school day with a Bible story and said prayers daily before lunch. Moore said he would set a hearing soon on a final injunction. ``Albeit that the defendants may have good motives ... the practices violate the Constitution of the United States as interpreted by the Supreme Court,'' the judge said. The Nassau County School Board,bolstered by strong community support, voted 5-0 on Sept. 27 to let Mrs. Mitchell continue her Bible-story readings, which she said she used to settle down her class at the start of each day. The parents, Donald and Louise Hatch, said they have no personal objections to Mrs. Mitchell or her teaching methods. However, they said, their daughter should not be read Bible stories in school. ``We have been confident from the very beginning what the decision would be,'' Hatch said following the 30-minute hearing Wednesday. ``What the Nassau County School Board has been doing clearly violates the freedom of religion.'' Attorney Bill Sheppard, representing the Hatches on behalf of the ACLU, said after the hearing, ``Everyone must obey the laws of the United States of America or we'll be a country without laws. ``Official lawlessness is the most repugnant.'' School board attorney Marshall Wood, who had the task of defending the board even after informing its members that their decision was a violation of the Constitution, told Moore that the daily Bible reading was not meant as religious instruction but as a means of calming the students. ``Mrs. Mitchell contends this (the Bible) is a piece of literature,'' Wood said. Mrs. Mitchell, 51, of Fernandina Beach, did not attend the hearing. She said earlier that she was overwhelmed by the issue. ``I feel very humbled by the support I have received, by the Christian people who have come out and are willing to voice their feelings,'' she said. ``I never imagined this.'' Mrs. Mitchell, a Methodist, said she has read Bible stories to her schoolchildren throughout her 30-year career. Superintendent Craig Marsh said the schools will abide by the judge's ruling and will order all prayer and Bible reading stopped. ``I did not know it was going on until the Hatches brought it up,'' he said Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Film Director Hospitalized
DOC.TEXT: Polish film director Andrzej Wajda became ill Wednesday on a visit to Prague and was admitted to the intensive care unit of a hospital, a doctor said. The doctor, who spoke on condition he not be identified, ruled out coronary disease but declined to reveal the nature of the 64-year-old Wajda's illness. Doctors reportedly expected to release Wajda from intensive care in the next two days. Wajda, in Prague at the invitation of the Polish Cultural Center, is perhaps best known abroad for his movies ``Man of Marble,'' about a Stalin-era labor hero who falls into disfavor with Communist authorities and dies in the 1970 Gdansk shipyard strike, and ``Man of Iron,'' which chronicled the rise of the Solidarity free trade union.

DOC.HEAD: Man's Life Support Removed After Judge's Order
DOC.TEXT: The family of an 82-year-old man who has been in a coma for six years removed his feeding tube Wednesday after convincing a judge that he would not want to be kept alive by artificial means. Sidney Greenspan has been comatose since suffering a stroke in 1984 while stricken with Alzheimer's disease, an progressive and irreversible neurological disorder. His wife Bella, son Howard, and daughter Marla turned to the legal system in 1988 to have his intravenous feeding tubes removed. Relatives said Greenspan had expressed a desire to die if he ever lapsed into a vegetative state. Cook County Circuit Court Judge Richard Dowdle consented in a ruling Wednesday, saying the evidence presented to him was ``clear and convincing that the ward, if mentally able, would refuse to continue the treatment.'' In July, the Illinois Supreme Court had ordered Dowdle to reconsider his 1988 refusal to allow the feeding tube removal. The language of Dowdle's decision Wednesday echoed a June ruling by the U.S. Supreme Court upholding Missouri guidelines that kept the parents of car accident victim Nancy Cruzan from having her tube feeding stopped. The parents believed Cruzan would not want to be kept alive, but she did not leave a ``living will'' or other such evidence. A neurologist, Dr. Allan Burke, testified last week that Greenspan was in vegetative state and was getting worse. Burke said Greenspan could not swallow or communicate with others, exhibited only ``primitive responses'' to stimuli, and would die in less than a week if intravenous feeding were cut off. The feeding tube was removed by the family on Wednesday afternoon at a North Side nursing home where he is cared for, said Judy Lewis, the nursing home's director of admissions. ``The family members - his wife, son and daughter - were all in the room when the tubes were removed,'' she said. Lewis said nursing home officials were not involved. She did not know which family member removed the tube. The judge also ordered that guardians try to feed Greenspan orally after tubes are removed. He refused to grant a stay requested by Americans United For Life, a group opposing the removal of Greenspan's life support. The group sought the stay to appeal the judge's decision. ``We reluctantly have decided not to appeal Judge Dowdle's decision,'' said spokesman Paul Linton. ``Although we strongly disagree with this finding, we also recognize that such findings are seldom reversed on appeal.'' Doctors have testified that Greenspan, former owner of a Chicago plumbing supply business, lost his ability to swallow in 1985 because of Alzheimer's disease and has been tube-fed since then.

DOC.HEAD: China Identifies Hijacker in Jetliner Disaster as Known Criminal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs, UPDATING with specific number of injured. Picks up 7th graf, Relatives of . . .
DOC.TEXT: The hijacker who seized a Boeing 737 that plowed into two parked jets at Canton airport was identified by Chinese authorities Wednesday as a common criminal. He was among the 127 people killed in the fiery crash. Forty-six people were injured, many seriously, in the crash early Tuesday. The official Xinhua News agency said those killed included 90 Chinese, 30 Taiwanese, four people from Hong Kong, two from Macao and one American. Chen Kaizhi, deputy party secretary of Guangdong province, identified the 27-year-old hijacker only as Xiaofeng of Hunan province, and called him ``an active criminal'' who engaged in corruption in Guangdong, Hunan and Fujian provinces. Chen said he would provide details later. Chen said the hijacker was identified from his remains. Officials have said nothing about the cause of the crash or what happened during the hijacking of Flight 8305 of the state-owned Civil Aviation Administration airline. They said the pilot was allowed to handle the situation ``as he saw fit.'' Relatives of victims and foreign diplomats voiced anger and frustration that China was issuing a minimum of information on the worst reported air disaster in its history. ``We've been moving around like a headless chicken. Nobody has told us where our relatives are,'' a middle-aged Chinese man said early Wednesday, trying to get information from officials in Canton. ``We don't know whether they are alive or dead.'' A woman seeking news of relatives said, ``We don't think the government officials understand how we feel.'' They spoke on the condition of not being identified. The disaster comes as China is acting as host at its first major international sporting event, the Asian Games. Security forces nationwide had been on alert to prevent incidents that might embarrass the government. In Beijing, State Council spokesman Yuan Mu called the hijacking a tragedy but said ``it won't have an adverse effect on the games.'' An airport official quoted air traffic controllers as saying the pirate appeared confused about where he wanted to go, first saying Hong Kong, then Taiwan. The Boeing 737 slammed into two jets and exploded in a ball of flames. One jet was empty. The other, a Boeing 757, was packed with passengers bound for Shanghai. The airport official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said 80 of the 103 people on the hijacked plane died, and 47 of the 124 people on the Boeing 757. Reports reaching Hong Kong said the hijacker sneaked into the cockpit by offering the cabin crew flowers after the plane left Xiamen, south China. The plane flew to Canton, where it circled the airport for about 40 minutes before crashing. One Western survivor reported a cockpit struggle as the plane landed, causing it to careen into the other jets. Other reports said the hijacker set off a bomb. Survivors' accounts indicated the crash was caused by the hijacker's panic when he saw he was in Canton, raising the question of whether the carnage could have been avoided if the jet had been allowed to go to Hong Kong or Taiwan. Some travelers passing through the airport after the crash were athletes and spectators on their way from the games in Beijing. A Filipino spectator, Helen Chua, said after arriving in Manila that airport officials would speak about the crash. National TV news Wednesday night showed a burning plane snapped in half, with passengers covered with fire-fighting foam inching their way down a wing to ladders. The charred, hijacked jetliner lay flipped on its back. A fatality list released more than 30 hours after the disaster at Canton's Baiyun International Airport gave the American victim's name as Mary Anna Gerk, but her parents in the United States identified her as Mary Anna Gilbert, 23, an English teacher from Alexander City, Ala. Officials said Erin Lynne Thomas of Oklahoma City was sitting next to Ms. Gilbert and survived, suffering a broken shoulder, head injuries and burns.

DOC.HEAD: Hawaii Limits on Late Filing of Income Statements Ruled Invalid
DOC.TEXT: Hawaii's narrow limits on the filing of late income statements by low-income workers on welfare were declared invalid Wednesday by a federal appeals court. Hawaii cancels a month's welfare benefits if a statement proving eligibility is filed late, unless the applicant was ill or had trouble with the mails. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said exceptions had to be broader under a federal law waiving the deadline for ``good cause.'' The ruling allows a woman from Waianae in Oahu to keep $198 that the state sought to withhold in 1987 because she was a day late in filing her statement of earned income, after her employer had refused to provide pay stubs. Hawaii's lawyer in the case said the decision had ``nationwide implications.'' ``States that have restrictive definitions of good cause are on shaky grounds'' if the ruling stands, said Deputy Attorney General Thomas Farrell. Farrell said no decision has been made on an appeal. In the 2-1 ruling, the court said Congress intended the federal government to define ``good cause'' instead of leaving it to the states. The court did not provide its own definition, saying only that Hawaii's was too narrow. ``We felt under any definition of good cause, it should encompass employers' problems or any circumstances beyond (the applicant's) control,'' said John Ishahara, a lawyer for the Legal Aid Society of Hawaii. The case involves federal laws encouraging welfare recipients to work by exempting a portion of their first four months' wages, and a monthly amount of work expenses, from their income eligibility limits. Recipients must file forms with the welfare department by the sixth day of each month stating their job income. Regina Vierra, who has a child, got her first month's pay from a part-time job in October 1987 and was supposed to attach her pay verification to her November welfare eligibility form. But the court said her employer turned down eight requests to provide pay stubs, and Vierra, who could not read well, was not told by her caseworker that she could verify her income without the stubs. After her employer finally provided the stubs, she filed the form one business day late. Under Hawaii's definition of ``good cause'' for lateness, adopted in 1984, the state refused to deduct a portion of her earnings from her income and denied her $198 check for a month because she did not fit the exceptions of illness or mail troubles. She was paid the benefits conditionally, however, while she appealed the decision. Reversing a ruling by U.S. District Judge Harold Fong, the appeals court said Hawaii's restrictive definition of ``good cause'' conflicted with the federal welfare law's goal of ``fostering self-sufficiency and personal independence.'' ``Congress expressly included the `good cause' exemption to provide a shield for innocent late filers,'' said the opinion by Judge Harry Pregerson.

DOC.HEAD: Barenboim Plays Piano on Televised Program
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: The first of this season's ``Live from Lincoln Center'' telecasts was performed Wednesday night by the New York Philharmonic, conducted by Zubin Mehta, with guest pianist Daniel Barenboim. Some classical soloists who have taken up conducting as a serious parallel career find they're better performers when they return to their musical instruments. Barenboim seems to be one of those, playing with more conviction about the music than we remembered from some years ago. Barenboim, who played two concerti, was music director of the Orchestre de Paris from 1975 to 1989 and has been named music director of the Chicago Symphony, beginning next season. He hadn't played piano with the New York Philharmonic since 1984. In his first piece, Beethoven's ``Concerto No. 3 for Piano and Orchestra,'' Barenboim's sound was that of a pianist who cares about the music. He plays with clarity. And he played on the same wave length as the orchestra, merging the piano sound with the orchestra's sound. Soft parts were very beautiful. Some of them were introspective, some bittersweet, some deeply sad but serene not anguished, dignified not maudlin. The concerto was played for its music, not used as a showcase. Tchaikovsky's ``Concerto No. 1 for Piano and Orchestra,'' played after intermission, was more of a showcase for speed and virtuosity. When it began, Barenboim was more subtle and varied in dynamics than some recordings. But Mehta raised the volume and Barenboim began to attack more aggressively. This concerto is written to be a dazzler that the audience can flow along with, one reason it's so popular. But it's even more impressive when some of it softens more than was done Wednesday night. Barenboim had the strength and passion for the furiously fast parts but his playing there seemed to flow less naturally than it had in the quieter parts of the Beethoven. The concert, a pension fund benefit, held in Avery Fisher Hall, began with Weber's ``Oberon Overture.'' This is very sweet at the start and rises to some excitement. Through both moods, the New York Philharmonic's playing was smooth as silk.

DOC.HEAD: New Cancer Test Needs More Study, But Could Bring Low-Cost Early Detection
DOC.TEXT: A researcher says he's developed a simple test that could cost as little as $25 and provide early detection of many cancers, but an American Cancer Society official said Wednesday it may not be specific enough. Stuart Gordon of the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center admits more research is needed, but said results of early experiments, published Monday in the medical journal Cancer Research, are promising. ``This is too small a study to make any absolute statement, but it's enough to make us proceed'' with full-fledged clinical trials, Gordon said. The test, which uses just a few drops of blood, detects a protein that appears to be present at high levels only when normal cells are becoming malignant, he said. The test was 100 percent effective in identifying the protein in the early stages of cancer growth, and was 76 percent effective in identifying late-stage cancers. Dr. John Laszlo, a senior vice president for research at the Atlanta-based American Cancer Society, said the test could be less useful than Gordon thinks, adding it was too early to tell. ``It's like taking your temperature. You don't know from the reading whether you have tuberculosis or you have the flu,'' he said. The test is the result of research Gordon began in 1972, when he set out to find out why cancer patients often have problems with blood clotting. ``It struck me that this meant there was something coming from the cancer cells that activated this clotting,'' he said. Gordon found a protein in the blood of most cancer patients, particularly those in the early stages of their disease. Cancer cells apparently need the protein to reproduce, but its purpose and origins have not been established. ``I think they've made a finding that this particular blood coagulant is abnormal and now we need to know how specific it is and how often people that don't have cancer do have this kind of abnormality,'' Laszlo said. ``You might expect patients with other kinds of diseases to have this kind of protein in their blood.'' Gordon's study involved 128 blood samples, 54 from people with various types of cancers, 20 from patients with benign growths and 54 healthy subjects. Current tests are aimed at specific cancers, but Gordon said his test would detect any type of cancer. Gordon hopes expanded clinical trials will test at least 1,000 people over a two year period. Gordon, a biochemist and associate professor at the University of Colorado School of Medicine, holds a patent on the blood test and is negotiating with several pharmaceutical companies to pay for the massive trials. About 1.5 million Americans are expected to be diagnosed with cancer this year, with more than 500,000 deaths projected, figures show. Gordon said the test, administered in a doctor's office and costing $25 to $40, may be just four years away. ``Today, we are able to do a better job of treating early-stage cancers,'' with early detection significantly improving cancer survival tests, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Metal Chips in Reporter's Body From Old Wound, New Autopsy Finds
DOC.TEXT: A new autopsy on the body of a reporter who died in a car crash last week cast doubt on reports that he and another journalist had been the victims of foul play. Pedro Martinez Guzman, 28, and Jorge Euceda, 38, were found dead near their wrecked car 27 miles east of the capital Friday. Colleagues and relatives asked a human rights group to authorize an autopsy, which revealed the presence of metal fragments in the Martinez Guzman's body. The Roman Catholic Church's legal aid office said bullet fragments lodged in Martinez Guzman's face, causing him to crash the car he was driving. But a second autopsy, ordered by Transit Judge Vicente Serrano, showed the fragments were from an earlier injury, said Coroner Denis Castro Bobadilla. Martinez Guzman was editor of the Salvadoran magazine Semana and correspondent for the respected Mexican magazine Proceso. Euceda was a journalism professor at a local university and a contributor to the newspaper Diario Latino. Serrano said the investigation was continuing. The armed forces press office said Tuesday that four witnesses had reported seeing the reporters' car had being struck by a truck. The reporters were thrown from the vehicle after it overturned, the press office said. The journalists were returning from a reporting trip to eastern El Salvador. In Mexico City, the Association of Foreign Correspondents in Mexico sent a letter to Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani expressing ``profound consternation'' at the deaths. It urged the government to ``do all possible to clarify the circumstances of death and to bring to justice those ultimately responsible.'' At least 40 reporters have died in political violence covering El Salvador's 10-year-old civil war.

DOC.HEAD: Coup Attempts Against President Aquino
With AM-Philippines-Mutiny
DOC.TEXT:
Soldiers seized control of an army base on the southern island of Mindanao on Thursday. Here is a summary of previous coup attempts since President Corazon Aquino took office in Feburary 1986:
Manila Hotel Coup Attempt July 6, 1986 About 100 rebel soldiers led by three generals and hundreds of followers of the late President Ferdinand Marcos occupied the luxury Manila Hotel where they proclaimed Arturo Tolentino, Marcos' running mate in the Feb. 7 snap presidential elections, as president. The rebels surrendered peacefully after occupying the hotel for nearly 40 hours. The government dropped rebellion charges against Tolentino and the rebels after they pledged loyalty to the constitution.
Enrile Attempt Nov. 22 1986 The military under then Chief of Staff Gen. Fidel Ramos aborted a coup attempt dubbed ``God Save the Queen.'' Ramos two weeks earlier ordered all commanders to neutralize a plot by ``military adventurists'' to eliminate leftists in the Aquino government, confirming a newspaper report of a coup plot by disenchanted officers close to Defense Secretary Juan Ponce Enrile. The plot involved removing ``inept and left-leaning'' Cabinet and other government officials and reducing Mrs. Aquino, ``the queen,'' to a figurehead role in government where Enrile would emerge as the real power broker. No arrests were made, but Enrile was removed in a Cabinet shakeup on Nov. 23.
GMA Takeover Jan. 27, 1987 Troops loyal to Marcos seized a television station and raided at least two suburban military bases. One mutineer was killed, and 16 others were wounded in a pre-dawn firefight at the Villamor air base next to the Manila international airport. Rebels also raided the armory of the Philippine navy at Sangley point in Cavite City, 10 miles south of Manila, and took two officers hostage. Rebels at Sangley and Villamor later surrendered. Air Force Col. Oscar Canlas, who led the takeover of GMA 7 station, surrendered after holding out for 61 hours. He was tried by a military tribunal and sentenced to 12 years at hard labor for rebellion.
Black Saturday April 18, 1987 Mutineers led by a pro-Marcos officer stormed the army headquarters at Fort Bonifacio and seized some 50 hostages in a bid to free comrades jailed after the failed January coup attempt. The rebels aired demands for a military takeover of the government, which they claimed was infiltrated by communists. One mutineer was killed and two hostages were injured in a brief firefight. The mutineers surrendered eight hours after their pre-dawn attack.
Honasan Coup Attempt Aug. 28, 1987 Soldiers led by renegade Army Lt. Col. Gregorio ``Gringo'' Honasan attacked the Malacanang presidential palace before dawn but were repulsed by Mrs. Aquino's personal security group. The rebels also tried to seize the armed forces general headquarters in Camp Aguinaldo and seized the government television station and a hotel nearby. The rebellion was crushed less than 24 hours after it was launched. Honasan, a former Enrile aide, escaped, leaving at least 53 dead and more than 300 injured, including Mrs. Aquino's only son.
December Coup Attempt Dec. 1-9, 1989 About 3,000 rebel soldiers launched this coup attempt. Rebel aircraft bombed the Malacanang presidential palace and the armed forces headquarters. Mutineers seized the Villamor air base and the Sangley naval armory. On the first day of the mutiny, U.S. jets provided air cover for loyal troops and turned the tide in favor of the government. Rebel soldiers briefly occupied the government television station but failed to air propaganda. They also seized the Mactan air base in Cebu in the central Philippines. Rebel soldiers, driven out of Fort Bonifacio army headquarters, seized several high-rise apartments and hotels in the nearby financial district of Makati, holding out for five days before they surrendered. The rebellion ended Dec. 9 when the Mactan rebels led by air force Brig. Gen. Jose Commendador surrendered. The fighting killed at least 113 people and wounded more than 600. At least 1,099 soldiers, including 159 officers, have surrendered or been arrested.

Forty-five years after its defeat and dissection, Germany is again one nation, its leaders facing the formidable task of merging two alien systems and promising that this new power dominating Europe will serve peace. Massed before the battle-scarred Reichstag building and awash in floodlights, an estimated 1 million Germans from all walks of life joined at midnight in an emotion-laden chorus of the national anthem. Fireworks lighted up the sky and bells - one of them pealed near the ruins of Hitler's citadel. Schoolchildren hoisted a huge German flag. Eleven months after the Berlin Wall fell in a peaceful revolt that cast aside Communist overlords, the city that symbolized the Cold War division of Europe rejoiced. It is again the capital of a united Germany. ---= NEW YORK (AP) - Secretary of State James A. Baker III says there is growing sentiment among nations to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait and the Bush administration is weighing such a military move through the United Nations. After a week of talking to other world leaders at the United Nations, Baker said Tuesday night: ``There is more of a willingness to consider some sort of an approach like that, if it became necessary at an appropriate time, than we had anticipated there might be at this stage of the conflict.'' But he stressed that sentiments could change quickly, even in one day. And he emphasized the administration prefers a diplomatic and political solution to Iraq's annexation of Kuwait and seizure of the Persian Gulf emirate's oil fields. Baker spoke at the conclusion of a two-day meeting of 35 foreign ministers to prepare for a European Security Conference summit in Paris on Nov. 19-21. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - President Bush wants Americans to convince skittish lawmakers that backing a $500 billion budget package won't cost them re-election, even though it requires taxpayers to shoulder ``a small burden.'' ``I'm not, and I know you're not, a fan of tax increases,'' Bush said in a nationally televised address Tuesday night. ``But if there have to be tax measures, they should allow the economy to grow. They should not turn us back to higher income tax rates, and they should be fair,'' he added, referring to the proposed tax increases on gasoline, cigarettes, boats, liquor and furs. In a third straight day of public and private lobbying for the agreement worked out by his aides and congressional leaders, the president was meeting today with journalists from around the country. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Some Americans may have to choose between heating their homes and buying food this winter as they face soaring fuel costs, a proposed new energy tax and scarce government aid, advocacy groups say. ``We're going back into the `food or fuel' problem of the early '70s for low-income and senior citizens,'' says Edwin Rothschild, an energy specialist at Citizen Action, a consumer and environmental group. The average heating bill of $800 - common in much of the ortheast - will be closer to $1,200 this winter, he predicted. Federal officials said Tuesday that barring a further flareup in the Persian Gulf, there will be more than enough heating oil and natural gas to meet demand this winter. ---= KINGSTON, Mass. (AP) - The search for 13-year-old Melissa Benoit ended in a way that has traumatized this picture-book community: The girl's body was found in the basement of her neighbor, a father of two who had helped look for her. ``I'd rather know that it was just some sicko that grabbed her off the street than someone she trusted,'' said Michelle Ponte, who lives in nearby Plymouth. ``I have a 10-year-old daughter who absolutely freaked out when she heard this.'' The slaying on Main Street hit just about everyone in this town of 8,500, where trees are hung with pink ribbons in Melissa's honor and dozens of people - including the alleged killer - joined the search after she disappeared Sept. 15. Melissa's partially clad body was found last week buried in the basement of Henry Meinholz Jr. He has pleaded innocent to murder. The cause of death has not been determined. ---= LOS ANGELES (AP) - Four people who say a snooty bouncer at a chic nightclub denied them entry and made them feel ``like scum'' because of their unhip clothing are asking a judge to decide whether that's cool under the law. The four argued Tuesday in small claims court that their civil rights were violated. They want damages of $250 apiece. The four - a lawyer, a termite company operator, an accountant and an accounting manager from the San Fernando Valley - said they were rejected by a doorman at the Mayan, a trendy downtown club that used to be a porno theater. Municipal Court Commissioner Diana Wheatley said she would issue a ruling later.

DOC.HEAD: New Fox Series Says Values Distorted in Beverly Hills
DOC.TEXT: In tonight's new Fox show, Brenda, a pretty 16-year-old whose family just moved from Minneapolis to the glittering hamlet of Beverly Hills, is puzzled by what she's seen so far. ``Brandon,'' she asks her twin brother, ``are we going to make it here?'' Brandon has much wisdom. ``The houses are bigger, the weather's warmer, but - doesn't mean they've cracked the meaning of life, y'know what I mean?'' This pretty well sums up the plot of ``Beverly Hills, 90210.'' A new one-hour Thursday series, it originally was called ``Class of Beverly Hills.'' But Fox either realized that today's Beverly Hills has no class or there are too many Southern California high school series on TV. With its decent, wholesome twins played by Jason Priestly and Shannen Doherty, the series concerns the assimilation of a decent, wholesome Midwest family into new and, gosh, almost unreal surroundings. The two co-stars are pretty good actors. But they deserve a medal or something, because the premiere - written by Darren Star, yes, Darren Star - is so stultifying it would get an F even in film school. And it runs 90 minutes. You don't need that much time to prove that shows about vast wealth, shallow people, expensive cars, monstrous mansions, bubbling Jacuzzis and even distorted values mean nothing without Really Bad Dialogue. There is almost no RBD, as we call it in the trade, to goof on here. There only is stilted teen chat and stock teen-age characters, albeit the wealthy kind. Tonight's show concerns doings in the make-believe West Beverly Hills High School, where the new kids in town first meet the pampered offspring of movie and TV stars, tycoons and maybe network presidents. The twins drive an old Chevy compact. Not so their new peers. They drive BMWs, Mercedes and Porsches, and think nothing of sushi for lunch, or Friday night pool parties with rock bands, with the whole school invited. This display of the quiet good taste that is the hallmark of Beverly Hills causes a certain amount of teen-age snobbery and insecurity, of course. But is it all that different from the Midwestern kind? Maybe. Consider Brandon's new girlfriend, a poor little rich kid. The daughter of a rock band manager, she casually says her mother once was a ``major groupie.'' There is some excitement, however, in this clash of Midwestern and Movietown cultures. For example, Brandon declines to make love to his new sweetie as they sit bubbling in her Jacuzzi, even though she enthusiastically suggests it. He contends they haven't known each other long enough: ``I mean, aren't you supposed to hold out on me for a little bit?'' This is soooo intense that she has a florist bring him roses a day later. Right there in Spanish class. Alas, the whole school gets the wrong idea about what's going on, pattly because he doesn't deny anything, not even when a classmate says, ``You must be awesome, dude.'' Brandon now faces a crisis. But sister Brenda isn't doing so well, either. She doctors the birthdate on her driver's license, goes to a night club with new friends, and meets a suave, blonde, 25-year-old lawyer who thinks she is of legal age. He is patient, respectful and understanding when she says ``no'' on the first date. But three dates later, when he's pressing for bedtime, she confesses her dark secret. Boy, does he get cranky. He carries on as if she is not . . . sincere. All this would seem prime fodder for a film about old-fashioned values in Beverly Hills. You could call it ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Conservatives.'' But all we get here is an epic in bland, one in which the twins' parents are only comforting ciphers and most of the wealthy teen-agers are so tame it appears their idea of kicks is a drive-by spending spree. The night's only major crisis consists of Brandon's discovery that a bright, ambitious coed he respects secretly lives in . . . Van Nuys. Wow, Valley Girl! Gnarly! Quel Drag! Near tears, she asks him this: ``Why should I be deprived of a good education because I am geographically undesirable?'' My child, thank your stars you are geographically undesirable. If you continue at West Beverly Hills High, you will wind up going into TV and writing a series with its own ZIP code, like ``Beverly Hills, 90210.'' --- Elsewhere in television... `GRAND' MINUS TWO RETURNS: NBC's ``Grand'' sitcom begins its second NBC season tonight, its residents recovering from an end-of-season tornado in the tiny piano-factory hamlet of Grand. Two characters are gone now, Wayne the cop, and Tom, the husband of Carol Anne, daughter of the town patriarch. The series now will emphasize Carol Anne (Bonnie Hunt) and the chain-smoking, lower-class Janice (Pamela Reed), and a dark secret will be revealed in coming episodes. Will viewers learn who killed Laura Palmer? Nahhh. Besides, who cares? End Adv PM Thurs Oct. 4

DOC.HEAD: Enrollment Triples At Tiny School
DOC.TEXT: Enrollment tripled at the Orton School this fall, but there is no risk of overcrowding. Three students now share the school's single classroom. ``Now I have someone to play with at recess,'' said Levi Tibbs, a fifth-grader who was the school's lone student last year. His playmates are sisters Emily Hansen, a second grader, and Sheri Davis, who is in sixth grade. Their attendance at the 1918 schoolhouse has helped stave off its extinction. ``We considered closing it, but if we did, then we'd have to pay to board those kids in town or we'd have to pay mileage for them to be driven to school and home every day,'' said county school Superintendent Jerry Kleinsasser. And that trip is no quick jaunt. The nearest town is Fort Pierre, a long hour's drive down 50 miles of bumpy, winding road that follows the rugged breaks of the Missouri River. Locals call the area starkly beautiful. Outsiders call it desolate. Winters are harsh and snowy on the Dakota prairie, and the wind almost never stills. ``You can hear the coyotes fighting and jabbering all night long,'' said teacher Steve Pickner, 31, who lives with his dog in a rent-free mobile home on the school site. His nearest neighbors are antelope, grouse and rattlesnakes. Pickner is in his first year as a teacher - he graduated from the University of South Dakota in August - and he has his qualms. ``I'd rather teach 50 kids in one class than three in different grades,'' he said. ``That's 21 separate lessons I have to prepare each night, but it does keep me busy and helps pass the time out here.'' It's hard to get used to the quiet after classes. ``I look forward to Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays when the mail comes,'' Pickner said. Occasionally, he helps mend fences at a nearby ranch that raises one of the nation's largest private buffalo herds. Elementary Principal Elsie Baye says teachers rarely stay more than a year at Orton. ``It's isolated,'' she admits, and the free housing is essential to lure teachers to such a rustic outpost. Still, she persists in putting the best face on it: ``Someone who is an artist or wildlife photographer would just love it there.'' And as for the children, ``It's a great educational opportunity. Our rural kids are usually good students. They get a lot of one-on-one.'' Levi Tibb's mother, Loretta, taught at the Orton School; her husband, Wayne, and their three other children all went there. ``They were almost a year ahead of other students when they got to ninth grade,'' she said. In Orton's classroom - big and bright with three desks in the middle - two students sit together while Pickner tutors the third across the room. An outdated computer sits in one corner; a television set that gets only one channel sits in another. The other classroom fixtures include an aging piano, an ant farm, a water fountain and a microwave oven where the kids and teacher heat their lunches. Once a month, a janitor shows up to shine the linoleum floor. Three times a day, the huge bell atop the freshly painted white building tolls. The bell did not toll this year for the Orton School, but its future is not assured. Stanley County rural schools once were full, but fewer ranch families live in the area, Mrs. Tibbs said. ``They couldn't all make a living here anymore because milking cows and a few acres of land just didn't cut it. People sold out to others, and the remaining ranches got bigger. That cut down on families and kids in the area,'' she said. But Orton is not alone in its tininess. Of the three other rural schools in Stanley County, none has more than eight students. Almost one-fourth of the elementary schools in South Dakota still have only one or two teachers. Legally, schools cannot be closed unless enrollment slips to fewer than five. And neither the kids nor their parents seem inclined abandon the small schools. ``It's funner than a big school,'' said Sheri Davis.
