DOC.HEAD: Another Budget Crisis, Another Deadline Deal
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Another budget, another crisis, another deadline deal - complete with congressional vows that it won't happen this way again. But it always does. That's not the way the job is supposed to be done, and there still is no guarantee that the bargain reached at the brink of budget disaster is going to hold. President Bush urged taxpayers, who soon will be voters, to back the plan, calling it ``the best agreement that can be legislated now'' and saying the alternative is economic chaos. With some Republicans balky, and with public opinion surveys reporting opposition to the tax and spending steps involved, Bush made his appeal Tuesday night in a 10-minute, nationally televised speech. After four months of futility and 10 days of hard bargaining, budget negotiators reached a compromise before the dawn of Monday's deadline, and described the outcome as successful if politically distasteful. But the deal carries its own fine-print concessions of failure. It masks the true size of the projected federal deficit by ruling that some major expenditures simply don't count, and erases ceilings that can't be met. Nevertheless, the five-year, $500 billion plan does make a start at pruning chronic deficits. Without it, the government would be dispatched to chaos by automatic spending cuts under the 1983 deficit control law that was supposed to avoid all this in the first place. Lobbying House Republicans to support the settlement, Bush argued that all the alternatives are worse. He said he had to compromise and they should too. But he doesn't have to run for re-election until 1992, and they're facing the voters in just over a month. This is the sixth time in nine years that Congress and the administration have negotiated budget deals because they can't handle the job the old-fashioned way, in which presidents make proposals and the House and Senate vote on spending and taxes. Because presidents have veto power, that process required compromise and negotiations, but the votes came first. Still, Congress seldom met its own deadlines for action on budget measures, ignoring them because there were no sanctions to enforce them. ``Congress' self-imposed budget deadlines have usually been missed, and massive continuing resolutions and reconciliation bills have been the rule rather than the exception,'' President Reagan said in his final budget message. He said those ``large, cumbersome bills provide cozy hiding places'' for special-interest spending by lumping all the government's money decisions into one giant measure. Reagan had said he wouldn't sign any more of them. Bush had said he wouldn't do business that way, either. ``Government by continuing resolution - or government by crisis - will not do,'' Bush said in his first presidential address to Congress in 1989. The tax and spending provisions that make up the budget compromise of 1990 will go into giant reconciliation bill to be passed before Oct. 20 or else. Without it, the automatic spending cuts will hit. But first, to buy time for that effort, Congress has to pass a budget resolution by midnight tomorrow, the deadline on a five-day extension approved on Sunday. The government also must have an increase in the debt ceiling, which was extended through Friday. Without deadlines, nothing tends to happen. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., likened it to the college student who never studied until the night before finals, then crammed all night. ``He flunked,'' Helms said, ``and the result will be the same. Congress will flunk.'' It has so far. In every previous budget pact, projected deficits have been far lower than the real ones turned out to be. ``They have never once been met,'' said Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y. ``They are wildly below reality.'' The budget pact Bush and Congress negotiated last year forecast a deficit of $99.4 billion, just under the legal limit. The administration now forecasts a deficit of at least $218.5 billion for the budget year that ended Sunday. The deficit ceiling was supposed to be $64 billion this year, but that fiction is gone. Under the new budget agreement, the projected deficit won't be that low until 1995. The target for this budget year has been more than tripled, to a $205 billion deficit. And getting there took a numbers game. Even so, if the deal and the estimates hold, the deficits would start to decline. ``This is real,'' Bush said, as he lobbied fellow Republicans to make it happen. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Ralph Nader Tackles Insurance Industry in New Book
DOC.TEXT: It's a jungle out there for insurance buyers, and unwary consumers sometimes spend too much for too little coverage because they don't know the right questions to ask. Consumer activist Ralph Nader believes the insurance industry would like to keep it that way. ``There is a deliberate gobbledygook that occurs in order to reduce your common-sense defenses,'' he said in a recent interview. Nader also believes a consumer backlash over high rates and confusing policies is erupting nationwide, most notably in California, where voters approved a proposition last year that mandates sharp cuts in auto insurance rates. He says his latest book, ``Winning the Insurance Game,'' should help dispel some of the confusion and better arm those shopping for insurance. The book takes an encyclopedic approach to all the forms of insurance a typical American might encounter, including government programs such as Social Security and Medicare. It explains in plain English the various types of insurance policies, their benefits and their bad points. Nader said he wrote the book along with writer and former attorney Wesley Smith because he believes most consumers are ill-prepared in the insurance marketplace. ``Where would they learn? They don't learn in school about how to buy and what not to buy in the insurance market. Are there consumer training clinics, adult education? No. So they sort of pick up what they pick up through the school of hard knocks, and that's not enough.'' Nader described a number of common mistakes of insurance buyers. Chief among them is not knowing about discounts that are available for the asking. Another mistake is assuming that all insurance companies and insurance agents charge about the same. Smith, who also participated in the interview, told of his own experience in buying auto insurance that shows the value of shopping around. Smith said he went to a number of companies that were the least expensive by reputation. The best rate he found was about $2,900 a year for two cars. ``So I went to another agent who sold from the same carrier who had been in business longer. I said, `Look, I've been offered this insurance but I know this price isn't right because I know based on the reputation of the company that you can do better. He looked at me and he said, `Let me ask you, do you own your own home?' I said, `Yes, I do. Why?' `Because that puts you in a preferred rate.' That saved me 900 bucks a year.'' Nader said other discounts consumers need to ask about include those for airbag-equipped cars and multiple policies in the same family. In addition, he said, many people buy too much auto liability coverage based on the level of their assets that they need to protect. Another problem for many drivers, he said, is ``they don't know to put their best foot forward and get a reduction in price by showing they've got a great driving record.'' With life insurance, a common error is being talked into an investment vehicle attached to the policy that really isn't needed but jacks up the rate, Nader said. Nader and Smith said health insurance may be the most problematic for consumers. ``They tend to buy too many micro policies that should be instead handled by an umbrella policy,'' Nader said. ``Why should you buy a cancer policy? Why should you buy any one of the micro policies that usually are overpriced?'' Another mistake, he said, involves so-called medigap insurance, which supplements Medicare. ``Some elderly people have been known to have five or 10 medigap policies. They keep responding to that celebrity on TV who you saw in a movie 25 years ago.'' Among other mistakes with health insurance is ignorance of what policies exclude, such as eyeglasses, pre-existing conditions and normal pregnancies, Smith and Nader said. But perhaps the biggest problem with individual health insurance is its cost, the two said. ``Individual policies are basically out of the price range of most Americans,'' Smith said. ``So that leaves them with group policies through work. And a lot of people will stay in jobs they loath rather than lose that potential benefit.'' Smith and Nader argue that the only solution to the health insurance problem is a national health insurance plan.

DOC.HEAD: Criticism of the Budget Agreement
DOC.TEXT: The budget agreement reached by negotiators and endorsed by President Bush would depress the economy, seriously slow job growth and in some ways be self-defeating, according to one study making the rounds. Former U.S. Treasury economists who conducted the study said the $500 billion estimate of deficit reduction is badly overstated because negotiators chose to ignore the negative, even recessionary economic impact of higher taxes. The study, for the National Center for Policy Analysis and the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, concludes that in some ways the agreement would contradict its purpose, costing $1.24 in lowered output for every revenue dollar generated. ``Most people are complaining about the new taxes they will have to pay, but the greater burden is the loss of output and lower personal income that will be caused by higher taxes,'' said Gary Robbins, one of the authors. Robbins, former chief of the Treasury's econometric forecasting staff, said the budget negotiators failed to recognize that implementation of the budget would produce a dynamic, largely negative effect. Robbins and his wife, Aldona, former senior economist in the Treasury's office of economic policy, now operate Fiscal Associates, a consulting firm. Their econometric model produced these differences from projections in the budget agreement: - There would be 408,000 fewer jobs by 1995 and almost 520,000 fewer jobs by the year 2000. - Real gross national product, the total of goods and services produced, would be $112.6 billion lower over the next five years, and would be more than $50 billion a year lower than the projections by the end of the decade. - Because tax payments would be lower in a depressed economy, the federal government would receive only 67 cents of each dollar of new taxes it presumes to collect over the next five years. - The deficit reduction would be about $44 billion less than the five-year, $500 billion estimate. The study did agree with the Office of Management and Budget projections, used by budget negotiators, that federal spending would fall as a percentage of gross national product. But it differed in more ways than it agreed. ``Government forecasters assume that the federal government can collect new taxes without causing any economic harm,'' said Gary Robbins. ``Our own forecast is more realistic.'' He said the budget package would worsen an existing recession by imposing new income, payroll and excise taxes in an effort to raise $134 billion of revenues over the next five years. By his estimates, that effort would fail, with new revenues amounting to only $90.2 billion, again because higher taxes would depress economic activity. Over five years, he said, lost output would equal $450 a person. The chamber and the center, which commissioned the study, have been both supporters and critics of administration policies in the past. The center describes itself as a nonpartisian, nonprofit policy research organization. Earlier, analysts at the conservative Heritage Foundation, whose ideas and policies have influenced thinking in the Reagan and Bush administrations, called the budget agreement deplorable. The Heritage analysis, by Daniel Mitchell, a foundation fellow, said the package ``combines the largest first-year tax increase in America's history, dubious economic assumptions, phony spending cuts and inadequate enforcement.'' Mitchell said that at a time when annual economic growth has slowed to a crawl, ``enacting of the agreement surely would throw the nation into recession.''

DOC.HEAD: Excluded Religious Facts Edging Back Into Classrooms
DOC.NOTE: With Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: Teaching moral standards and religious elements of history, generally shunned by public schools in recent decades, seems to be making a sporadic but growing comeback. This is the assessment of specialists in the field who cite accumulating evidence of the shift, which they say is urgently needed to overcome a huge gap in educating the young. The situation ``has been pathetic,'' educator Charles R. Kniker said of the failure of recent decades to teach religion's pervasive historical and social influences. The omission has been documented in numerous studies of textbooks. But the ignored influences and effects of religion gradually and sporadically are being restored, Kniker said. ``It's slow going, but it's a clear phenomenon,'' he said in an interview. ``There's a major growth of interest in academic study about religion in the schools. It's been a wilderness, but certainly changes are going on.'' Kniker, professor of education at Iowa State University and editor of the journal Religion & Public Education, has made a national survey of state policies on teaching about religion and moral values. Results showed a spotty pattern, but indicated developing concern in that field. Since the survey broke new ground, however, prior data was lacking with which to compare the results. ``The main purpose was to get a big snapshot of where we are now in this country,'' a ``base line study to see what is the reality'' so comparisons can be made with it in the future, he said. Thirteen states permit teaching about religion in social studies, while typically prohibiting indoctrincation in a religion's beliefs. As Alabama specifies, it allows ``religious facts only.'' Ten states have school policies on the Bible as literature, some noting that the Supreme Court outlawed systematic or devotional reading of the Bible, but approved ``objective teaching of religion.'' Iowa, for instance, specifies: ``Religious books such astthe Bible, the Torah and the Koran shall not be excluded from any public school . . . nor shall any child be required to read such religious books contrary to the wishes of the child's parent or guardian.'' Twelve states set policies on religion in world history, some calling for units about religion in such courses. ``California legislation requiring textbooks to have greater acknowledgement of the role of religion in history exemplifies a trend gaining much national attention,'' the survey report says. Forty-one states have laws or guidelines on citizenship or character education, and 20 states mention moral-spiritual values. But some indicated that teaching them was taboo, or limited to ``democratic values.'' Kentucky leaves choice about values to school districts, while Ohio and Wisconsin designate the values to be taught. Ohio lists ``compassion, courtesy, tolerance, honesty, self-discipline, self-respect, responsibility, courage, diligence and integrity.'' Wisconsin adds ``personal ethics'' and the ``value of frugality.'' Twenty states allow observance of a moment of silence, none mentioning that the practice replaced school prayer. Recitation in schools of the Pledge of Allegiance is required in 19 states, while many make participation voluntary. Charles C. Haynes of Washington, D.C., president of the National Council on Religion and Public Education, which publishes the journal edited by Kniker, said: ``Changes are coming very rapidly, encouraging more teaching about religion in history and teaching of values. Many districts are adopting new policies . . . The change is quite dramatic. It's now irreversible.'' Haynes, author of a new book, ``Religion in American History, What to Teach and How,'' published by the Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development, noted recent approval by the California State Textbook Commission of a new history textbook published by Houghton Mifflin that covers religious dimensions of history. Haynes said both educators and religious scholars are achieving ``common ground'' about the essential inclusion of teaching about religion, noting recent guidelines about it issued by broad religious-educational coalitions. The consensus ``grew out of a controversial time,'' he said. But now it's generally recognized that teaching about religion is ``good for education, good for students, and more important, good for religious liberty.'' Kniker said expulsion of religious knowledge from schools stemmed from misinterpretations of the 1962-63 Supreme Court decisions banning sponsored prayer and Bible devotionals. Schools and textbook publishers purged virtually any religious reference, fearing controversy, even though the court had said study about religion was essential to education, he said. Kniker said present changes in attitudes resulted from rising evangelical concern and from many studies showing the stark absence of religious facts from classroom versions of history and society. School board and teacher requests for guidance materials have soared, prompting the National Council on Religion and Public Education's distribution center at Iowa State University in Ames to open a telephone service, Kniker said. More than 500,000 copies of the pamphlet ``Religion in the Public School Curriculum, Questions and Answers,'' which was put together by a wide array of educational and religious organizations, have gone to school officials and others.

DOC.HEAD: Toyota Land Cruiser: Redesign Smooths Ride, Profile
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Toyota has taken the edge off its Land Cruiser for 1991, both inside and out. The company's most expensive four-wheel-drive vehicle retains the wide, brutish look of an off-road cruiser, though design changes have softened its profile and smoothed its ride. The squarish front hood is rounded and more aerodynamic. There's full-time four-wheel-drive to reduce vibration and tire wear and help with low-speed steering. For even more traction the center differential can be locked via a dashboard button and the vehicle shifted into low range. Coil springs at all four wheels give a smoother, more car-like ride. And the redesign includes 5 inches added to the wheelbase and 2 to the track, giving the Land Cruiser a longer wheelbase and wider track than either the Range Rover or Jeep's Grand Wagoneer. Toyota kept the 4-liter, six-cylinder powerplant from last year. The fuel-injected engine is rated at 155 horsepower and was paired with the standard four-speed automatic overdrive transmission in the vehicle offered for testing. The package offers enough power for lumbering over ditches and other rough terrain at low speeds, but slow acceleration made it less satisfactory in highway passing. Toyota has not joined Range Rover and Grand Wagoneer in offering an eight-cylinder engine. As with most of the vehicles in this class fuel economy is poor. At more than 4,500 pounds, the Land Cruiser weighs about as much as two Ford Escorts and gets 12 miles per gallon in the city and 14 on the highway. The Toyota got around 11 during a rigorous test outing that sampled a variety of driving conditions. Towing capacity is 3,500 pounds, increasing to 5,000 pounds with the optional towing package. Inside are firm, flat, cloth seats, including a bench seat in the back that splits 50-50 and folds down for extra cargo space. It offered good legroom even with the front bucket seats all the way back. Three good-sized adults can fit in the back, close but comfortable. Another three can fit in the optional third seat, though it's a bit lower to the floor and tighter. This bench seat also splits 50-50 for cargo handling and folds up against the side walls, a good place to keep it when not in use so the headrests don't block the rear-window view. The spare tire was stowed outside the vehicle, beneath the cargo floor. Fit and finish was good on the test vehicle. A newcomer also notices the extra visibility one gets from riding so high, and with that, the usefulness of the handles above each door when climbing in and out. Base price is $21,998. The Grand Wagoneer is about $28,000 and the Range Rover is over $38,000. Consumer Reports magazine did not have a listing of owner complaints on the Land Cruiser.

DOC.HEAD: Morris Dees: Scourge of KKK Sees Shades of Gray
DOC.NOTE: Eds: note Monday reference in 7th graf
DOC.TEXT: Black-and-white. Usually it means plain, explicit, uncomplicated. But in his law office, where the white pages of statute books were blackened by a firebomb, Morris Dees somehow keeps seeing shades of gray. Dees, the founder of the Southern Poverty Law Center and its chief counsel in trials that have destroyed Ku Klux Klan organizations, wants to understand his bitter adversaries - even the ones who've tried to kill him. ``A lot of these people have paranoid personalities bred from basically family problems when they were children,'' he says. ``They're looking for love and affection.'' ``If you look at a Klan roster, just about everybody ... can be an exalted something. It makes them feel important.'' White supremacists chafe at such cool analysis, and at least three racist groups have put Dees at or near the top of their hit lists. A display case in his offices holds charred law books and a melted clock, reminders of the 1983 firebombing by Klansmen. In a case set for trial Monday in Portland, Ore., the 53-year-old white Alabama lawyer is suing an organization called the White Aryan Resistance for allegedly inciting skinheads to fatally beat an African man there. A lawsuit he brought in 1984 in the lynching of a black teen-ager in Mobile, Ala., resulted in a judgment that bankrupted the United Klans of America. The victim's mother, Buelah Mae Donald, received title to the Klan's national headquarters. Dees pursued the case with zeal - and yet he wept, along with others, when one of the killers stood up at the end of the trial and begged Mrs. Donald's forgiveness. ``I just think once you come face-to-face with this person you stalk, and their families ... that's a catharsis that a lot of people go through,'' he said. Morris Dees grew up, blond-haired and blue-eyed, in Alabama cotton country. When asked the source of the righteous anger that seems to underlie the law center, he tells a story of his youth. He was 16 and his father sent him to accompany a tractor driver on the farm, a black man named Clarence, to a court appearance. Clarence had been charged with drunken driving, but Dees believed his story: ``His car had a tie rod come loose and he'd hit a concrete median and knocked himself dizzy.'' The justice of the peace operated out of a store, and during the ``trial,'' Dees said, ``he never quit serving crackers and cheese and Cokes across the counter.'' Guilty was the inevitable ruling. ``The fine was over $100. Clarence didn't have that kind of money,'' Dees said. ``I don't know, that kind of set me on wanting to become a lawyer.'' Dees graduated from the University of Alabama and its law school. While still a student, he set up a lucrative birthday cake delivery service, and later sold books by direct mail. He and a partner sold the business for a reported $6 million. Dees next put his direct-mail skills to work raising millions for George McGovern's Democratic presidential campaign in 1972, then used the mailing lists to appeal for help on his own project, the fledgling Southern Poverty Law Center. The center grew out of ``his determination that there was an enormous gap in legal defense in certain kinds of cases,'' said Julian Bond, a black civil rights leader from Georgia who became the center's first board chairman. What drives Morris Dees? ``A very well-developed sense of outrage,'' said Bond, now a professor and broadcaster in Washington, D.C. ``He knows the legal system can be used to right wrongs.'' The law center, which now has an endowment of $30 million and a $4 million annual budget, has taken on death penalty, voting rights, employment discrimination and other cases, but is best known for hauling the Klan and similar groups into court. Klanwatch, a handful of investigators at the Montgomery law center backed up by informants around the country, produces a bi-monthly ``Intelligence Report'' on hate group activities, which is sent to 4,000 police agencies. White robes reflected by a fiery cross, the fear reflected on black faces in the night, in the ``Intelligence Report'' these stark events are reduced to column upon column of statistics, names and dates. Black-and-white becomes gray again. ``It appears to be good solid information,'' said Lt. Robert McCulley of the Memphis, Tenn., police. ``Information is hard to come by. You don't go into a bookstore and walk to the section labeled `Terrorism.' '' To enter the Southern Poverty Law Center, a visitor climbs steps walled with stone past a granite monument to civil rights martyrs. The front door is unlocked electronically and, inside, a receptionist sits at a video security system. ``It's a necessary bunker,'' Bond said. ``If you do this work from the safety of New York City, it's one thing. But if you're right in the heart of the beast, a sensible person takes precautions.'' And Dees does. He varies his route and schedule to and from work. He avoids alleys. ``Demon Dees!'' Louis Beam, a Texas neo-Nazi, once shouted during questioning by his nemesis in one case. Beam challenged Dees to a duel. Exorcising the demon with a simple gunshot apparently was not enough for members of The Order, which murdered Denver talk show host Alan Berg. ``The preliminary plan called for kidnapping Dees, interrogating him, then flaying him - peeling his skin off his body - before killing him,'' wrote Kevin Flynn and Gary Gerhardt in their book, ``The Silent Brotherhood.'' In an otherwise even-toned interview, the only strong profanity came when the soft-spoken Dees was asked if he doesn't expect one day to become another name on the law center's memorial. ``Man, I don't want to be a martyr to anybody's (expletive) cause,'' he said. ``I didn't get into this thing for a cause.'' The law center began with a variety of suits: challenging unhealthy working conditions in textile plants, representing death row inmates and others. Dees first went up against the white supremacists in 1979, agreeing to represent a black marcher attacked during a peaceful demonstration in Decatur, Ala. Clubbed by KKK counterdemonstrators, the man tried to defend himself with a registered gun, Dees said. An all-white jury convicted him. Dees thought back to Clarence, and his day in court: ``Nothing had really changed.'' But it was about to. He filed a civil lawsuit against the Klansmen. Evidence uncovered by Klanwatch led to federal indictments against 10 Klansmen, and the suit ended in a settlement that, among other things, required the whites to attend a race relations class. The class was taught earlier this year by the Rev. Joseph Lowery of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, who is black. ``One of the Klansmen,'' Dees said, ``the day of the demonstration he had a club in his hand ... Eleven years later, he's standing there holding hands with Dr. Lowery in a prayer. ``And saying, `Maybe I was misguided back then, and we could have solved our problems in a different way.' '' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Christopher Sullivan is the AP's Southeast regional reporter, based in Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: Free-Speech Claim in Skinhead Case Called `Baloney'; ACLU Monitoring
With AM-Klan's Nemesis
DOC.TEXT: A white supremacist accused in a lawsuit of inciting skinheads to commit a racially motivated killing in Portland, Ore., says he was merely exercising his First Amendment rights. The suit, which seeks damages from the group White Aryan Resistance, or WAR, and four individuals, is merely ``a roundabout way of cutting off freedom of speech, freedom of association and even freedom of assembly,'' said Tom Metzger, the organization's leader and a defendant. The Oregon office of the American Civil Liberties Union plans to monitor the trial, set to begin Monday in Portland. Plaintiff's lawyer Morris Dees calls Metzger's claims ``baloney.'' The civil case follows the criminal conviction of three skinheads in the 1988 beating death of Mulugeta Seraw, a 27-year-old Ethiopian who was living and working in Portland. Seraw's skull was fractured with a baseball bat. Dees' Montgomery, Ala.-based Southern Poverty Law Center sued on behalf of Seraw's estate. In the past, the center has won millions in judgments by suing hate groups and their leaders, arguing that they are responsible for damage and injuries done at their behest, just as a corporation can be held liable for employees' actions. The suit contends Metzger and his son John have recruited skinheads to WAR in recent years, and that through agents they sent to Portland, they provided a skinhead group called East Side White Pride with racist materials promoting violence against blacks and Jews. Seraw's killers were members of East Side White Pride. Further, the suit - which was joined by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith - claims WAR agents were in contact with the Metzgers in Fallbrook, Calif., met with the skinheads and encouraged them to harm blacks. ``The allegations of personal involvement ... are totally nonsense,'' Metzger said. ``It's something that Mr. Dees has dreamed up.'' Dees said he has letters and phone records linking the Metzgers and their ``agents'' in Portland, as well as ``a damning affidavit.'' In it, one of the agents, Michael Barrett, tells of taking five baseball bats to Portland, of keeping close contact with the Metzgers, and of meeting with East Side White Pride skinheads. ``We told them to use violence if they got an opportunity, and to be sure and beat the hell out of the enemy,'' Barrett said in the affidavit. ``We were telling them what Tom and John Metzger told us to say.''

DOC.HEAD: 30 Years in TV Shadows: Jerry Van Dyke Has First Success in ABC's `Coach'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Until ABC's ``Coach,'' Jerry Van Dyke was often in the game but never on a winning team, unable to emerge from a 30-year shadow cast by his successful brother, Dick Van Dyke. The fame he did achieve was dubious: as the star of one of the most ridiculed failures in the history of television, ``My Mother the Car.'' ``If I waited for something good to come along, I'd never work,'' Van Dyke said. ``When people talk about bad television, `My Mother the Car' is the show that pops to mind. There have been worse shows, but that's the one people remember.'' It was in 1965, while the ``The Dick Van Dyke Show'' remained one of TV's biggest hits, that Jerry Van Dyke got his first series, with Ann Sothern as the voice of the mother-car. ``I'd just turned down `Gilligan's Island' because I thought it was ridiculous,'' he recalled. He went on to three other series failures: ``Accidental Family,'' ``The Headmaster'' and ``13 Queens Boulevard.'' Meanwhile, his older brother won six Emmys and TV immortality. ``I have an act I take on the road,'' Jerry Van Dyke said. ``That's what saved me. I don't know how most actors make a living.'' Van Dyke said the part of the handyman in the now-defunct comedy series ``Newhart'' was written for him, but CBS nixed the deal. But his persistence finally is paying off. He was nominated this year for an Emmy as best supporting actor in a comedy series for his role as Luther Van Dam, the befuddled assistant to Craig T. Nelson in ``Coach.'' Although he didn't win, the nomination was a boost. ``The Emmy nomination did a world of good for my confidence,'' he said. ``I've always known I was good, but if other people don't think so, it can hurt your confidence. ``It was a matter of not only being not successful but being in my brother's shadow. He had one of the best shows on television, and I had to compete with that. It hurt my career. I made my TV debut on his show, and it did me a whole lot of good. It got me in the public eye, and CBS signed me. But when I failed to produce, it hurt me. Then I stayed Dick Van Dyke's brother. I always knew if I had some success that I'd no longer be thought of as Dick Van Dyke's brother.'' It was thought for a while that Dick Van Dyke would make an appearance in a two-part ``Coach'' episode as brother Luther hasn't seen for 30 years. But the role may be changed to that of a former best friend. The part of Luther was created for Van Dyke by writer-producer Barry Kemp, who also created ``Newhart.'' Van Dyke had discovered Kemp in Phoenix and supported and encouraged him until he became a writer for ``Taxi.'' He met Kemp during what he calls a ``really bad period of my life and career'' 10 or 12 years ago. ``I was divorced,'' he said. ``I didn't have anything. My career was shot. I was working in joints. This kid came to me and said he was a writer.'' He liked Kemp's material so much that he put him up at his home in Los Angeles and paid him a salary. Although Luther in ``Coach'' was written for him, Van Dyke still had to bring the character to life. ``When you start on a show, where do you find a character?'' he said. ``You don't know where he's going to go. He's the world's most negative man, but that doesn't make a character. In some ways, he's comparable to me. We're the same age, his life is very similar to mine. Luther says, `I never got married because I was afraid of getting divorced. I never became head coach because I was afraid of losing.' ``He has no relationships. He lives with a bird. He doesn't want to make any waves. He likes the status quo. He has a cloud over his head. Yet, in his own little world, he's happy-go-lucky.'' Van Dyke's career began during four years as an entertainer in the Air Force. He won ``The All Air Force Talent Show'' twice, which led to two appearances on ``The Ed Sullivan Show.'' His live act has earned him headliner status in Las Vegas, Reno, Lake Tahoe and Atlantic City, and he also has appeared in a number of movies and the humorous miniseries ``Fresno.'' When he's not working, he and his family live on a 500-acre farm in Arkansas.

DOC.HEAD: Reservists' Families Face Financial, Emotional Upheaval
DOC.TEXT: As U.S. reservists ship out for the unknown in the Saudi desert, the families left behind struggle with uncertainties of their own. How to put food on the table. How to pay medical bills and mortgages. How to be a single parent or a surrogate one. Saddam Hussein and the Persian Gulf are worlds away, but for these families the upheaval in the Middle East has hit very close to home. ---

While Charles Fells serves his country, his pregnant wife, Linda, is at war with the system. Pvt. 1 Fells, 23, of the 423rd medical detachment, is training at Fort Drum, N.Y., and will ship out to Saudi Arabia any day. Last month, Fells lost his job as a food service manager when a hotel restaurant closed. Shortly after he left home, the Poughkeepsie couple's suspicions were confirmed: Mrs. Fells, 25, already the mother of 15-month-old David, was two months' pregnant. In financial trouble and lacking health insurance, Mrs. Fells looked to the government for help. She's still looking. Her days are spent being shunted from one military bureaucracy to another: wondering what benefits she's entitled to, what forms to fill out, where to get prenatal care, where to take her son in a medical emergency. ``I've been on the phone, all day and all night, for days now. It's not accomplishing anything: just making me feel sicker and sicker,'' Mrs. Fells said. ``They keep telling me they're going to help me, but I haven't gotten any, yet.'' An army hospital told her many of its doctors had been activated and there was no one left to see her. Private hospitals and clinics demanded hundreds of dollars up front because she has no insurance. ``I can't sleep at night; I'm really upset,'' Mrs. Fells said. ``I've been dizzy every day. I'm worried about the baby: worried that, because of my nerves, something's going to go wrong.'' ---

Jay Black recalls the day he felt he'd become a casualty of the Persian Gulf conflict. It was three or four weeks ago; Black is too harried these days to remember exact dates, or how much he's been through. ``I've yelled and screamed and cried more in the past few weeks than I can remember,'' Black said. On the day in question, he returned from the grocery store to find his year-old son, Billy, and the contents of the refrigerator on the kitchen floor. His wife, Sgt. Amy Durand-Black, home on a weekend furlough from Army reserve duty in Augusta, Ga., was in the bathroom throwing up, felled by the flu. It was supposed to have been a special weekend, one of the couple's last together before Mrs. Durand-Black, 27, left for reserve duty at a California medical clinic. Almost overnight, Black, 29, has become a single parent forced to live without his wife - the family's main breadwinner, a manager at an Atlanta theater company - on a budget that could not cover the rent and mounting bills. As a result, he's had to leave the small home he and his wife rented for $385 a month and move with his son and the family dog, Flash, to his grandparents' house in Rome, Ga. What used to be a 15-minute drive to his bookkeeping job at the same theater company is now a 120-mile roundtrip commute every day. ``I've seen my whole marriage flash before my eyes. All my belongings are now in a 10-by-10 storage cubicle,'' Black said. ``My feelings have run the gamut from patriotism to hatred of the Army.'' Black said he has become adept at juggling his creditors, telling them, ``My wife was activated, and I'm sunk.'' As Black tries to deal with the fact that his wife could be gone for several years, he and Billy are relying on friends to help them cope. ``I've got some wonderful friends who I've leaned on very heavily,'' Black said. ``I know I'm a terrible imposition on everyone. I guess my friends feel like they're doing their part for the war effort.'' ---

Patsy Bell and her family live paycheck to paycheck. Now that her husband has been called to active duty in the Persian Gulf, the paychecks have stopped. ``It'll be December or January until we get our checks from the Army,'' said Ms. Bell, 28, mother of 2-year-old Kathy. ``We had $145 left after he bought everything with his last paycheck. We don't have any savings. Most of the money would go to our bills and diapers and milk.'' Sgt. Frank Bell was among 141 reservists of the Las Cruces, N.M.-based 281st Transportation Company called up Sept. 20. For his wife, adjusting to life as the head of her household is frightening. Her husband, an elementary school teacher in nearby Lordsburg, has always paid the bills and handled any problems at home. ``We'll make do with what we have and do without what we can't afford. In the long run, we'll have to apply for food stamps,'' she said. Bell's orders were for 90 days, but Ms. Bell, like many reservists' wives in this mining community of 10,000, is preparing for the long haul. ``I called up to the welfare office to see if they could help me find a job,'' she said. ``I've been trying to look for a job, but as a secretary, most of the money would go for babysitting and gas. So I wouldn't be left with much of anything.''

Virginia Brock lies awake nights worrying about her sonsday at $5.74 a share, down from $9.42 last month and $12.33 earlier this year. The fall has erased more than $1.66 billion of the company's market value and led the Australian Stock Exchange to open an inquiry. News Corp. told the exchange Tuesday it did not know the reason for the decline. Murdoch said the mergers would eliminate some production jobs but the alternative was to close both the Daily Mirror and The Herald. The new 24-hour editions, publishing Monday through Saturday with editions at 10:30 p.m., 1 a.m., noon and 3 p.m., are expected to start next Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Foor release Sunday, Oct 7, and thereafter
Children Speak From the Heart About Missing Mom and Dad
With BC-Gulf-Families At Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Spellings in quotes are cq
DOC.TEXT: The children of soldiers do battle on the homefront with the heartbreak of separation, the longing for an absent parent's arms and the fear that Daddy or Mommy might never return. When they write about their feelings at having parents leave for possible war in the Persian Gulf, pain rises from the paper like heat from the desert. Such small voices; such big fear. ``I'm afraid for my Dad,'' writes Natalie, 9. ``I want him to come home. I always wonder what Dad's thinking. Is he thinking about me? Or is he thinking about war? Will he be safe? Or will he be slain? These things puzzle me. ``On the outside, I laugh at the jokes made about Housein. On the inside, I feel like crying. My eyes fill with tears when anyone mentions my father. Is the weather horrible? Or is it livable? I just want Dad home and to forget abou the gulf crises.'' ``I hope they don't have to fight,'' 7-year-old Justin writes. ``If they do fight, I hope my Dad dos'nt get killed. I have two brothers that miss him too.'' Natalie, Justin and 15 other kids at Bartow Elementary School in Savannah, Ga., have joined the ``Hero Club'' formed by counselor Mac Merritt to help them cope. Their writings are part of a club exercise. ``They're good at hiding their feelings. But the more we talk, the more they talk,'' Merritt said. In these little lives, there is much to work through, he has found. ``I'm afraid that my Dad might die,'' Stephen, 9, worries. ``I wish he was home. I hope he survives.'' ``I would like for them to have more food & water,'' Narria, 10, writes. ``I would not like my father to get killed. I wouldn't like my father to get very sick.'' ``I am worried about if war breaks out and gun fireing starts. What kind of food is he eating? I would like for them to have more water in Saudi Arabia,'' Valerie, 9, writes. Then an afterthought, above a drawing of an army vehicle baking under no fewer than eight suns: ``It seems like there is alot of suns over there in Saudi Arabia as hot as it is there.'' Darin, 6, worries that his father is worried, and offers reassurance: ``We are okay Love Darin I have not got sent to prinsipal.'' In his picture, his father parachutes from a plane into the desert. ``Dear Dad, How are you doing? How is the food down there? Have you shot guns any?'' Danielle, 9, writes. ``I wish you wouldnt.'' In her drawing, a smiling sun hovers over her dad. A smiling man with a gun shoots at a target in 7-year-old Larry's drawing. ``I wish my dad will not git killid,'' he writes. ``I hope he is okay,'' 6-year-old Sara writes. ``Wat is he doing? Wy do they have to do this? I am wanting them to stop evreythag.'' Below her words, Sara drew a blazing sun, a wolf, and her Dad in desert fatigues. ``Sometimes I wonder,'' reads the balloon above his head. When anxiety and fear become overwhelming, they spill out on the paper as hatred and violence. ``Powerful fright feelings,'' Merritt calls them. ``I hate the irookys because they toke over Kuwait. My father is over there. I hate Sudam Hussian, because he started all this by getting into Kuwait,'' Jason, 7, writes. Chris, 10, draws a picture of a man with a knife protruding from his stomach. ``Suddam Hussien'' reads the label above the man's head. ``Blood'' is labeled and marked with an arrow. ``Every day I wonder when my dad is coming home. I also wonder if Saddam Hussien is crazy enough to kill himself. I wish he wolld,'' Chris writes. ``I HATE SADOM HUSSIAM!'' 10-year-old Jamia prints in capital letters across the top of her paper. Below that, in still bigger print: ``I LOVE MY FATHER!''

DOC.HEAD: Center Helps Reserve Families in Crisis
With BC-Gulf-Families at Home
DOC.TEXT: Help is a phone call away for the thousands of women, men and children who become instant military dependents in the Persian Gulf crisis. More than 700 callers a month get advice at the Family Support Operations Center at Fort Totten, Queens, home of the nation's largest Army reserve command. The 77th Army Reserve Command serves 14,000 soldiers and their families; 334 of them have been activated. But the center will try to help callers from anywhere - even from other military branches. Its toll-free number, good in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, ``is a lifesaver; a lot of these people can't afford a long-distance phone call,'' said Paul M. Silverman, a civilian who is family support coordinator. Sgt. Mary Lou Bohrnmann, a reserve spokeswoman, said most of the callers need quick advice or commiseration. About 5 percent are overwhelmed; a few call four or five times a day to hear a reassuring, friendly voice. ``They're worried about keeping a roof over their head or money to pay for food,'' said Sgt. 1st Class Patricia Payne. ``They get kind of panicky,'' said Master Sgt. George Frangos. Most callers find out about the center from commanding officers or other military families. An information packet also is mailed automatically when a soldier is activated. Payne, Frangos, and Silverman - aided by six to 10 volunteers, plus, on weekends, seven or eight non-active reservists - guide neophytes through the military bureaucracy. They'll explain benefits. They'll help when a departing soldier forgets to sign a check or a power-of-attorney form. They'll sic lawyers on an unyielding bank that refuses to lower a reservist's mortgage rate or a landlord who threatens to evict a suddenly strapped family. They'll send a financial planner to help the spouse who, until now, never wrote the checks. They can even obtain a one-day, emergency food supply - although no one has asked for it, so far. And when the stress builds up, the staff tells soldiers and their families they're not alone. ``One soldier was going off, he was 21 or 22. I felt so sorry for the young man. He was scared to death,'' said Payne. He confided that he planned to spend his last night of freedom with his buddies. Payne, concerned about his panic, urged him to spend the night with his mother. ``I usually don't take the problems home. But I saw my son in him,'' said Payne. ``I called him at 10 o'clock that night. His mom answered. He said, 'I stayed home because I had a feeling you would be checking up on me.''' Payne, a widow with five grandchildren and three children, relates to her callers. Before she was activated, she worked at a bank to support herself and her youngest son, who's a senior in college. Now, they're struggling to make ends meet. ``We had scraped up every penny to put him through college. He called me and said, `Ma, should I come back home?''' But she wouldn't hear of it. ``I can help everybody's problems here,'' said Payne. ``But when I go home, I can't help mine.'' ``This has made us all more aware of our responsibilities, too,'' she said. ``There are certain things we have to get in order.'' --- Eds: Phone numbers for the Family Support Operations Center are 800-421-2884 in New York, New Jersey or Connecticut, 718-352-5734 elsewhere.

EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The writer, an Associated Press editor who has visited and reported from the Soviet Union for 20 years, participated in a recent trip to that nation by the Board of Directors of The Associated Press.

A decade ago, Moscow was a city of boasts, of sure-fire government plans, of blithe assertions that the Soviet Union would lead the world to a better society. Today, it is a city of cynicism, sometimes of despair. Talk is of just getting through the winter, of keeping bare necessities on store shelves, of somehow reforming a strangled economy before it collapses into chaos. Recent meetings with top Soviet officials and a wide range of workers, farmers and professionals suggest a darkening national mood that takes little account of the country's enduring assets. From gilded Kremlin reception rooms to angry street demonstrations, there is little mention of the nation's rich natural resources, its literate and educated workers, its high technology and huge internal market. All could be important engines of perestroika, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to revive the economy. Instead, Soviets point with growing alarm to shortages of food and almost everything else, and the absence of any serious sign that things will improve soon. Life is hard as winter approaches. Despite the theoretical promise of perestroika, prosperity seems far away. --- The display cases are almost bare in the small, poorly lighted food store on Tverskaya Street, one of Moscow's busiest avenues. Today, the store is rationing bread: one kilogram (2.2 pounds) per customer. An elderly man, profiting from the new freedom of speech, accosts a group of American visitors: ``It's the Communist Party that's responsible for all of this! Look at the empty shelves!'' Muscovites say milk is still plentiful in state stores, but that finding anything else is a roll of the dice. The severe bread shortages of a few weeks ago are over, but decent meat and many vegetables are rare. In the cavernous GUM department store on Red Square, many stalls once crowded with goods are closed off by metal grates. The goods may have been shoddy five years ago, but at least they were there. Such shortages are common throughout the country. ``Actually, we spend a lot less time waiting in line these days,'' said a woman in Leningrad, Russia's second-largest city. ``Now there's nothing to buy, so we just stay home.'' --- Nikolai Petrakov, one of Gorbachev's top political advisers, puts it point-blank: ``The economy, to all intents and purposes, has ceased to exist.'' The declaration seems somewhat melodramatic. Outside the window is not an arid plain, but a cacophony of trucks and buses. Hurrying workers and shoppers compete for space on the rainy sidewalks. Petrakov thinks he knows what the future looks like. The government will make a start on economic revival with its much-debated 500-day plan, Petrakov says, and predicts the transition to a Western-style market economy will be complete in 10 years. Others dwell more on the problems. Alexander Yakovlev, a senior Gorbachev aide, admits readily that reforming the Soviet system is far harder than he imagined. He says it's fine to plan things like a modern real estate market and effective banks, but how to do it in a country where no one knows what land prices should be and only ``two to three people'' really understand the Western banking and credit system? Many people ask how authorities will persuade frightened, conservative bureaucrats to give innovators the chance to make money in new ways and resuscitate the economy in the process. --- At the Ray of Lenin collective farm outside Moscow, the chairman granted that Soviet agriculture is less productive than U.S. farms. He sees the solution in importing American experts and studying U.S. methods. He opposes abolishing the whole concept of collective farms, the Soviet system in which families join in tilling land they do not own and receive wages in proportion to their work. Later, in his neat cottage, one of the farmers expressed very different ideas. People will work really hard only if they own their land, he said. He said he tried to talk the farm chairman, in the spirit of perestroika, into one little innovation: leasing him one of the collective farm's greenhouses. If he could make it more productive, the farmer said, he would earn extra money for his family and the farm could learn somethinge techniques. The chairman about greenhoussaid no. --- Gorbachev's policy of glasnost has brought breathtaking changes to politics. Street-corner orators denounce one politician or another as policemen stroll by unconcerned. Gorbachev and his ministers must defend themselves before angry legislators who want to know everything, from what personal privileges the leaders enjoy to how they will reform the economy. This looks at first like robust democracy. But some Soviets see the whole affair, especially the raucous parliament debates televised nationwide, as something else: another cooked-up-in-the-Kremlin plan to create the illusion of progress while the hopes of consumers are put on hold again. People have learned to watch carefully, y takeover. To many observers, including some Western diplomats, the most likely outcome is far less sensational: a slow, painful road to a market economy, pocked with problems but as inevitable as the laws of supply and demand. Everyone agrees time is of the essence. With every delay, rumors spread, resolve weakens and fear of anarchy mounts. Anarchists have a long history in Russia, and fear of chaos and the collapse of authority are widespread. --- In a light rain, as sunset nears, 60,000 people march just outside Red Square. They hold banners demanding the dismissal of Gorbachev's prime minister, Nikolai Ryzhkov, for economic incompetence. A woman whose sign reads ``Down With Soviet Power'' says reform must be speedy. ``Something must be done!'' she cries. ``Ryzhkov can't cope. In the United States, if the government ever faced anything like this, it would have to commit suicide.'' Behind her, another group marches in ominous silence, under the black flag of anarchists.

DOC.HEAD: TVIEW: PBS To Begin New Streamlined Era
DOC.TEXT: The audience is down, the competition from cable is rising. Despite the heady success of ``The Civil War'' series, PBS has its problems, but it also has a plan to deal with them. Public television has appointed its first programming mogul, responsible for picking the shows, scheduling them and promoting them. Take a meeting, Big Bird. Jennifer Lawson, the chief program executive, will be able to give faster answers to program proposals, speeding up what has been a cumbersome decision-making process, a PBS board member says. Producers of cultural and entertainment shows who would have gone to PBS in past years now have cable networks as a market for their wares, particularly the Arts & Entertainment and Discovery networks. ``There are now so many more people looking for good programs that we're not the only opportunity that people have, as we used to be,'' says the board member, Henry P. Becton Jr., president of WGBH-TV in Boston. ``We need to be able to be more responsive, to give quicker and more definitive answers, to take more risks in order to have access to the best people and ideas.'' He said it's likely the board, meeting next month, will approve the final step in the plan that shifts $105.5 million from various sources to a single program and promotion fund administered by Lawson, PBS' executive vice president for national programming and promotion. That will complete the process by which she has become the PBS equivalent of moguls like NBC's Brandon Tartikoff - in charge of program selection, scheduling and promotion. In olden days, public TV stations chose and helped pay for about half of the national prime-time schedule through a voting process run by PBS' Station Program Cooperative. Come November, that process will be history. Although Lawson will pick programs, she will consult a committee that includes PBS and public TV station executives and, in some cases, minority and independent producers, she says. ``It will not be me making decisions in a vacuum,'' she says. Lawson, who has spoken of experimenting with educational game shows and bringing more children's programs to public TV, says the full impact of the change probably won't be felt until the 1992-93 season. That's because many program projects now on the boards have been funded for this season and the next, although next season's schedule will give an idea of what's to come, she says. But the new system will allow better focus and planning, she says: ``It helps us move faster and it helps us move with more intelligence. Before, with the (program cooperative) marketplace, the process itself made the decisions. ``It was a voting on a series of programs without putting them in any context and looking at what that does to shape our profile. The new system helps us react faster to changes in the media environment.'' It's ``no secret whatsover'' that PBS ratings have fallen off, she says, even though 24-city ratings for ``The Civil War'' - national ratings are due this week - averaged a 9.1, the highest in PBS' history. The network's overall ratings dropped 3 percent in just the past year. When trying to lure viewers back, it sometimes pays to advertise. Lawson, wearing her program executive's hat, did that last month. PBS followed its ``Civil War'' telecasts with a one-week, $2 million ``Showcase Week'' advertising campaign on the commercial networks and cable TV, touting PBS' fall schedule of programs. The Sept. 30-Oct. 6 campaign, plugging such series as ``Masterpiece Theatre,'' ``The American Experience'' and ``Live From Lincoln Center,'' wasn't a first for PBS, Lawson said: ``Some years ago, the Ford Foundation did provide some funds for some limited advertising,'' she said. But the new campaign was PBS' first in at least a decade, she said, and was ordered up ``because we really want to do as much as we can with our resources to highlight what we're doing, and make it as visible as possible.'' PBS does a lot of show-promotion on its own 338 stations, she notes, ``but we feel we're preaching to the converted. We want to go beyond that and bring new people in.'' Another sign of changing times at PBS: It may take a leaf from ABC and NBC and become co-owner of a cable service. It's studying the idea of starting a separate educational cable service with the Discovery Channel, which serves 52.1 million homes. But the main event at PBS now is its shift to a program ``czar.'' And that hasn't occurred without sounds of alarm from public TV executives who worry that too much power is going into one person's hands. One of the chief worriers, William F. Baker, is president of WNET-TV in New York. His station has been a major producer of national shows, among them ``The MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour,'' ``Nature'' and ``Great Performances.'' He wouldn't want a return to the old program-picking system, ``not at all ... the old system was cumbersome, and we're happy to do away with it.'' But he's concerned, he says, that with the new system ``you have the risk of having a kind of common central taste.'' And that the system may not take into account the complexities of getting funding for programs. Baker, a PBS board member, says what he worries most about ``is that big producing stations, such as WNET, have millions of dollars committed in advance to create these programs, and if PBS doesn't help support those things we've already committed to, they could literally destroy the major producing entities. ``You just don't make these big shows, commit to them today and make them tomorrow. And that's one of our biggest concerns. It can be very destructive unless that is realized. ``There are some indications that they (PBS officials) understand that, and will realize it. But that's one of our biggest worries. And that, frankly, is my primary worry.'' WGBH's Becton, whose station produces nearly a third of PBS' prime-time series, among them ``Masterpiece Theater'' and ``Nova,'' admits to having early reservations about the centralization of program-picking power at PBS. Unlike Baker, though, his concerns aren't couched in terms of potential doom. Far from it. He said he's been working to ``make sure we had some safeguards, some checks and balances in this new system. I'm now pretty satisfied they're in place, and it's a good plan. I'm quite enthusiastic about it.'' PBS needs that centralized power now, he adds: ``We need to be able to make quicker decisions (for program producers and stations). We need to be able to fund things that are a little more adventurous, if you will. ``The old system was good at approving programs that pleased a lot of people a little bit, but not so good at finding a program that might have been more unique, had more of an individual vision, or whatever. ``And I think we need more of that at this point.''

DOC.TEXT: Oil prices took another steep dive on the futures market, falling more than $3 per barrel as concerns about war and supply problems dissipated. ``The so-called war premium is being eaten away,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Contracts for November delivery of light sweet crude oil closed $3.14 lower at $33.95 Tuesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Crude contracts for later months all dropped, most by $1.50 per barrel, their maximum limit for the day. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - State energy officials and industry representatives were told there are adequate supplies of heating oil for this winter, but some worried about possible shortages if there is a glitch in the system or increased tensions in the Mideast. ``We don't think there is going to be a supply problem this winter,'' Calvin Kemp, director of the Energy Information Administration, said Tuesday at a conference on this winter's fuel outlook. But officials cautioned that the supply picture could change. --- TOKYO (AP) - A government support package helped propel Tokyo stocks to their biggest one-day jump in history but left uncertain prospects for an extended rebound from the worst market decline in more than 30 years. The closely watched Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues leaped 2,676.55 points, or 13.24 percent, to 22,898.41 on Tuesday after the Ministry of Finance announced emergency measures to shore up the ailing market. In the morning half of today's trading, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues added 331.16 points, or 1.45 percent, to 23,229.57. --- NEW YORK (AP) - After four years of investigation and innuendo, federal allegations of rampant lawbreaking by junk bond financier Michael Milken will be aired publicly for the first time at a special hearing beginning next week. U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood ordered the unusual proceeding Tuesday after lawyers for Milken and the government failed to agree on a way to avoid further delays in sentencing the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. executive. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Sales of new homes fell 1.4 percent in August, the government said. In response to Tuesday's report from the Commerce Department, analysts said sales would have fallen further but for buyers who signed contracts before the effects of the Persian Gulf crisis were felt. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Farmers should prepare themselves for lower target prices, as Congress looks for ways to cut the agriculture budget by $13 billion over the next five years, farm organization officials say. Government officials said that the cuts would be painful, although no one could give details yet on how the cut agreed to by White House and congressional negotiators to reduce the deficit would be accomplished. --- SEATTLE (AP) - In the eyes of corporate executives, Seattle, the Northwest's biggest city is the best place in the nation to locate a business, elbowing out Atlanta for the top spot. Seattle had finished second last year behind Atlanta in the annual survey by the commercial real estate firm Cushman & Wakefield. Atlanta dropped to sixth this year. Second place in this year's survey went to Sacramento, Calif., which was 15th last year, while Portland, Ore., moved up from 27th place to third. Rounding out the top 10 were Norfolk, Va.; San Diego; Atlanta; Columbus, Ohio; Dallas-Fort Worth; Minneapolis-St. Paul; and Tampa, Fla. --- TAMPA, Fla. (AP) - A manufacturer of the Army's main tactical field radio was ordered to pay $3.8 million for conspiring to defraud the government on defense contracts by falsifying reliability test results. E-Systems Inc. of Dallas received the sentence Tuesday from U.S. District Judge William Terrell Hodges after formally pleading guilty to a three-count criminal information. Prosecutors charged the company repeatedly altered performance records and concealed repairs and defects in tests of the field radios to ensure the Army would accept and pay for them. --- NEW YORK (AP) - American troops in the Middle East are getting some free cigarettes courtesy of two tobacco companies, but smoking critics are denouncing the giveaways as a ploy to hook a new generation of soldiers. Philip Morris U.S.A., the nation's leading cigarette maker, said Tuesday it had donated 2 million smokes to America's Persian Gulf forces in response to letters from the soldiers themselves. Critics say tobacco companies have repeatedly taken advantage of wars to hook soldiers on their products. ---

Nervous traders, mindful of the continuing Persian Gulf crisis, took their profits and cut short a two-day surge on Wall Street Tuesday. The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 industrials, up about 25 points for the first half of the day, closed down 10.64 at 2,505.20. The dollar dropped against all major currencies in uneventful U.S. trading after moving mostly higher overseas. Gold prices skidded on European and Asian markets, but they gained modestly in the United States. Precious metals posted an impressive turnaround from weeks of sharp loss. Grains and soybeans were higher. Cattle futures were lower. Pork futures were sharply higher. Bonds were higher.
