DOC.HEAD: Oil Falls As Quickly As It Rose
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices are showing an ability to fall as sharply on the hint of peace as they can rise on the hint of war. Crude oil futures plummeted more than $3 per barrel on the volatile New York Mercantile Exchange on Tuesday, a day after falling more than $2 a barrel. The back-to-back dives left traders wondering where the bottom would be, just as they had wondered last week how high oil could rise as it moved into the $40 range. ``The so-called war premium is being eaten away,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Contracts for November delivery of light sweet crude oil closed $3.14 lower at $33.95 on Tuesday. Crude contracts for later months all dropped, most by $1.50 per barrel, their maximum limit for the day. Oil's fall this week started off in response to more moderate overtures from President Bush and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Once crude began sliding, it dragged down futures prices for home heating oil and unleaded gasoline. Heating oil fell 8 cents to 92.03 cents per gallon Tuesday for November delivery. All later contract months dropped by the day's limit of 4 cents a gallon. Unleaded gasoline fell 6.98 cents to 86.93 cents per gallon for November delivery. All later contract months fell by their limit of 4 cents a gallon. Natural gas fell 2.9 cents to $1.88 per 1,000 cubic feet for November contracts. Most other contract months were lower. As the tough talk by the Gulf protagonists has faded, the world's oil supply picture has improved. Increased crude output from Saudi Arabia has begun to reach European markets, easing the early strain from the Iraq and Kuwait oil embargo. ``There was a window there where we had the shortfall from Iraq and Kuwait and we weren't really seeing the increase in OPEC production,'' Hittle said. ``That window happened to coincide with the fieriest rhetoric.'' After the futures market closed Tuesday, the American Petroleum Institute released a report showing that the nation's crude stockpile fell sharply last week. Gasoline stocks were up slightly, while stocks of distillates, which include heating oil, were down slightly, API said in its statistics for the week that ended Sept. 28. Crude oil stocks fell to 354.6 million barrels, from 364 million barrels a week earlier, although they remained above their level of 333.3 million barrels a year earlier. Gasoline stocks rose to 223.9 million barrels, up from 222.3 million barrels a week earlier and 223.7 million barrels a year earlier. Stocks of distillates, which include heating oil, fell to 134.8 million barrels, from 136.5 million barrels a week earlier, although they remained above their level of 122.9 million barrels a year ago. The nation's refineries ran at 91.2 percent of capacity, down from 92.8 percent a week earlier but up from 89.4 percent a year ago, the API said.

DOC.HEAD: Milk Companies Stuck With Leftover Milk-fat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Health-conscious consumers are on a low-fat buying craze and major dairy companies are having a cow about how to shed tons of fatty leftovers squeezed out of milk, ice cream and other products. ``As we take more fat out of our products, which consumers are wanting more and more, you have to have a place to put it - which we don't,'' said William D. Fischer, president and chief operating officer of Dean Foods, the nation's second-largest dairy. ``We're losing half a million dollars a month'' by selling the fat for less than it costs to remove it from the milk, he said Tuesday. Dean Foods, based in suburban Franklin Park, produces about 4.4 billion pounds of fat annually and is selling it at a loss while looking for some other way to use it. The largest U.S. dairy, Borden Inc. of New York, faces similar problems, although it keeps no detailed records of the amount of money lost this way, said Jim McKinley, manager of financial communications. ``It's a problem that affects the entire dairy industry,'' McKinley said. ``Sales of low-fat products have been increasing at a higher rate than other products.'' Skim and low-fat milk sales accounted for about 40 percent of the market 10 years ago, but now comprise about 60 percent, industry analysts said. ``It reflects a changing consumer preference for low-fat products,'' said John McMillan, food-industry analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. ``Fifteen years ago, nobody bought low-fat and skim milk.'' The turnaround occurred so quickly, officials said, that dairy makers were taken by surprise and had no alternatives for getting rid of the fat except to continue selling most of it for use in the production of butter. Butter, however, is also shunned by health- and cost-conscious consumers. ``There's now more butter on the market than we can possibly consume,'' Fischer said. ``There's also a glut worldwide.'' The industry has asked the federal government to ease its predicament with legislation aimed at providing incentives for farmers to breed cows producing low-fat milk with more protein. Farmers currently have no incentive to change breeding patterns because, under federal pricing guidelines, they receive the same amount of money no matter what fat content milk has. ``The new way would reward farmers for producing milk with more protein and less fat,'' Fischer said. The Agriculture Department supports such legislation because its budget is taking a beating after buying surplus butter in a multibillion-dollar dairy price-support program. The government this year reported 397.5 million pounds of stockpiled butter, purchased at a cost of $502.6 million under the support program in which it annually buys about 10 percent of national dairy production. Those costs and the price of storing the dairy products are so high the government began giving them away to needy families in the early 1980s. But the government began having problems giving it away because the stockpile was so huge, said Kelly Shipp, a USDA spokesman. Giveaways to schools and other agencies now help reduce the stockpile each year, but butter still is being produced at such a rate that the government suffers huge losses, Ms. Shipp said. Changes in the government's milk-marketing rules are years away, however, she said. ``Unfortunately, the rules say we have to have a nationwide hearing process and farmer referendum before we make changes,'' Ms. Shipp said. ``We're moving as fast as we possibly can. We can't just go out and change things tomorrow because we want to.'' Dairy companies grumble that even after any possible changes are drafted, it would take years before farmers could breed cows to produce low-fat milk. ``This is a problem we've had for years, and each year that goes by without a solution costs us money,'' McKinley said.

DOC.HEAD: After Four Years, Allegations To Get Public Airing
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken's lawyers could get their first crack at their client's main accuser - ex-con inside trader Ivan Boesky - at a hearing on allegations the government says show Milken deserves years in prison. After four years of investigation and innuendo, the government's most celebrated Wall Street fraud case finally will get a public airing starting next week at the special hearing ordered by U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood. The government requested the hearing to try to substantiate charges made in a pre-sentencing memorandum urging a stiff prison sentence against Milken based on an alleged history of wrongdoing far beyond six felonies he has admitted. Assistant U.S. Attorney John Carroll said Tuesday the government would limit its inquiry at the hearing to four transactions by Milken alleging insider trading and other wrongdoing in the mid-1980s involving Caesar's World Inc., MGM-UA Entertainment Co., Storer Communications Inc. and Wickes Cos. The Caesar's transaction involves new charges of insider trading. The three others were included in the government's original 98-count fraud and racketeering indictment against Milken handed up in March 1989. Wood last week had asked the government to limit its presentation to under five transactions of more than 35 included in its presentencing memo, including allegations of insider trading, stock parking, and illegal payoffs to clients and money managers. Milken's lawyers, in a lengthy rebuttal, deny most of the claims. The government's sentencing memo issued last week portrayed Milken as a systematic lawbreaker who rigged the financial markets for his own benefit. The defense said the 44-year-old Milken was a hard-working and honest businessman and philanthropist who has acknowledged his mistakes and shouldn't be punished for unproven crimes. Carroll said the government had not decided whether to call to the stand Boesky, the former arbitrager who implicated Milken in wrongdoing shortly after he admitted in November 1986 to running a widespread insider trading network. If Boesky testifies, it would be the first time defense lawyers will meet Milken's chief accuser face to face. Other potential witnesses are former Milken associates at Drexel's Beverly Hills, Calif., high-yield bond department, Boesky associates and others said to be involved in the alleged illegal transactions. Boesky was released in April after two years in federal custody of a three-year sentence. He has testified publicly once, at the trial this summer of former stock speculator John A. Mulheren Jr. Prosecutors presented a list of 14 witnesses who cooperated with government investigators typically in exchange for immunity from prosecution who may appear at the planned two-week hearing, set to begin next Tuesday. Milken in April pleaded guilty to six felonies including conspiracy and tax and securities fraud, and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties in a deal settling broader charges. But in its pre-sentencing memo, the government alleged many more crimes than those Milken admitted. Milken faces a maximum 28 years in prison. His lawyers have urged the judge to sentence him to community service developing and running inner-city youth education programs in Los Angeles. Wood said the hearing is designed to shed light on Milken's character to better enable her to devise an appropriate sentence. Both sides will have 20 hours to present arguments and cross-examine witnesses as at a trial. The hearing further delays the long-awaited sentencing, originally set for Monday, in the most celebrated case stemming from the government's Wall Street insider trading investigations that began in late 1986. Milken attorneys are expected to use their presentation time at the hearing to present character witnesses who would bolster their request for community service in lieu of prison time. Arthur Liman, Milken's lead lawyer, said the hearing would give the judge the ``benefits of separating the myth of Michael Milken from the person.'' The judge said that in sentencing she would discount any testimony about alleged lawbreaking by Milken other than the four transactions. She also said she may ask questions about some of the six felonies to which Milken has pleaded guilty. Under federal case law, sentencing judges can consider unadmitted conduct. Earlier this year, another judge refused to consider such allegations against former stock speculator Robert Freeman.

DOC.HEAD: Smoking Critics Rebuke Tobacco Companies for Gulf Cigarette Giveaway
DOC.TEXT: War is breaking out in the Persian Gulf but it's over cigarettes, not oil. The antagonists in this battle are U.S. tobacco companies giving free cigarettes to U.S. forces stationed in the gulf vs. anti-smoking groups who say the giveaways are a ploy to hook a new generation of soldiers. Philip Morris U.S.A., the nation's leading cigarette maker, said Tuesday it had donated 2 million smokes to Operation Desert Shield in response to letters from tobacco-deprived soldiers. Larry Glennie, company director of military specialty sales, said Philip Morris had shipped the 10,000 cartons of Marlboros to Saudi Arabia on Sept. 26. They were distributed free to ``members of the Army, Air Force and Marines who have the least access to the basic comforts of everyday life,'' he said. The shipment followed a Sept. 25 announcement by the much smaller Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp. that it planned to send an undisclosed number of free Kool Milds and Richlands to the U.S. contingent defending oil-rich Saudi Arabia against a possible Iraqi attack. Smoking critics said the moves subverted a 4-year-old Defense Department health policy aimed at discouraging cigarette use. ``As health organizations, we certainly have to be concerned about the readiness of our troops,'' said Fran DuMelle, chairwoman of the Coalition on Smoking or Health, a Washington lobby group. ``I think the coalition is principally outraged at the tobacco industry's attempt to exploit the situation in the Mideast,'' she said. ``In every war in the last 40 years, the industry has used the concept of free cigarettes to hook a new generation of smokers.'' Steven Dickinson, a spokesman for the American Cancer Society, said he wasn't surprised by the giveaways, but questioned why the Pentagon hadn't taken a public position on the free smokes. ``The point is, the Department of Defense has recognized that smoking is a deterrent to fitness. Here they are playing into the tobacco companies,'' Dickinson said. At the Pentagon, Defense Department spokesman Maj. Douglas Hart said he would have to check further before he could comment on the tobacco company announcements. ``This is the first I've heard about this, to tell you the truth,'' Hart said. It was unclear whether the free cigarettes violated the Pentagon's anti-smoking policy, which was begun in 1986 by then-Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. The policy restricts where soldiers may smoke and subjects recruits to an aggressive educational campaign to discourage them from smoking because of what medical authorities have called the extreme health risks, which include cancer. Glennie said Philip Morris had received a number of letters requesting cigarettes from troops in Operation Desert Shield. ``They were having trouble getting cigarettes,'' Glennie said. He rejected the anti-smoking lobby's criticism. ``I don't think there's anything we do that we don't get criticzed for,'' he said. ``The company felt that since we'd gotten the letters directly from the front-line troops, we thought it was the right thing to do.'' A Philip Morris press statement quoted one unidentified letter from a paratrooper in the 82nd Airborne division as saying, ``We are not greedy people, just paratroopers unable to get hold of great cigarettes. So any cigarettes you could send us would make our stay here much more pleasurable.'' Another soldier was quoted as saying, ``We came over here with hardly any notice and most of us are out of tobacco and tired.'' Philip Morris U.S.A. is part of Philip Morris Companies Inc., the world's largest consumer products company, based in New York. Besides its cigarette brands, which include Marlboro and Benson & Hedges, the company sells items ranging from Miller beer to Maxwell House coffee to Velveeta cheese spread.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Deal Would Raise OSHA Fines for First Time in 20 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires. ^By KAREN BALL
DOC.TEXT: Occupational Safety and Health Administration fines would increase for the first time in the agency's 20-year history under the $500 billion deficit-cutting package. The proposed sharp increases in federal fines for workplace safety violations came under fire from business and labor leaders on Tuesday. The AFL-CIO has been pushing higher OSHA fines for years, but spokesman Rex Hardesty complained Tuesday that the proposed increases were being spurred by a desire to cut the deficit rather than an effort to protect workers' lives. Under the deficit-reduction package unveiled Sunday by White House and congressional budget negotiators, OSHA fines would be raised by five times. The most serious penalty - for willful violations of workplace safety regulations - would increase from $10,000 to $50,000. Mark Cowan, who heads a consulting firm that represents corporations, said, ``It sounds like OSHA's about collecting money to pay the tax man. ... It's like the former Georgia speed traps, where they used a massive campaign to catch speeders to raise revenues for the state.'' Cowan, who served as a Labor Department chief of staff and OSHA aide under then-President Reagan, said the agency would be ``regulating without public involvement,'' contending the plan would not get a thorough hearing in Congress. AFL-CIO spokesman Rex Hardesty said officials ``won't raise OSHA fines when our brothers' and sisters' lives are in jeopardy, but they'll raise fines for a deficit.'' Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole had pushed for a threefold increase, giving the agency the power to levy fines as high as $30,000 for the most flagrant violations, noted department spokeswoman Johanna Schneider. The department supports the fivefold increase in the budget deal because President Bush supports it, she said. She said OSHA inspectors still would be most concerned with worker safety, adding, ``We're just not interested in cash or the bottom line.'' The higher fines would raise an estimated $95 million in the 1991 fiscal year and $1.1 billion more over the next four years, according to the Office of Management and Budget.

DOC.HEAD: Not All the Well-Heeled Bothered by Luxury Tax
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires. ^LaserPhoto DN1
DOC.TEXT: Shoppers in this deliriously rich Dallas enclave look at it this way: If you can afford a $50,000 Mercedes Benz, surely, my dear, you can afford the luxury tax on it. ``I don't like it, but I think it's fair,'' said Rick Jones, sorting through designer shirts at the Polo Shop, one of this community's high-priced shops. But Randle Stricklin, a salesman at Cartier Inc., where watches range in price from $1,000 to $20,000, complained the tax burden should fall evenly on all retailers. ``It hits hard,'' he said. ``Why single out luxury dealers, who have suffered in the last 10 years - especially in Texas?'' Elsewhere in the country, merchants who cater to the carriage trade complain that the government proposal to raise taxes on big-ticket items - including expensive cars, yachts, jewelry and furs - discriminates against their wealthy clientele. Though they protest, many merchants are bracing for a flurry of sales as customers rush to put an extra case of champagne or a pair of sapphire earrings on their tab for the holidays, before the tax takes effect. The 10 percent luxury tax, part of a $500 billion deficit-reduction agreement unveiled Sunday, would apply to the portion of the price of some luxury items over certain thresholds. For example, a $6,000 fur - priced $1,000 above the $5,000 tax threshold - would cost $6,100, if the taxes are approved by Congress. Cars would be taxed at 10 percent of the amount above $30,000. The threshold for jewelry would be $5,000. ``If you can afford to pay $30,000 for a car, you sure can afford to pay a few hundred dollars more,'' said Terri Jung of Austin as she left a Neiman-Marcus store. ``My first answer as a luxury car dealer is, maybe it isn't fair,'' said Todd Meier, president of Rodger Meier Cadillac, where $55,000 cars are sold from a chandelier-lit showroom. ``But overall, as a citizen, I think it makes sense to tax people who theoretically can afford it.'' Meier said virtually all of the more than 2,000 new Cadillacs he sells each year would be affected by the tax. Highland Park, home of the billionaire Hunt brothers and tycoon T. Boone Pickens, sits squarely in the middle of Dallas, a separate world where nannies wheel their charges along streets lined with Mercedes-Benzes, Cadillacs and BMWs. Highland Park shopper Billy McCarthy said the luxury tax was unjust. ``It'll just be going for the wealthy,'' he said. ``We're overtaxed as it is.'' Most agreed the taxes might slow the economy by dissuading middle-class shoppers but would not affect the rich. ``It might prevent people like us. We're going to think twice,'' said DeAnn Ralston, window-shopping with co-workers outside Bachendorf's Jewelers. In any case, luxury is in the eye of the beholder. Roger Rock, manager of a Tiffany & Co. store, said he didn't think the taxes would slow business. Tiffany's catalog lists jewelry ranging from under $200 to nearly $1 million. ``It depends on what you call luxuries,'' Rock said. ``From my point of view, these are all necessities.''

DOC.HEAD: Biotechnology Patent Application Backlog Almost Four Years Long
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The backlog of patent applications for inventions in the biotechnology field has grown to 8,213 and some applicants are waiting almost four years for final action by the Patent and Trademark Office, a study says. The General Accounting office, in a report released Tuesday, said the inventory of unexamined biotechnology patent applications increased by about 33 percent in 1989 and 1990 and that efforts to accelerate the process ``have been less effective than anticipated.'' Waiting time for biotechnology patents, the study said, averaged about 26 months last year, compared to a 19-month average wait in other technology fields. Rep. Ron Wyden, who ordered the study by the GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, called the finding ``very, very disturbing.'' ``These sorts of delays not only put struggling, young biotech companies at risk, they may also hold up distribution of new, lifesaving drugs, seed for supercrops or engineered organisms to clean up pollution,'' the Oregon Democrat said. To obtain a patent, applicants must file descriptions of the new technology. Patent examiners then determine if the proposal is new, useful and significantly different from earlier patents. This requires experts, who understand the science involved, to search previous patent files. Among biotechnology patents issued in 1989, those for genetic engineering inventions took the longest - an average of 47.4 months. Patents for immunology inventions took an average of 44.1 months and biochemicals 37.7 months. The GAO said the Patent Office increased its biotechnology patent examiners from 91 to 112 from October 1988 to July 1990. It said more examiners could not be hired because the Patent Office lacked experienced senior staff to train the new employees. The report said the lack of experienced examiners in biotechnology has caused the first examination of patent applications to be delayed an average of 13.1 months, compared with an average of 7.1 for all technologies. Patent Office officials once set a goal of reducing the processing time for biotechnology applications to 18 months by 1992, but the report said the officials now believe they will be unable to meet that goal.

DOC.HEAD: Wealthy Do Best, Poor Worst Under Budget Package, Study Shows
With PM-Budget, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Wealthy Americans would bear the lightest share of the burden imposed by the new $500 billion deficit-reduction plan, while the poorest people would shoulder the greatest costs, a congressional study says. The richest one-fifth of American families, with annual after-tax income averaging $81,934, would lose 0.9 percent of their earnings as a result of the plan. That would come to a $766 loss. But the poorest one-fifth of Americans would lose 2 percent of their average $7,316 annual after-tax incomes, or $148, according to the study by the House Ways and Means Committee. The average American family would suffer a 1.2 percent hit. Its $33,401 average after-tax income would shrink by $394. The analysis seems to show that one of the priorities Democrats touted during their four months of budget negotiations with the Bush administration - a package that spreads the burden based on peoples' ability to pay - was not achieved. The study analyzed the effects of the higher taxes and benefit program cuts the package would impose. These include levies on luxury items, tobacco, alcohol, fuel, airline tickets and the incomes of people who earn more than $100,000 annually. The package also applies the 1.45 percent Medicare tax to people with incomes of up to $73,000, rather than the current $51,300. It increases the monthly $28.60 premium Medicare recipients pay for doctors' care by about $5, and doubles the $75 deductible beneficiaries themselves pay for physicians' bills. It provides a number of tax breaks for businesses and expands the earned income tax credit for the poor. It also requires states to impose two-week waiting periods for people waiting to collect unemployment benefits. The study also concluded that: -For families in the second-lowest fifth of annual income, averaging $16,917, the loss would be 1.6 percent, or $272. -For families in the middle fifth, averaging $25,896, the loss would be 1.3 percent, or $347. -For families in the second-highest fifth, or an average of $36,481, the loss would be 1.1 percent, or $416. The study also made a pitch for the $14.5 billion expansion of child care initiatives that the Ways and Means Committee is pursuing. The analysis showed that if the child care measure is approved - along with the extension of the 3 percent tax on telephone calls intended to pay for it - the distribution of the budget package would be spread more evenly. The poorest one-fifth of Americans would lose 0.9 percent of their after-tax incomes, while the wealthiest one-fifth would lose 1 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Prices Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar was mostly lower against other major currencies in Europe late this morning. Gold prices were higher. Traders said they expected quiet conditions for the rest of the session because the German markets are closed for the unification day celebrations. Traders said the dollar has settled in a narrow range between 1.5440 marks and 1.5570 marks and isn't likely to break outside this range unless there are clear signals from the U.S. Federal Reserve about its monetary policy. ``We are in a stand-by situation,'' one Milan trader said. Clues about the direction of U.S. interest rates might surface later in the day when Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan testifies before a congressional committee on the banking insurance system. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.08 yen to a closing 136.65 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 136.77 yen. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8905, compared with $1.8890 late Tuesday. Other dollar rates at midmorning in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates included: 1.5515 German marks, down from 1.5540; 1.2915 Swiss francs, up from 1.2900; 5.1995 French francs, down from 5.2050; 1.7480 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7502; 1,162.50 Italian lire, down from 1,162.75, and 1.1528 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1532. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $389.85 per ounce at midmorning, up from $388.75 bid an ounce late Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $388.80, up from $388.60. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.23 to close at a bid $388.48. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.69 a troy ounce, down from Tuesday's $4.72.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Pump Prices Rise Again, AAA Survey Finds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices at the pump rose 3.6 cents last week to an average of $1.346 per gallon of self-serve regular unleaded, according to a nationwide survey. That puts gasoline 27.1 cents a gallon higher than on Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait and threw world oil markets into chaos. The survey was released Tuesday by the American Automobile Association. The average pump price remains below the highest ever recorded by the AAA, which was $1.388 per gallon in 1981 after the Iranian revolution. Gasoline prices were up in all regions of the country, with the biggest increase in the Great Lakes region, the AAA survey said.

DOC.HEAD: Princeton Scientists Report Fusion Reactor Can Break Even
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 9th graf pvs, `Manos said...', to add that process unrelated to so-called `cold fusion.' Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Fusion, which...'; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Physicists at Princeton University say they have developed a fusion reactor capable of producing as much energy as it consumes, a step that brings them closer to harnessing the energy of the H-bomb. Scientists said Tuesday the breakthrough allows them to move ahead with developing fusion as an alternative to coal and nuclear power. But they cautioned that the project, which has spanned 15 years and cost $1 billion, faces several major hurdles - including determining how to extract the energy from the reactor - and could be decades away from commercial use. Scientists said their Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor at Princeton can reach the break-even point. ``It's step one, the first real threshold you have to get across to get an engineering device whose ultimate objective is to produce much more energy than you put in,'' said Robert Sachs, a physics professor at the University of Chicago. The researchers, at the Princeton Plasma Physics Research Laboratory, have combined atoms of a heavy form of hydrogen called deuterium to form helium and energy. The next step, which researchers hope to achieve in 1993, would use a mixture of deuterium and a radioactive form of hydrogen called tritium to generate large amounts of energy in the Tokamak reactor. Dennis Manos, principal research physicist at the Princeton labs, said that with modifications, the reactor will be capable of generating 10 million watts of power a day. Manos said the Joint European TORUS laboratory in England is working on a similar form of energy and is observing many of the same findings as their Princeton counterparts. The process used at Princeton has nothing to do with the so-called ``cold fusion'' claimed by scientists at the University of Utah last year, Manos said. The Utah scientists said they had produced energy from fusion at low temperature with simple apparatus, possibly opening the way to an almost limitless supply of cheap energy. But other scientists generally have rejected their claims. Fusion, which powers the sun and the stars, creates energy by combining, or fusing, two hydrogen atoms into a heavier helium atom. By contrast, fission, which powers conventional nuclear plants, releases energy by splitting atoms. The hydrogen bomb uses fusion to cause mass destruction. Proponents say fusion eliminates the danger of reactor meltdowns, produces less radioactive waste than current nuclear plants do, and is produced from a readily available source - hydrogen. ``It is a potentially safer technology, but it has a long way to go when you compare it with existing commercial fission technology,'' Manos said. Manos described the Tokamak as a doughnut-shaped fireplace lit by blowtorches. Deuterium is heated to the point where atoms break into plasma, a mixture of free electrons and free nuclei. Scientists then bombard the plasma with a high-tech blowtorch - radio waves and high-energy particle beams. Tokamak has attained 50,000 watts and a world record temperature of 400 million degrees Centigrade with the deuterium mixture, Manos said. The next step, which is scheduled for 1993, is to see if a deuterium-tritium mixture will burn in Tokamak. Manos compared it to developing a way to ignite a wet log in a fireplace. After that, the trick will be to set up a controlled-fusion reaction that will keep going without prodding by the particle beam. ``You take the blowtorch away from the wet log and see if the log still burns,'' Manos said, adding such a step is at least a decade away. The Soviet Union, the United States, Japan and the European Economic Community hope to develop a test reactor sometime after the year 2000, he said. Manos and Sachs cautioned that even if a test reactor is built researchers will still have to find a way to get at the power. ``How to extract the energy from the reactor in a useful way is an engineering question no one has yet answered,'' Sachs said.

DOC.HEAD: Murdoch Merges Australian Papers
DOC.NOTE: EDS: All values in U.S. dollars
DOC.TEXT: International media mogul Rupert Murdoch said Wednesday he will merge four of his Australian newspapers into two around-the-clock productions. The head of News Corp. told a news conference that the morning Melbourne Sun and afternoon Herald would become The Herald-Sun. In Sydney, the afternoon Mirror and the morning Daily Telegraph will operate as the Daily Telegraph Mirror. All but the Herald are tabloids. ``These far-reaching changes are made as part of a commercial decision to consolidate News Ltd.'s competitive positions in both cities,'' he said. The moves come amidst a plunge in the value of News Corp.'s stock. It was trading Wednesday at the equivalent of $5.56 a share, $9.42 earlier this month. The fall has wiped out more than $1.66 billion of the company's market capitalization and led the Australian Stock Exchange to launch an inquiry. News Corp. told the exchange Tuesday it did not know the reason for the decline. The new 24-hour editions, publishing Monday through Saturday, are expected to start next Monday. While Murdoch said there would be no cutbacks in editorial staff, other production areas will be trimmed. He said the Sunday Sun and the Sunday Herald in Melbourne would continue as separate publications. The new Sydney paper is projected to have a circulation of 480,000, compared with 600,000 for The Herald Sun. Murdoch said the move was one part of News Corp.'s goal to move to high-tech color printing in Australia, which would see full color printing on every second page. Prime Minister Bob Hawke said he felt the mergers would be beneficial overall. ``It will probably mean a loss of jobs for some people, but as far as the community in general is concerned they probably will get a better service,'' he said. Hawke said he did not foresee damage from a reduction in the divergence of newspaper voices. ``If I look at the sort of opinions that come out of the Telegraph and the Mirror and out of the Sun and the Herald and the two city papers down there, I don't see an enormous divergence of opinion,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Headquarters a Magnet for Ceremonies, Protests
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 11th graf pvs, No reason ... to UPDATE with developments in Rwanda; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Few things get Agriculture Department officials as worked up as prospects of a demonstration in front of their administration building. The building is where the secretary of agriculture has his office, and it's convenient for tourists walking along the Mall as they take in the museums and art galleries. It's also a great place for ceremonies, such as planting trees, and for demonstrations against all sorts of injustices and grievances. A bit of each was in store on Tuesday, a bright autumn day scheduled by the Farm Animal Reform Movement, or FARM, to protest what the group sees as the inhumane treatment of cattle, hogs, sheep and poultry that farmers produce for consumer tables. On Monday, the office of Secretary Clayton Yeutter sent notices to reporters that he would be participating in a tree-planting ceremony on Tuesday, an hour before the scheduled demonstration by FARM members. Yeutter, the notices said, would share the planting of three trees with His Excellency, Major General Juvenal Habyarimana, president of the Republic of Rwanda, in central Africa. ``Both the United States and Rwanda recognize the importance of reforestation,'' the notice said. ``The (USDA) is the lead agency in the National Tree Planting Initiative, with the goal of planting one billion trees a year.'' The notice added that President Habyarimana's reforestation programs ``serve as models for other African nations hoping to increase their agricultural production.'' On Tuesday morning during a staff meeting, Yeutter's press secretary, Kelly Shipp, was informed that the tree-planting had been canceled. A bit later, another notice went to reporters, saying that President Habyarimana ``has canceled his stay in the United States and returned to Rawanda.'' Habyarimana cut short his visit to deal with an invasion of his nation by up to 10,000 Rwandan refugees living in Uganda. The refugees returned to their homeland on Sunday and attacked several villages, prompting U.S. Embassy officials to begin moving Americans out of the region today. The troubles in Rwanda aside, Agriculture Department officials were left with no ceremony and the question of what to do with three unplanted dogwood trees. The Forest Service provided a partial answer: one tree already was planted, so Yeutter and guest could throw a few shovels full of dirt on it during the ceremony and picture-taking. The other two, standing nearby, were to be taken to the National Arboretum. At 3 p.m., right on schedule, a handful of FARM protesters gathered across the street from the administration building near their exhibits, which included gory photographs of slaughtered livestock and a wooden crate containing a dummy calf to portray veal production. More demonstrators showed up with signs and banners condemning animal cruelty on the farm. At the peak of the march, about two dozen demonstrators traipsed back and forth for cameras and a few reporters. Nearby, at least two dozen federal police officers and USDA security people barred the way to the front doors of the administration building. Sandra Behm, one of the organizers, said in an interview that it was annual World Farm Animals Day - as proclaimed by her group - and also the birthdate of Mohandas K. Gandhi, the late Indian leader. Behm said FARM has about 13,000 members nationwide and that she was ``surprised more of us didn't show up'' for the demonstration. What does she want? Legislation that would improve the conditions of animals raised on ``factory'' farms where they are confined and kept in conditions of ``horrible suffering'' during their lifetimes. Does this mean pigs should wear boots and cows woolen bras to protect their udders? ``No, I don't think they'd like that,'' she laughed. ``I don't think that's natural.'' But, in the end, Behm said, ``We'd like the whole world to wake up and see that eating animals and animal products is killing us, killing the environment.'' Meanwhile, she said, until that happens, animals will be raised and killed for food, but ``we should do it as humanely as possible.'' A short while later, five members of the protest group were taken into custody as they tried to outrun guards and enter the administration building. Two were released, but three were taken away for booking as trespassers. There were no visible serious injuries. ``We'll take care of 'em,'' said Behm. ``We'll get 'em out.'' Suddenly, it was all over. Protesters melted away and USDA officials got over their jitters.

DOC.NOTE: $adv07
For release Sunday, Oct. 7, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: With Graphic
A Year After `Mini-Crash,' Markets Still Slump
DOC.TEXT: On Oct. 13, 1989, Wall Street was suddenly faced with a problem. A planned buyout of UAL Corp., the big airline holding company, collapsed for want of financing, touching off a ``mini-crash'' in stock prices. Today, nearly a year later, Wall Street still has a UAL-buyout problem - plus a long list of others that have since all but overshadowed it. In the process, the acute selloff that struck the stock market last fall has given way to a chronic case of malaise in just about every major category of investment, including stocks, bonds and real estate. Though the two ailments might look very different at first glance, analysts have begun to diagnose them as symptoms of a single phenomenon: The first full-blown bear market in nearly a decade. ``We've moved from a time of euphoria to a period of financial distress,'' said Hugh Johnson at the investment firm of First Albany Corp. in Albany, N.Y. ``Last year around this time is when everything started to come unstuck.'' As Johnson and a good many other observers see it, the big problem then and now can be summarized in the same simple terms: deteriorating credit conditions. As autumn 1989 arrived, would-be lenders were fleeing the market for ``junk'' debt, such as the bonds and other loans used to finance takeovers like the proposed UAL buyout. The flagship junk-debt firm on Wall Street, Drexel Burnham Lambert, collapsed in February 1990, and deals like the one for UAL still have not been concluded. As autumn 1990 begins, the supply of money to lend is contracting in many additional places, most notably at the big multinational banks near the heart of the financial system. ``It started at the high-risk end of lending,'' Johnson said. ``Now it's much more broad-based.'' Any talk of a year-old bear market might not seem to square with recollections that the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks reached a record closing high of 2,999.75 less than three months ago, on July 16. But broader market indexes, made up of hundreds of stocks rather than a handful of blue chips, lagged behind in this year's trading, and most have never equalled the peaks they reached around September 1989. Indeed, the highs for a few stock-price yardsticks still date back to before the Crash of 1987. The charts of bank stocks tell the story in most vivid terms. For instance, Citicorp, parent of New York's biggest bank, sold for as much as $35.50 a share last year. Lately it has been trading for less than $15. ``The banking industry is the major worry,'' said Thom Brown, an analyst at Rutherford, Brown & Catherwood Inc. in Philadelphia. For most people, all this raises a bottom-line question: Must trouble on Wall Street translate into equal travail on Main Street? Does each drop in the prices of stocks or junk bonds portend a recession of worsening proportions? No single, definitive answer to this question has yet emerged. Most of the experts now are talking of a ``mild'' economic downturn - perhaps two consecutive calendar quarters in which the nation's gross national product, after adjustment for inflation, declines. Just what toll that might exact in jobs, reduced corporate profits or lost tax revenues for federal, state and local governments remains to be seen. Some analysts talk of a risk that recession, either already under way or soon to begin, could prove a lot more severe than has been predicted. Others, by contrast, argue that most of the damage can be confined to a relatively few industries where money and credit conditions are most pivotal - banking, investments, housing and perhaps a few more. These observers argue that much of the country did not share in the speculative credit boom of the 1980s, and thus might not feel the full weight of its collapse in the early 1990s. For instance, businesses that sell significant amounts of goods overseas could get a lift from the decline of the dollar in foreign exchange over the past year. Energy-related businesses stand to benefit from the same surge in oil prices that has heightened fears of a recession since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. In addition, many analysts say, the bleaker the economic outlook gets, the more likely interest rates are to start falling - sooner or later cushioning the impact of the slump and, if all goes well, helping to set the stage for a subsequent recovery. But hardly anybody sees such a recovery as a prospect for the near future. Analysts at Wright Investors' Service in Bridgeport, Conn., concluded: ``The question at issue, it seems to us, is no longer whether the U.S. economy will sink into recession but how deep that recession will be.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday, Oct 7

DOC.HEAD: AEA Reports August Traffic Up 10 Percent, But No Profits
DOC.TEXT: The Association of European Airlines said Wednesday its 21 member carriers posted a 10 percent rise in overall passenger traffic in August but called the growth ``profitless.'' The rise kept pace with traffic growth over the past year, the AEA said, adding that the Gulf crisis, higher fuel prices and other cost increases ``have seriously eroded already thin (profit) margins. ``Current growth could fairly be described as profitless,'' the AEA said in a statement. AEA said fuel costs had been rising before the Gulf crisis began and had not been offset by the relative weakness of the dollar. ``While depreciation in the dollar has ... softened the effect of more expensive fuel, it has also reduced the value of the European airlines' dollar earnings during the peak transatlantic travel season,'' the AEA said. In August, AEA traffic to and from the Middle East was down, but losses on Gulf routes were largely offset by gains in traffic to and from Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Xerox Exec To Head Sematech
DOC.TEXT: The semiconductor research consortium Sematech has named a top Xerox Corp. executive as its president and chief executive officer, officials announced today. William J. Spencer, a veteran microelectronics researcher, will succeed Robert Noyce at Sematech's helm. Noyce died of a heart attack this summer. ``I am honored to join the elite team at Sematech,'' Spencer said in a prepared statement. Spencer is the former group vice president and senior technical officer for Xerox Corp. in Stamford, Conn. He also previously managed Xerox's worldwide research activity. Noyce, a pioneer in the semiconductor industry, died June 3. He had headed the Austin-based chip manufacturing research center since July 1988. Spencer, 60, will play an important role in guiding Sematech's research. He also will serve as a key spokesman for the microchip industry on issues such as federal funding and bolstering the semiconductor industry and its support companies against foreign competitors. Spencer joined Xerox in 1981, when he became manager of the company's integrated circuit laboratory at its Palo Alto Research Center. He formerly worked for the government-funded Sandia National Laboratories in Livermore, Calif., and as a research professor of medicine at the University of New Mexico. Sematech was created by 14 companies in 1988 to regain the world lead in microchip manufacturing technology for the United States by 1993. The consortium employs 650 people in Austin. It has an annual budget of $200 million, which is supported by member companies and by matching funds from the Defense Advanced Projects Research Agency.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Surge On USSR Rumors
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices surged in early trading this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade, leading the grain markets higher amid expectations of new Soviet purchases of U.S. agricultural products. Joel Karlin, a grains analyst with Chicago-based Research Department Inc., said rumors abounded in the markets that the United States will grant the Soviet Union most-favored trading status within a month. Karlin said the Soviets also were rumored to be seeking credit from U.S., European and Japanese lenders, partly for purchases of foreign agricultural products. ``It's giving the market a boost on ideas they're probably going to buy some meal and oil first,'' Karlin said. ``Corn and wheat are being dragged up by the soy complex.'' Rain-related harvest delays in the Midwest also contributed to the buying sentiment, although warm, dry conditions were expected to return to the region later in the week. In early trading, wheat futures were 3 cents to 4 cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.68} a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 2} cents higher with December at $2.27 a bushel; oats were { cent to 1 cent higher with December at $1.24 a bushel; soybeans were 3} cents to 10} cents higher with November at $6.17 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .03 cent lower to .13 cent higher with October at 79.97 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .12 cent lower to .13 cent higher with October at 87.70 cents a pound; live hogs were .02 cent to .20 cent lower with October at 56 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .88 cent to the permitted daily limit of 2 cents higher with February at 63.85 cents a pound. Cattle futures fell Tuesday but most pork futures advanced.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls for Passage of Budget Package
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 17 grafs new to raise Fitzwater saying not enough votes yet, include Fitzwater, Brady remarks on possible changes; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today called on congressional skeptics to support a $500 billion package of tax increases and spending cuts. He said lawmakers will be ``courting disaster'' if they do not pass it. Bush urged members of Congress to vote for the package and then ``blame the president'' when they talk to voters. Earlier, White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We don't have enough votes yet'' to pass the budget package. He said a Senate vote will be close, but the House at this time would defeat the plan worked out by administration and congressional negotiators. Bush called the budget agreement balanced and fair, although he acknowledged it will hit Americans in the wallet. ``There's nothing that is without pain,'' the president told a group of journalists from around the country. However, he said, `` It is our last best chance to try to get this federal deficit under control.'' ``There comes a time when you have to make tough decisions, give a little and do what is best for the country,'' Bush said. He said he, too, had to compromise to get the deficit-reduction agreement. ``No one got everything he or she wanted,'' he said. Bush broke his ``no new taxes'' campaign pledge to get the budget agreement. ``We linger along and don't get a deal, we are courting disaster,'' he said. Looking to the congressional debate on the package this week, he said, ``I call upon the Congress, both House and Senate, to cast their vote for this plan, and to prove to the American people that we can solve problems, that we can go out and get something done and put this nation on the path to long-term economic growth.'' Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said today he supports the deficit-reduction package, giving Bush a big boost in his efforts to sell the compromise proposal to Congress. Greenspan's views were seen as crucial because supporters of the package are looking to the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates to offset any negative economic effects from cutting government spending and raising taxes. Fitzwater and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, who briefed the visiting journalists, said Congress might make some changes in the package, fashioned after months of wrangling by the negotiators. ``There will be some details that will be fleshed out,'' said Fitzwater, but he insisted they would not be significant changes. If the major provisions do not remain, he said, ``you don't have an agreement.'' Brady discussed changes in the context of mistakes that might have been made in the crush to finish the deal. ``I'm sure those mistakes will be corrected,'' he said. Asked about the 12-cent tax increase on gasoline included in the package, Bush said, ``I can't get enthusiastic about a tax on the American people. We are not dealing with the best of all worlds.'' But, he added, ``we are trying to solve an enormous problem.'' ``The tax is fair,'' he said, noting that gasoline tax in the United States is ``still substantially below world markets.'' While the spending cuts and tax increases will hurt different people in different ways, Bush said, the $500 billion package is ``the medicine that a sluggish economy needs to go forward, to have more growth.'' He acknowledged there is hesitancy on the part of both Democrats and Republicans who have to face the voters next month to accept a plan that increases taxes. ``I have to understand the passions of people standing out there for election,'' he said. He indicated he would not try to punish Republicans who don't support him. ``I can't bring myself to be recriminatory,'' he said. He acknowledged that ``every once in a while the going gets a little tough. ... Nobody said it would be easy.'' However, he insisted that even with some members of his own party shunning the budget agreement, ``I don't feel embattled.'' Bush in a television address to the nation Tuesday night urged Americans to convince skittish lawmakers that backing the package won't cost them re-election. Today he continued high pressure lobbying to bring House Republicans on board. He met with 20 Republicans this morning, and planned to contact as many later in the day. Bush also canceled political travel plans for Thursday and Friday which would have taken him to New England to campaign for several GOP candidates. He decided to stay in Washington to lobby for a possible congressional vote on the budget package. Fitzwater said several lawmakers indicated today that Bush's TV address gave them the justification they needed to back the package. ``It fulfilled a part of their need which was to have an explanation from the president to the voters,'' the spokesman said. ``I'm not, and I know you're not, a fan of tax increases,'' Bush said in a nationally televised address Tuesday night. ``But if there have to be tax measures, they should allow the economy to grow. They should not turn us back to higher income tax rates, and they should be fair,'' he added, referring to the proposed tax increases on gasoline, cigarettes, boats, liquor and furs. Many lawmakers already are shunning the package because it will hit Americans hard in the wallet, a fact that could reverberate when voters go to the polls next month. The $500 billion budget accord, reached Sunday after months of negotiation, shaves benefits to farmers and Medicare recipients and reduces tax deductions for people who earn more than $100,000. A congressional study released Tuesday said the poor would be hit hardest by the package and the rich would feel its increases the least. The plan's increased taxes and reduced benefits would take an average 2 percent of the earnings of one-fifth of Americans with the lowest incomes, according to the survey by the House Ways and Means Committee. Speaking for the Democratic leadership, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell echoed the president, saying, ``This package is a compromise. Neither side got what it wanted.'' Democrats, he said in an equal-time TV address after Bush spoke, joined a Republican president to get the agreement. Now, he said, ``We hope the Republican members of Congress will also set aside partisan differences in doing what's right.'' While it is expected to take a tough sell among many Democrats as well as Bush's fellow Republicans who don't want to endorse tax increases and spending cuts in an election year, some opponents said the president had a good chance of getting the package through Congress. One, Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., said that more than half the House Republicans were opposed or leaning against the package but that administration lobbying eventually would sell it. Support is considered stronger in the Senate, where only one-third of the 100 members are up for re-election this year while all 435 House seats are up for grabs.

DOC.HEAD: Argentina Loan Reportedly Suspended
DOC.TEXT: The International Monetary Fund has suspended payment of a $245 million loan to Argentina because the government failed to achieve promised economic reforms during the third quarter, according to a report published Wednesday. Argentina did not accomplish adequate cuts in its inflation rate, which was in double digits each month from Juyy to September, and the government's fiscal surplus for the period turned out to be lower than promised, according to a daily financial newspaper, El Cronista Comercial. Citing sources in Washington, the newspaper reported that Argentina can reclaim the IMF standby loan if it cuts its government deficit, its inflation rate and the size of the public sector work force. That would require massive layoffs, the paper reported.

DOC.HEAD: Maxwell To Shed TV Interests To Concentrate On Papers, Printing
DOC.TEXT: Robert Maxwell's Mirror Group Newspapers said it will sell its interests in television companies for $300 million in an effort to concentrate on its newspaper and printing activities. Maxwell said in a statement Tuesday that the decision follows investment in new technology, which has resulted in the successful change from black-and-white printing to color printing for three of the group's British newspapers. They include the Daily Mirror, the group's national-circulation tabloid flagship, which has a daily sale of 3.9 million. ``We have decided in the future the group should concentrate purely on newspapers and printing,'' the statement said. ``We intend to expand our newspaper activities both at home and abroad, particularly in the USA where there are some excellent opportunities for expansion.'' It gave no other details. Included in the sale of Maxwell's television holdings are a 20 percent interest in Central TV in Britain, a 12.5 percent interest in the TV1 channel in France and a 51 percent interest in Music TV. The company also will dispose of its interests in British Cable TV. Czechoslovak-born Maxwell, who has business interests in eastern Europe, also announced the group had taken advantage of new opportunities there with the conclusion of various transactions. Among them: - The acquisition of a 50 percent stake in the Berliner Verlag, a newspaper and magazine publisher in what was formerly East Germany that publishes the Berliner Zeitung newspaper and its evening stablemate BZ am Abend. The statement said Mirror Group Newspapers had acquired the Berliner Verlag jointly with Gruner and Jahr, a Bertlesmann subsidiary. - A 40 percent interest in a daily and evening newspaper in Budapest. - Participation in two newspapers in the Soviet Union - Delovoy Mir and Literaturnya Gazeta. - A 40 percent interest in a Bulgarian newspaper and printing group.

DOC.HEAD: Future of Disgraced Junk Bond Prince Milken Rests With Young Judge
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto NY301 of Oct. 3
DOC.TEXT: She speaks softly, neutralizes adversarial lawyers with grace and charm, and often wears a ribbon in her flowing dark hair. The sweet gentility and stunning good looks of U.S. District Judge Kimba M. Wood may belie the stiff discipline of her federal courtroom, but acquaintances know better. Wood is strict, shrewd and exacting. She is about to make history as the judge to pronounce sentence on Michael R. Milken, the billionaire junk-bond pioneer described by prosecutors as Wall Street's most devious crok. ``She's a brilliant judge, careful, patient, considerate, concerned about reaching the right decision,'' said Jeffrey Mishkin, chairman of the New York City bar association's federal courts committee, who has known Wood for years. But Wood's sentencing record, largely for minor drug offenses, reveals nothing about how she may punish Milken, whose case may set a standard for the future treatment of white-collar criminals. At 46, she is the youngest member of the 21-judge Manhattan federal court, one of most active in the nation, where celebrity defendants ranging from Imelda Marcos to John Mitchell have stood trial. She was appointed two years ago and received Milken's case by random assignment. The ex-Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. executive faces up to 28 years in prison for admitting to six felonies in a plea bargain last April, most stemming from his relationship to inside trader and government informant Ivan F. Boesky. Speculation over how Wood will decide Milken's fate has become a hot topic, especially since she took the extraordinary step of delaying a scheduled Oct. 1 sentencing to allow for a hearing into other crimes Milken may have committed. She ordered the hearing, which begins next Tuesday, after digesting mounds of documents from the prosecution and defense, along with hundreds of letters, painting widely divergent pictures of Milken. The prosecution's pre-sentencing memorandum alleged a range of crimes well beyond those the financier admitted. The defense called his crimes aberrations in an otherwise upstanding life. Wood opted for the hearing to get a better understanding of the real Milken. ``From all I can see about how she's handling the case, she's doing it very well,'' said Harry First, a New York University law professor familiar with Wood's background. ``She's not going to give in wildly one way or the other on the pressure,'' First said. ``I doubt she'll see him as this wonderful man who's been railroaded by the government, nor someone who made so much money that he should go to jail for a long time.'' Still, it's conceivable she will spare Milken from prison, as his lawyers have urged, and put the financial wizard's talents to work in a community service program. She can't give him any more than the maximum 28 years. The few nationally significant cases Wood has handled don't provide a full picture of her overall views but suggest she's willing to buck conventional thinking. In October 1988, for example, she reversed a ruling by the Immigration and Naturalization Service that had denied refugee status to a Ghanian soldier who helped plan an botched coup attempt. Wood said in some circumstances, ``a coup may be the only means by which political change can be effected.'' In another instance last year, she upheld the right of a 76-year-old New York state judge to seek reappointment although he had passed retirement age. ``She knew the answers to every argument that was made, indicating she had done a great deal of preparation,'' said the state judge, Isaac Rubin. ``She's capable of handling any matter no matter how difficult it is.'' If there's been any flaw in Wood's handling of the Milken case so far, experts say, it was her decision to accept his plea agreement in the first place. Its ambiguity played an important role in the delay of Milken's sentence as lawyers haggled over the relevancy of unproven crimes. ``It looks terrible for the defendant to plead guilty to so much less than what the government says he did,'' said Albert Alschuler, a University of Chicago law professor who studies plea bargains. ``This flap about whether the government can talk about these other crimes should have been settled at the time of the plea agreement.'' Wood declined through her clerk to be interviewed to avoid even the appearance of prejudice or conflict of interest in the Milken case. His defense attorneys and prosecutors also declined to discuss the judge for the same reason. Nonetheless, public information and interviews with others, including her husband, reveal a portrait of a widely admired jurist, working mother, fluent French speaker, registered Democrat, avid cook, tennis buff and ballet aficionado. ``She's always had this very calm exterior and yet she's very tough,'' said husband Michael Kramer, a Time magazine journalist who first met Wood in 1981. ``I mean in the judicial sense, in a steel-trap mind way.'' Like other working parents, she struggles to balance time for her 4-year-old son and the rigors of the judgeship, which often means she gets home at 9 p.m. and works weekends. Still, friends say, she has never been intimidated in what historically has been a male-dominated profession. ``I view her as a great role model for women lawyers because she has a style that asserts itself in a totally elegant way,'' said Laura Handman, a friend and lawyer at the New York firm of Lankenau & Bickford. ``She's completely in control, but not at all in an aggressive, obnoxious way.'' Kimba Maureen Wood was born Jan. 2, 1944, in Port Townsend, Wash. Her parents found the name by leafing through an atlas and settling on Kimba, a small town on South Australia's Eyre Peninsula. Wood's resume reads like a classic example of superlatives. She attended the Sorbonne in Paris, got her B.A. from Connecticut College, master's degree from the London School of Economics and law degree from Harvard University. She specialized in antitrust law and spent more than 15 years at the New York law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae, where she represented clients ranging from Lloyds of London to St. Regis Paper Co. and eventually earned more than $200,000 a year. ``She was excellent to work with, much appreciated by clients because she was quick to understand their problems,'' said Taylor Briggs, a senior partner who was on the committee that hired Wood. ``She was the right combination of a good person and good lawyer, softspoken but firm.'' Her success prompted other judges to privately encourage her to seek a seat on the bench, although it meant a 50 percent pay cut. She was appointed by then-President Reagan in April 1988, on the recommendation of Republican Sen. Alfonse M. D'Amato. ``She presented us with a final decision on it,'' Briggs said. ``That was typical of her. She decides what she wants to do and does it.'' Although physical appearance has nothing to do with her work, many say Wood's dark brown, gray-flecked hair, jade-green eyes and high cheekbones are an integral part of the impression she leaves. ``She's a Girl Scout. Reverent, brave, honest, loyal, friendly, helpful,'' said Lloyd Constantine, a friend, former adversary and chief of antitrust enforcement for New York State. Constantine said he believed Wood's approach in the Milken affair was typical of how she handled cases as a lawyer. ``She probably wishes she could do this in isolation, outside the microscope,'' he said. ``Knowing that's impossible, she is absolutely preparing herself to the teeth about this. Her hallmark was being overprepared, coming into every discussion completely, fully informed.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday, Oct. 7

DOC.HEAD: Looking Back on Takeovers, One Year After The Campeau Disaster
With BC-Junk Bonds, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: It was a stunning disclosure from Campeau Corp. a year ago: The real estate developer who pulled off the biggest retail takeovers of the 1980s couldn't meet interest payments on billions of dollars in junk bonds used to finance the deals. No one knew at the time, but the heavy debt load from its purchases of Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc. would set off a chain reaction that rippled through corporate America. The junk bond market collapsed on the news, bringing the '80s takeover boom to a sudden halt as financing for deals vanished. It didn't end there. A month after Campeau's announcement, an attempt by United Airlines employees to buy parent company UAL Corp. unraveled when bankers, fearful of another disaster, refused to back the deal. The failure of the UAL buyout led in turn to a 190-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average on Oct. 13. The turbulence in the junk bond market ultimately contributed to the bankruptcy of Drexel Burnham Lambert, the investment firm that pioneered the risky, high-yield securities as a tool for financing buyouts. The Federated and Allied deals were not the only debt-financed transactions to falter: So did the $4.9 billion leveraged buyout of Southland Corp. and Doskocil Inc.'s $133 million takeover of Wilson Foods Corp. But a year later, corporate finance is not in chaos. Last year's turmoil brought about a more conservative attitude toward buying and selling companies. The emphasis now is on buyouts undertaken not for investment but for strategic reasons, such as expanding a company's business and market share. Economists and analysts can look back over the past year and at the buyout binge itself and find that despite some pockets of trouble, takeovers accomplished a lot of good. ``It would be naive to say they didn't do damage . . .,'' said Professor Alfred Rappaport, a mergers and acquisitions specialist at Northwestern University's Kellogg Graduate School of Management. ``But when you look at it holistically . . . there were considerably greater benefits than costs.'' Others agree. ``You've still got a very small number of highly leveraged actions that hit rough waters . . .,'' said Gregg Jarrell, a finance professor at the University of Rochester's William E. Simon School of Business. ``It's an exaggeration to look back and say `My goodness, what a terrible idea.' It's inconsistent with the evidence.'' During the takeover boom, critics complained about assets being sold to finance buyouts, but analysts say these divisions and subsidiaries often landed in good hands, those of entrepreneurs or companies seeking strategic acquisitions. ``Something like 80 percent of the assets acquired in leveraged deals end up being sold to strategic buyers,'' said Jarrell. Takeovers also turned some firms around. ``You needed some way to change management or change direction in a company that's not doing so well and in many cases we got that,'' said Bernard Black, a corporate finance professor at Columbia University's School of Law. Black cited Revlon Inc. as an example of a company that benefited from a buyout. Takeover strategist Ronald Perelman won control of Revlon in 1985 and pared down all its businesses except for cosmetics. ``He sells off health care to people who run health care and probably run it better,'' Black said. ``He keeps the cosmetics business and buys more, building up the Revlon name.'' Sometimes just the threat of a buyout kept managers on their toes. After GAF Corp. dropped a takeover attempt of Union Carbide Corp. in 1986, Carbide recapitalized, sold businesses including Eveready batteries and Glad plastic bags and focused on chemicals. It became a better company and its stock price rose, Black said. Without the takeover boom, ``We wouldn't have made the progress in getting ahead into productivity in the way that we've begun to do,'' said Rappaport. ``That was an important prod to management.'' But does this mean that executives, now facing less of a threat from outsiders, will let their companies become flabby? No, because takeovers helped create a force that isn't going away: institutional investors who are becoming increasingly active and forcing management to be more responsive to shareholders. ``They've had to step up to the plate now that Boone Pickens and Carl Icahn and those folks have been hobbled,'' Jarrell said. The institutions, many of them big public employee pension funds, were already gaining notoriety in the early '80s, but they are ``more aggressive than they would have been had it not been for the takeovers,'' said Jarrell. Institutions found that the large blocs of shareholder votes they controlled gave them power even beyond takeover battles and proxy fights where dissidents sought to unseat directors. Despite such achievements, analysts don't ignore the reality that debt-financed takeovers damaged or destroyed some companies and curtailed the profits and expansion ability of others. The problem was money was so easy to borrow that no one worried about exorbitant prices and insurmountable debt. ``People lost sight of how to value a company,'' Rappaport said. ``The sin was not leverage - the sin was paying too much and utilizing leverage in companies and times where it wasn't warranted.'' Black agreed, saying, ``The prices just got to points where everything had to go right for anyone to make any money.'' That was the exact problem in the buyouts of Federated and Allied, which cost Campeau $10 billion. Today, the two retailers are mired in the Chapter 11 reorganization process. So is Ames Department Stores Inc., which foundered after acquiring the Zayre discount store chain. Other companies went out of business after buyouts: most of the B. Altman and Bonwit Teller stores owned by L. J. Hooker Corp. and the Garfinckel's and Miller & Rhoads store chains. Southland is walking a tightrope, trying to complete a planned bailout by a Japanese retailer but also considering a Chapter 11 filing. These companies have a common thread: They are retailers. But that's no coincidence - many buyouts that stumbled were in cyclical industries, subject to the uncertainties of consumer spending or seasonal factors. But even a food company like Doskocil was not immune from debt problems, and it is also reorganizing in bankruptcy court. There's one silver lining amid the misfortunes of overburdened companies - new opportunities for other businessmen. Companies and funds have been formed to rescue firms. GE Capital Corporate Finance Group, for example, has established a specialty operation providing debt and equity for restructurings, reorganizations and turnarounds. Although the end of the takeover boom forced many Wall Street firms to trim their investment banking staffs, today's strategic transactions prompted some dealmakers to leave the big firms and set up their own companies.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday Oct. 7

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Surge On Soviet Buying Talk
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rose sharply Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, leading grain futures higher amid unconfirmed rumors that the Soviet Union has been on an international agricultural buying binge. Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., cited reports and rumors that Moscow bought as much as 900,000 metric tons of soybean meal from U.S., South American and European suppliers and 5 million tons of grain from Canada. The Soviets also were said to have bought as much as 8 million metric tons of various agricultural commodities from all over the world since Tuesday, Lespinasse said. ``We don't know if it's true,'' he said. ``We certainly think it's true in the case of the meal.'' Soybean meal for October delivery rocketed up more than $8 a ton, which gave the soybean market its strongest boost. All grain and soybean markets closed below the day's highs, though, as profit-taking cut the gains near the close. At the close, wheat futures were 1{ cents to 3 cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.74 a bushel; corn was 2{ cents to 4 cents higher with December at $2.29\ a bushel; oats were { cent to 1{ cents higher with December at $1.23} a bushel; soybeans were 4 cents to 14\ cents higher with November at $6.20{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: EC Wants Special Trade Arrangements with East
DOC.TEXT: The European Community on Wednesday asked for special exemptions from world trade rules while the Eastern part of Germany is integrated into the 12-nation trading bloc. A senior EC official told the council of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that the EC wants permission to make its own arrangements with trading partners of former East Germany. The official, Tran Van Thinh, said although bilateral deals with East Berlin violated GATT's international rules, the EC could not ignore the legitimate interests of Eastern European countries. GATT's ``most favored nation'' principle stipulates that a government should not give trading benefits to one country without extending them to other members of the trade forum. East Germany was not a member of the 99-nation GATT. East Germany's external trade was $59 billion in 1988. Two-thirds was in bilateral deals with the Soviet Union and other countries in COMECON, the East European trading group. A statement from the EC said an abrupt halt to this trade would ``lead to a number of additional factory closures, further loss of production and higher unemployment'' in the countries affected. The EC said transitional arrangements would be limited both in duration and scope. Countries affected would include the Soviet Union, Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Romania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia. Trade officials said the GATT council would discuss the request at its meeting in November.
