DOC.HEAD: Big Three Report Late-September, '90 Model Year Sales Figures
With BC-MI--Auto Sales-Table
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AMs version planned.
DOC.TEXT: Sales of the Big Three automakers' North American-made cars and trucks dropped 8.9 percent in late September and 10 percent for the 1990 model year, which ended with ominous tones from the Mideast and Capitol Hill, automakers said Wednesday. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said their vehicle sales fell to an average daily rate of 38,648 during the Sept. 21-30 period this year, compared with a rate of 42,408 during the same time last year. Car sales fell 5.1 percent and truck sales were off 15.1 percent. Each of the automakers said it still hasn't seen any dip in sales volumes or move to smaller, more fuel-efficient cars tied directly to rising oil prices in the wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. But Ford sales Vice President Robert Rewey said the decline was spurred by sagging consumer confidence. ``Accordingly, now that the deficit reduction agreement has been reached, we hope that interest rates will be reduced,'' Rewey said, referring to Sunday's proposal on new taxes and spending cuts to shrink the deficit. Among the new taxes is a three-step proposal to boost the federal gasoline tax to 21 cents a gallon after next July 1 from the current 9 cents a gallon. Congress still must enact legislation for such charges to be implemented. Such a tax increase, coupled with rising gasoline prices because of the Mideast crisis, may push consumers into smaller cars, analysts have speculated. For the 1990 model year, which ran from Oct. 1, 1989, through Sept. 30, the Big Three's domestic car and truck sales dropped to an average daily rate of 31,496 compared with 35,002 the year before. Car sales fell 13 percent and truck sales dropped 5.4 percent. In late-September last year, automakers were winding up end-of-model-year fire sales that included attractive cash rebates and low-interest financing deals. When the 1990 model year began last October, the companies pulled back on their incentives and their sales rates plummeted. Through the first nine months of the calendar year, the Big Three said their vehicle sales were down 8.2 percent as car sales fell 10.6 percent and truck sales declined 4.2 percent. Ford said its late-September domestic car sales rose 3.5 percent but truck sales fell 3 percent for a combined 1.1 percent increase in vehicle sales. So far this year, Ford's combined car and truck sales were 8.6 percent behind last year's pace. Ford's model-year sales of domestic cars and trucks were down 10 percent from the 1989 model year. GM said its car and truck sales for late September were 16.1 percent behind last year, with car sales down 12.2 percent and truck sales off a hefty 23.3 percent. Through the first nine months of this year, GM's vehicle sales were down 5.4 percent. For the 1990 model year, sales of GM's domestically assembled vehicles were off 8.8 percent. Chrysler has been in a sales slump since February, when incentives expired on the company's popular minivans. It said its late-September truck sales, which include minivans, fell 14.3 percent compared with the year-ago period and car sales were up 5.5 percent combining for a 4.7 percent decline in vehicle sales for the period. Through the first nine months of 1990, Chrysler's combined car and truck sales were down 14.6 percent and for the 1990 model year, the sales rate was off 13.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Xerox Executive Chosen for Sematech
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: William J. Spencer, a microelectronics researcher and Xerox Corp. vice president, Wednesday was chosen president and chief executive of the Sematech semiconductor research consortium. Spencer, 60, succeeds Robert Noyce, who died of a heart attack June 3. Noyce, co-inventor of the integrated circuit and a pioneer in the semiconductor industry, had headed the Austin-based chip manufacturing research center since 1988. Spencer will play an important role in guiding Sematech's research. He also will serve as a key spokesman for the microchip industry on issues such as federal funding and bolstering the semiconductor industry. ``The national mission we must accomplish is key to America's competitiveness and key to preserving our standard of living for our children and our grandchildren,'' Spencer told Sematech's Austin workforce after his appointment Wednesday. ``I am honored to join the elite team at Sematech,'' he said. The nonprofit Sematech was created by 14 companies in 1988 to regain the world lead in microchip manufacturing technology for the United States by 1993. The consortium employs 650 people in Austin. It has an annual budget of $200 million, which is supported by member companies and matching funds from the Defense Advanced Projects Research Agency. Spencer brings to his new post a lengthy background in microelectronics research. He was group vice president and senior technical officer for Xerox Corp. in Stamford, Conn. He also managed Xerox's worldwide research activity. Spencer joined Xerox in 1981 as manager of the company's integrated circuit laboratory at its Palo Alto Research Center. He formerly worked for the government-funded Sandia National Laboratories in Livermore, Calif., and Albuquerque, N.M., and was a research professor of medicine at the University of New Mexico. Holder of a master's degree in mathematics and a doctorate in physics from Kansas State University, Spencer began his career in 1959 with Bell Laboratories. ``Sematech and the semiconductor industry are extremely fortunate to have Bill Spencer as a champion and leader,'' said Charles Sporck, chairman of Sematech's board of directors and head of the selection team which chose him. ``With his experience in key research positions at Bell Laboratories, Sandia National Laboratories and Xerox Corp., Dr. Spencer has the technical expertise to implement programs which will enable this country to remain globally competitive,'' Sporck said. Sematech is developing advanced semiconductor manufacturing methods, equipment and materials. Research results are given to the member companies and the federal government for commercial and military applications. As CEO, Spencer will direct Sematech's advance semiconductor manufacturing staff and will serve as the consortium's primary liaison to its 14 member companies and the government. Member companies include Advanced Micro Devices, AT&T, DEC, Harris Corp., Hewlett-Packard, IBM, Intel, LSI Logic, Micron Technology, Motorola, NCR, National Semiconductor, Rockwell International and Texas Instruments.

DOC.HEAD: adv07
DOC.NOTE: For release Sunday, Oct. 7, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Junk Market Down, But Not Out Forever, Analysts Say
DOC.TEXT: A year since Campeau Corp. found itself buried in takeover debt, the buyout business has regained much of its vigor, but the junk bond market that fueled the 1980s merger boom still lies battered and bruised. Analysts say the bonds will make a comeback someday because they were too good an idea to give up. ``It's a legitimate financial tool and too many people made too much money for something like that to be forgotten,'' said Gregg Jarrell, a finance professor at the University of Rochester's William E. Simon School of Business. Alfred Rappaport, a professor at Northwestern University's Kellogg Graduate School of Management, agreed: ``Obviously there's some stigma attached to it, but the broad idea of making capital available at less than investment grade to companies is as appealing now as in the '80s.'' Campeau's $6.6 billion buyout of Federated Department Stores Inc. and its earlier $3.6 billion takeover of Allied Stores Corp. depended heavily on junk bonds. The company's announcement that it could not meet interest payments on the high-yield securities shocked the $200 billion junk bond market, sending prices sharply lower. But that was just the first in a series of hits. The next one came in October after a planned employee buyout of UAL Corp. faltered. Bond prices were slammed again in January as Federated and Allied filed for bankruptcy protection. January brought another cruel blow: lower-than-expected ratings for bonds issued by RJR Nabisco Inc. The company's outstanding junk bonds - once a rock of stability amid the market's turmoil - fell 10 percent in value in one day, and took other junk issues down with them. This past summer brought a recovery of sorts to the market, prompted in part by RJR Nabisco's plans to recapitalize and retire some junk debt. The financial press began to talk about a comeback. But in August Iraq invaded Kuwait, triggering concerns about a weakening economy. The junk market fell to new lows as it suffered along with other bonds, stocks and the dollar. Investors lost billions of dollars as the junk bond market collapsed. Some of them were savings and loans associations that became insolvent and were forced to seek government assistance. Perhaps the biggest casualty of the junk bond troubles was Drexel Burnham Lambert, the investment firm that pioneered their use as a buyout tool. Drexel was forced to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection because of its own junk bond losses. With a track record like that, it's hard to imagine junk bonds could make a comeback. But they were popular investments, not only because they helped some people make a lot of money. They also helped companies that couldn't get credit any other way. And they helped young companies like MCI Communications Corp. expand. ``It is central to the growth of key industries and companies,'' said Rappaport of the junk market. Furthermore, ``people in the financial markets have very short memories,'' he said. But just when the market will come back is hard to say, especially with the economy's current malaise and with debt increasingly becoming a four-letter word. ``At a time when the economy is slowing, you're better off slowing an accumulation of corporate debt,'' said Alan Levinson, director of financial services with Wefa Group, an economic forecasting service in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. Furthermore, companies feel it's safer to secure bank loans at several points above the current 10 percent prime rate than to sell bonds carrying interest rates of 16 percent or 17 percent. Even when the market does revitalize, no one expects junk debt to be issued at the pace of the 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Moves Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined on world currency markets Wednesday amid expectations that interest rates are poised to move lower. Gold prices bounced higher in a technical rally. On New York's Commodity Exchange, bullion settled at $393.90, up $4.80 a troy ounce. Later, Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $394.00 an ounce, up $5. The dollar slumped following Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's endorsement of the proposed budget agreement. He told Congress that the $500 billion deficit-reduction package would ``lessen pressures in credit markets.'' Though he did not specifically promise to lower interest rates, Greenspan said he ``most certainly'' believed an enacted budget agreement would exert downward pressure on rates. Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less attractive, thereby reducing investors' need for the U.S. currency. Greenspan's comments ``drove the dollar down . . . to new lows for the week,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst at the consulting firm IDEA. Still, Chandler noted that the dollar did not pierce ``the bottom of a broad trading range.'' Trading was relatively light, which exacerbated the dollar's move downward. Chandler predicted traders will continue to sell dollars ahead of Friday's release of unemployment data for September. Earlier in Tokyo the dollar eased to 136.65 Japanese yen, from Tuesday's 136.73 yen. Later in London, the dollar fell to 135.15 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 136.04, down from 136.72 yen on Tuesday. In London, one British pound cost $1.8990, more expensive for buyers than Tuesday's late $1.8890. In New York, it cost $1.9025 to buy one pound, more expensive for buyers than $1.8930 on Tuesday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates included: 1.5420 German marks, down from 1.5495; 1.2835 Swiss francs, down from 1.2885; 5.1660 French francs, down from 5.1915; 1,155.75 Italian lire, down from 1,160.75, and 1.1516 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1527. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates included: 1.5435 German marks, down from 1.5540; 1.2845 Swiss francs, down from 1.2900; 5.1747 French francs, down from 5.2050; 1.7410 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7502; 1,160.25 Italian lire, down from 1,162.75, and 1.1516 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1532. Gold prices moved higher overseas. In London, the metal closed at a bid $390.75 a troy ounce, up from $388.75 late Tuesday, and at $390.50 bid in Zurich, up from $388.60. Earlier in Hong Kong gold closed at $389.15 bid, up from $387.55. Silver prices were mixed On New York' Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.690 a troy ounce, up from $4.679 on Tuesday. But in London the metal closed at $4.70 an ounce, down from $4.725.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market retreated near the close of a quiet session Wednesday, faced with revived upward pressure on oil prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which spent much of the session hovering near Tuesday's closing level, finished with a 15.84-point loss at 2,489.36. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 564 up, 972 down and 437 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 135.49 million shares, against 188.32 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 165.41 million shares. Stock prices began to rally late last week from their lowest levels in more than a year. The upswing drew support from an encouraged reaction to the budget compromise reached by President Bush and many members of Congress. But analysts said traders remained cautious about chances for any major progress in shrinking the federal deficit, especially given the recession fears that have swept the financial world of late. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, offered a bit of reassurance on that score Wednesday, saying the budget plan held out the prospect of ``what appears to be a credible, enforcable reduction in the budget deficit.'' The recent recovery in stocks also drew some impetus from a drop in oil prices. But the oil market turned upward again Wednesday, sending crude oil futures for November delivery more than $3 a barrel higher to more than $37 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Losers among the blue-chip industrials included International Business Machines, down ~ at 107]; General Electric, down 1\ at 54{; Eastman Kodak, down } at 37\, and General Motors, down 1| at 35]. GM posted a 16.1 percent decline in domestic sales of cars and light trucks for late September. Retailing stocks were broadly lower, weighed down by increasingly gloomy expectations for holiday-season spending by consumers. Wal-Mart Stores fell 1} to 27}; Sears Roebuck 1[ to 25]; J.C. Penney 1{ to 42}; K mart ~ to 25{, and The Limited 1\ to 13. Apple Computer dropped 2| to 27 in the over-the-counter market. The company announced plans for lower-than-expected prices on three personal computers it is introducing this month. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $30.34 billion, or 1.02 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 1.79 to 170.80. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 3.68 to 367.37, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 3.81 at 311.40. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market tumbled 4.94 to 351.45. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 309.25, down .38.

DOC.HEAD: Gamble Steps Down as Colt's President; Stilwell Named Successor
DOC.TEXT: Colt's Manufacturing Co. announced Wednesday the resignation of its president and chief executive, Richard F. Gamble, who helped arrange a state-backed buyout in March that ended a three-year strike at the gun maker. The company said Ronald E. Stilwell, an 18-year veteran of Colt's who also participated in the management-led buyout, will become the new president. Colt's, which makes the military's M-16 rifle, did not immediately name a new CEO, but company Chairman Anthony D. Autorino said Stilwell would be a candidate for that job as well. In March, Gamble, Autorino and Colt Firearms executives joined with striking workers and the state to buy the gun maker from its parent, Colt Industries. The buyout, which drew some criticism because it brought the state into the gun making business, ended a bitter, three-year strike at the company. Last week, a state financial report indicated the market value of the state's $25 million investment of pension funds in Colt's decreased by about 13 percent in the cmmpany's first three months. But officials said Wednesday the company is in good financial health, thanks largely to Gamble's efforts during six months as president and CEO. ``The state's investment in Colt's remains a fiscally prudent one,'' state Treasurer Francisco L. Borges said in a prepared statement. Autorino said Gamble had planned to return to retirement after leading the new company through its first six months. Both Autorino and Kathleen Palm, an aide to Borges, said Colt's has improved financially since June 30. Colt's makes handguns and rifles for sporting, law enforcement and military use. Its products include the Colt 45 pistol, the Sporter rifle and the M-16. ``We expect to see our military business grow in the near future,'' Autorino said. ``With the Mideast situation, there's a lot of things happening with the M-16.''

DOC.HEAD: American Express Trying to Recoup Charges from Tour by Unemployed Mom
DOC.TEXT: American Express is trying to recoup over $24,000 in charges from an unemployed woman who declared personal bankruptcy shortly after a two-month European tour with multiple cards. ``You gave this woman seven cards? That's appalling,'' Chief U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Alexander Paskay told Ira Axelrod, an American Express representative during a hearing Tuesday. Last October, Dixie Lee Dorsey went on an eight-country European tour and charged $24,227 on two of her seven American Express cards although she had little income and has been without a job since 1978. ``You were just charging whatever you felt like charging?'' Larry Foyle, an attorney for American Express, asked Ms. Dorsey. ``I was having a good time,'' Ms. Dorsey replied. The 37-year-old Winter Haven woman declared personal bankruptcy in January, shortly after she and her two daughters returned from the trip. American Express Travel Related Services is trying to recover the money she charged. The company maintained she obtained the Green and Gold cards under pretexts and charged luxury goods and services even though she knew she couldn't pay for them. Dorsey's number of accounts was unusual, Axelrod said, but not unique. He said card holders can charge as long as their payment history is good and Ms. Dorsey was current on all seven accounts until she went to Europe. On her bankruptcy petition, she listed total debts of $193,577. Paskay didn't rule immediately, but said he would issue an order on whether she should be held responsible for the American Express charges even though she is in bankruptcy proceedings. Ms. Dorsey, who appeared without a lawyer, said she once had as many as 25 credit cards. Even though she quit her last job 12 years ago, she said she was able to meet her obligations until her boyfriend disappeared late last year with much of her property. She said he had been giving her between $3,200 and $6,000 a month.

DOC.HEAD: Dispute On Heating Oil Tax Percolates on Hill
DOC.TEXT: Politicians from the Northeast are fighting a proposed 2-cent per gallon tax on home heating oil, as ranking officials disagree on whether the proposal could scuttle the budget agreement. The regional dispute drew a call to Texas Sen. Lloyd Bentsen from his 1988 presidential running mate, Massachusetts Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the governor said Wednesday. Bentsen, who ran for vice president alongside Dukakis, said that if taxes are raised on other petroleum products, heating oil should be no exception. ``His goal was to ensure an equitable sharing of the tax burden,'' spokesman Jack DeVore said. Bentsen argues that the gasoline tax is more burdensome to residents of southwestern states who drive farther, on average, than northeasterners. But northeasterners are particularly concerned about heating oil because a cold snap last December caused prices to skyrocket and the Middle East crisis is pushing prices up going into this year's heating season. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said he is among those working to eliminate the heating oil tax from a budget agreement hammered out by congressional leaders and administration officials. On the House floor, Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass., warned Wednesday that the heating oil tax could lead to a mass defection by northeastern lawmakers from a budget agreement. The budget compromise had originally exempted heating oil from any new tax, but it was changed at the last minute. ``Mr. Speaker, I hope you and the majority leader in the other body (Senate) help me restore the home heating oil exemption,'' Conte said. ``Because without it, support for the budget package among the Northeast and this member is shaky.'' Conte's threatened defection is notable because, as ranking Republican on the House Appropriations Committee, he was among the participants in the closed-door negotiations that led to the budget agreement between the Bush administration and congressional leaders. Rep. Barbara Kennelly, D-Conn., joined in the anti-heating oil tax effort by writing to Bentsen: ``I cannot accept the two-cent tax on heating oil. This is a longtime traditional disagreement between our regions, but I refuse to concede.'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, in a Washington news conference, acknowledged that the heating oil tax is politically sensitive but rejected the suggestion that the issue alone could sink an agreement on reducing the federal deficit by $40 billion. The heating oil tax raised concern and anger among northeastern officials as much for how it happened as for the substance of the proposal. According to Conte, the summit agreement made final on Sunday contained a specific exemption protecting home heating oil from a general 2-cent-per-gallon tax on other petroleum products. But later, even as congressional leaders were gathering at the White House for a news conference on the agreement, Bentsen had a White House staffer use whiteout to erase the heating oil exemption. Dukakis told a news conference in Boston that Bentsen told him the heating oil exemption was put in the agreement without his knowledge. ``He was very upset and said it had to include heating oil or nothing at all,'' Dukakis said.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Futures Rally, Oil Soars in Chart-Based Trading
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices rose sharply and oil futures soared Wednesday in moves that analysts said were inspired more by technical factors than developments in the Persian Gulf. On other commodity markets, copper futures rallied; grains and soybeans advanced; and grains and soybeans were mostly higher. Gold futures settled $4.50 to $4.80 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in October at $393.90 a troy ounce; silver was 0.7 cent to 1.1 cents higher with October at $4.69 a troy ounce. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil settled 74 cents to $3.37 higher with November at $37.32 a barrel; wholesale heating oil was 2.55 cents to 7.38 cents higher with November at 99.41 cents a gallon; wholesale unleaded gasoline ended 1.59 cents to 6.21 cents higher with November at 93.14 cents a gallon. The advances in both the precious metal and energy markets resembled similar run-ups that have occurred whenever tensions increased significantly in the 2-month-old U.S.-Iraqi confrontation in the Middle East. But this time there was no news to trigger the surge in prices. Instead, analysts linked the rise in prices mainly to bullish chart patterns and perceptions that recent losses were overdone. ``It was more technical than anything else,'' said Tom Bentz, director of petroleum trading for United Energy Inc. He said crude oil opened moderately higher in reaction to Tuesday's American Petroleum Institute report of lower-than-expected U.S. crude supplies, then held fairly steady for several hours until the November price edged above $35.60 a barrel, the opening price of the previous session. ``Then it seemed like it started to snowball,'' Bentz said. ``Buying started coming in and that started bringing more technical buying back into the market.'' Gold's advance also was a mostly technical affair, analysts said, although signs of some large-scale bullion purchases lent strength to futures. Peter Cardillo, director of commodity trading with Jesup, Josephthal & Co., said the rally reflected investor confidence in the market after the December gold contract bounced off the $390 level Tuesday. December gold settled at $393.90 Tuesday and at $398.50 Wednesday. Technical factors and concerns about near-term supply tightness helped boost copper futures prices on the Commodity Exchange. Copper settled 1.25 cents to 3.45 cents higher with October at $1.30 a pound. Soybean futures prices climbed sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade, leading grain futures higher amid talk that the Soviet Union was on an international agricultural buying binge. The rumors were partially confirmed after the close when the Agriculture Department reported a sale of 150,000 metric tons of U.S. soybean meal to the Soviets. Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said Moscow was rumored to have bought as much as 900,000 metric tons of soybean meal from U.S., South American and European suppliers and 5 million tons of grain from Canada. The Soviets also were said to have bought as much as 8 million metric tons of various agricultural commodities from all over the world since Tuesday, Lespinasse said. Soybean meal for October delivery rocketed $8 to $183.50 a ton. Wheat futures settled 1{ cents to 3 cents higher with December at $2.74\ a bushel; corn was 2\ cents to 3} cents higher with December at $2.29 a bushel; oats were { cent to 1{ cents higher with December at $1.23} a bushel; soybeans were 4 cents to 13} cents higher with November at $6.20 a bushel. Most pork belly futures rose the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange for the third straight day, reflecting rising cash prices and heavy usage of frozen stocks, analysts said. The belly market lent strength to hog futures but cattle futures finished narrowly mixed after a day of choppy trading amid conflicting perceptions about the cash market's future direction. Live cattle finished .15 cent lower to .30 cent higher with October at 79.92 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .07 cent lower to .28 cent higher with October at 87.75 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to 1 cent higher with October at 56.60 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.93 cents to 2 cents higher with February at 64.20 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Surges Ahead, War Anxiety Revisits the Market
DOC.TEXT: Oil shot up more than $3 per barrel Wednesday, as war worries returned to the futures market in a rally that proved surprising even to traders who have grown accustomed to wild swings. ``It wasn't one headline,'' said Ron Caples, a broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``It wasn't one speech or one action or one rumor. The easiest way to describe it is the war premium is back, at least for today. I don't want to go out on a limb and predict prices tomorrow.'' Contracts for November delivery of light sweet crude oil closed $3.37 higher at $37.32 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Later contract months all closed higher as oil made a substantial rebound from back-to-back dives Monday and Tuesday that totaled more than $5 a barrel. Oil had opened slightly stronger Wednesday on an industry report showing the nation's crude supply went down by 9.4 million barrels last week, as well as news that Secretary of State James A. Baker III said he had found growing international support for a military strike against Iraq. But after several hours of lackluster trading, oil suddenly began surging ahead late in the afternoon, led by strong buying from the large trading houses. The reason for the jump seemed to elude professional traders. The rally may have been helped by news that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had gone to Kuwait, the oil-rich nation he conquered in August. ``A lot of people are feeling if he was down there, then maybe he was planning new strategies with his generals or whatever,'' said Thomas Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. Others said Saddam's visit to the occupied territory could not fully explain the rally. Home heating oil and unleaded gasoline contracts followed crude futures, as they have throughout the volatile week. Heating oil rose 7.38 cents to 99.41 cents per gallon for November delivery, with later months all closing higher. Unleaded gasoline went up 6.21 cents to 93.14 cents per gallon fo November delivery, with later months closing higher. Natural gas contracts all traded higher, with November contracts rising 3.5 cents to $1.915 per 1,000 cubic feet.

DOC.HEAD: Collapse of High-Rise Bailout Deals FHA Largest Claim
DOC.TEXT: The government will take over a luxury high-rise development that borrowed almost $159 million in federally backed money in what officials called the biggest federal mortgage insurance program bailout. Federal housing officials and developers of the financially troubled Presidential Towers apartments failed to meet an Oct. 1 deadline to agree on a proposed $16 million loan to help the project stay solvent, both sides said Wednesday. The money would have forestalled a default on loans developers obtained to build the 2,346-unit high-rise, which opened in 1985 on the west edge of the city's downtown. The federal government now must repay the loans and take over as lender, spokesmen for both sides indicated. The tab is the biggest in the history of the Federal Housing Administration's mortgage insurance program, said Bill Glavin, a spokesman for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, which oversees the FHA. Glavin said HUD hopes to foreclose on the project in six months. When HUD takes over such a project, it generally sells the property, he added. Douglas R. Woodworth, a spokesman for the developers, said they would try to negotiate an arrangement ``we think would be less costly to the government than a foreclosure.'' Such a deal could occur under a special program that would allow HUD's immediate payout to be limited to $40 million, reducing the first mortgage by that amount. The developers would owe the $40 million to HUD as a second mortgage they would pay later, Woodworth said. HUD would gain by not having to take a large loss at one time to its insurance fund but could suffer greater losses in the future. Developers Daniel E. Levin, James P. McHugh and Daniel J. Shannon would gain by buying time until the project becomes self-sustaining, which HUD said could take up to eight years. HUD Secretary Jack Kemp favored the $16 million bailout only if the developers could raise $13 million of their own, which Glavin said they could not or would not do. Kemp said in Chicago last month that ``there should never have been this type of federally guaranteed investment'' as the one that backed loans to Presidential Towers. The 48-story, four-building complex was built over the objections of community activists who said it would displace many poor and homeless people. It is about 90 percent occupied. Its 3,100 tenants are mostly young professionals and should not be affected by the project's latest financial troubles, Woodworth said.

DOC.HEAD: Glenn Appears Before Ethics Committee
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES in first 5 grafs new with meeting conclusion; picks up 2nd graf pvs, Appearing individually. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Sen. John Glenn met privately with the Senate Ethics Committee on Wednesday and said he thoroughly discussed all aspects of his assistance for Charles H. Keating Jr. while the businessman's savings and loan was collapsing. Glenn, one of five senators who intervened with regulators for Keating and also accepted political donations from him, met with the committee in private for 2{ hours. He later declined to reveal the substance of the discussions. ``I survived,'' the Ohio Democrat told reporters. ``I appreciated very much the fact that the committee would take the time to discuss this whole issue with me, which we did. There was adequate time to present everything.'' The committee's vice chairman, Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., said no decision on Glenn's case had been made. Glenn was the first of the five senators summoned to a committee meeting to explain their help for Keating. Appearing individually at closed hearings this week and next, the senators will explain their intervention with U.S. banking regulators and their acceptance of a total of $1.3 million in political donations from Keating and his associates. Congressional sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, have said committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett recommended cases be dismissed against Glenn and John McCain of Arizona, the only Republican among the five. McCain is scheduled to appear Thursday. The six-member committee has not acted on Bennett's recommendation, nor on his conclusion that cases proceed against Democratic Sens. Alan Cranston of California, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan. A decision to continue any of the cases could bring hearings in which Bennett and defense lawyers would oppose each other in a trial-like setting; the committee would sit as a jury. The panel has the authority to rebuke by letter any senator found in violation of standards of conduct, or it could recommend full Senate sanctions of censure or expulsion. Keating and his associates donated $200,000 in the fall of 1985 and spring of 1986 to the National Council on Public Policy, a political action committee that promoted Glenn's issues and paid for travel after his 1984 presidential bid collapsed. Glenn also received $34,000 in direct contributions for his campaigns. Bennett's report, according to congressional sources, makes connections between the timing of Keating's contributions and actions taken by the senators. ``The conclusion was there was no connection between the contributions and actions'' of Glenn and McCain, one source said earlier this week. Federal regulators had already concluded that Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan of Irvine, Calif., was heading toward failure when the senators held two crucial meetings in April 1987. The thrift wasn't seized by the government until April 1989, by which time the government was stuck with a bailout cost that could exceed $2 billion. All the senators under investigation, except Riegle, met April 2, 1987, with Edwin J. Gray, then chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. Gray contended the senators offered a deal to aid Keating, but each lawmaker vigorously denied that account. A week later, all five senators met with the San Francisco-based examiners who were investigating Lincoln. And, according to a regulator's transcript, the lawmakers were told that criminal referrals would be made to the Justice Department. It was at the second meeting, according to the transcript, that Glenn made the oft-quoted comment: ``To be blunt, you should charge them or get off their backs.'' Glenn has said previously that if he had learned earlier about the potential criminality, ``there would have been no point in holding either meeting, and I would not have attended. I attended no further meetings on this subject, nor did I discuss the matter further with any member of the FHLBB or its staff.'' At another point, Glenn said that if Keating thought campaign contributions would buy influence, then ``John Glenn must have been the biggest disappointment to him than anybody he contributed to.''

DOC.HEAD: Lewd Parties Lead Regulators To Study Possible Nynex Breakup
DOC.TEXT: State utility regulators, concerned about lewd parties for Nynex employees and vendors that included prostitutes, authorized a study Wednesday into whether the telephone holding company should be broken up. The study was recommended by the chief lawyer to the state Public Service Commission, William Cowan, in part to try to prevent future conventions such as the ones held in Florida by Nynex's Materiel Enterprises Co. Materiel Enterprises was the purchasing subsidiary of Nynex, the regional ``baby bell'' company that owns New York Telephone Co. and New England Telephone Co. At the time of the parties, Materiel Enterprises was not government regulated, as are the telephone companies. The regulatory commission is investigating whether vendors who attended the annual weeklng bashes may have received special treatment when they later pursued business deals with Materiel Enterprises. New York Telephone had been ordered to purchase supplies from Materiel Enterprises at higher prices than the company would have paid on the open market, state Attorney General Robert Abrams has charged. Those higher costs may have been passed on to customers through higher rates, he said. In February, the Federal Communications Commission ordered fines totaling $1.4 million against New York Telephone and New England Telephone because of $118.5 alleged overcharges made to the two units by Materiel Enterprises. New York Telephone is asking for a $900 million rate increase. The utility commission said Wednesday it would separate the Materiel Enterprises case from the rate hike case because it might take too long to complete its Materiel Enterprises investigation. Nynex, in a two-paragraph statement, said divestiture was ``not an option'' it would consider. But the company said it would cooperate with the commission in resolving the problems cited by the report. Nynex stock fell 75 cents a share to close at $71.62{ in consolidated New York Stock Exchange trading Wednesday. Previously, Nynex spokesman Peter Goodale has said that an analysis of the company's dealings with its vendors found no correlation between the amount of business awarded and attendance at the conventions. In his report to the utility commission, Cowan said he believed that customers could be better served if New York Telephone was split off from Nynex. ``The manner in which this corporation (Nynex) has handled itself since divestiture in 1984 raises serious and troubling questions about its management agenda, its business purposes and the future direction in which it will lead the New York Telephone Co., unless changes are made,'' Cowan said. It was unclear Wednesday whether the utility commission has the authority to order Nynex to divest New York Telephone. However, Bradford said, there were structural changes besides divestiture that could loosen the relationship between Nynex and its two telephone companies. Aides to Abrams called the recommendation to study a Nynex breakup a ``bombshell.'' They said it had not been tried in any other states. Utility commissioner James McFarland, while not endorsing the notion of divestiture, said the Nynex purchasing practices involving Materiel Enterprises were full of ``chicanery and venality, if not criminality.'' The annual booze and sex blasts were arranged by Materiel Enterprises executive Lawrence Friedman, who was fired in 1988 by Nynex. Friedman later received a $1 million settlement from Nynex after suing the company for alleged religious discrimination. Nynex said it fired Friedman for misconduct while Friedman claimed it was because he is Jewish. On Tuesday, Nynex said it merged Materiel Enterprises with another unit, Nynex Services Co., to form a new subsidiary called Telesector Resources Group Inc. Nynex said it will provide centralized planning, marketing and purchasing to New York Telephone and New England Telephone.

DOC.HEAD: Chartwell Reps Resign From Special Avon Panel
DOC.TEXT: Chartwell Associates said Wednesday that its representatives have quit a special Avon Products Inc. committee because the panel seems unwilling to fulfill its mission of finding ways to increase the value of the cosmetics company. Avon responded that its special committee will continue to examine alternatives to enhance stockholder value despite the resignation of the two Chartwell members. The announcements indicate a rift has occurred in the delicate relations between the big beauty products marketer and the limited partnership that has been stalking it. Formation of the panel was part of a truce worked out in the spring under which Chartwell agreed not to wage a threatened proxy fight against Avon. Under the settlement, Avon supported Chartwell nominees to two of the four slots available on Avon's board. They were elected at the May annual meetig. The news encouraged buying in Avon stock, which rose $1.25 to $26.75 in composite New York Stock Exchange trading Wednesday. Chartwell issued a news release Wednesday criticizing Avon's senior management and the special committee for failing to show ``any desire or determination'' to fulfill the committee's original charge. The Chartwell representatives said they could not ``sit idly by and condone inaction'' so they decided to submit their resignations. ``We will continue to work toward finding a means to fulfill our obligation to all Avon shareholders - a means that will be satisfactory to Avon's board and management,'' Chartwell's representatives said. Joseph Rice, an Avon board member who is chairman of the special committee, said in a news release that the remaining panel participants would continue to look at a broad range of alternatives. Nothing has been ruled out yet, he said. Among the alternatives under review are a recapitalization of Avon, asset sales and sale of the entire company, Avon has said in the past. Chartwell has exerted pressure on Avon on and off since last November. A principal in Chartwell, John P. Rochon, who is vice chairman of the makeup marketing company Mary Kay, has made several takeover advances on Avon. Others in the limited partnership include the Fisher brothers of New York and the Getty Family Trust. The partnership has periodically boosted its holdings of Avon stock and is believed to have about 19.8 percent of Avon's voting stock. Chartwell has said that its intends to be a long-term investor in Avon and has not indicated that it plans to launch a hostile bid for the company.

DOC.HEAD: Worst Model Year Since '83, But Auto Sales Rate May Be Strengthening
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Sales of North American-made cars and trucks dropped 3.7 percent in late September, capping the worst model year since 1983 when the industry was struggling back from the dark days of the early '80s, automakers reported Wednesday. The Honda Accord was the best-selling car of the 1990 model year, easily topping the No. 2 Ford Taurus. The 10 major domestic automakers reported selling an average of 44,443 cars and trucks during the Sept. 21-30 period this year, compared with an average of 46,158 during the same time last year. Domestic car sales were nearly even and truck sales dropped 10.4 percent. Car sales by General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. fell 5.1 percent during the period while sales of cars made in Japanese plants in North America rose 40.4 percent. The Big Three held 84.3 percent of the domestic car market during the period. The late-September sales came against a time last year when automakers offered more attractive incentives than they did this year. Auto analyst David Healy of Barclays de Zoete Wedd in New York said the late-September sales rate was healthy. ``Cars for the 10 days were a good deal stronger than I figured,'' he said. ``Truck sales look to be the weakest all year. ``Maybe there is a shift in (car and truck) mix going on because of gasoline prices, but it's a little early to tell,'' he said. Automakers have been saying for more tan a month that they haven't seen any effects on sales directly related to rising gasoline prices stemming from the Mideast crisis. ``Nevertheless,'' Ford sales Vice President Robert Rewey said Wednesday, ``consumer confidence has experienced its steepest decline since 1981.'' For the first nine months of this year, and with imported cars and trucks counted in, automakers said their sales dropped 5.9 percent compared with the same period last year. Car sales were down 6 percent and truck sales were off 5.7 percent. However, the underlying demand for cars and trucks has been strengthening in recent months, Healy said. ``It looks like the sales rate may have bottomed out,'' he said. ``Even with the Middle East and scary gasoline prices and threat of war and big drops in consumer confidence surveys, you get better vehicle sales (now) than you had for the last 12 months.'' Sales in the 1990 model year wound up 7.9 percent behind the 1989 model year. When heavy trucks are counted in later, it's likely that about 14.2 million cars and trucks will have been sold during the 12 months ending with September. About 11.7 million vehicles were sold in the 1983 model year, just after the country emerged from a recession and before the start of the selling boom of the mid- and late-1980s. ``I think that the American consumers' overbuying of cars in the late-'80s has finally caught up to them,'' Healy said. ``I think a lot of people were staying home paying for their old cars rather than buying new ones.'' Honda can be especially pleased with sales of its Accord. It easily captured the honor of being the most popular car in the 1990 model year with sales of 418,177. That was 32 percent more than the Ford Taurus with 316,906. Included in the Taurus figure is a sizeable number of sales to fleet customers, such as rental car and taxi companies. Honda does little fleet business, making the difference in retail sales larger. The best-selling vehicle overall, though, was the Ford F-Series full-size pickup truck at 538,040 for the model year. The Chevrolet C-K Series of full-size pickups was second at 486,104.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Witnesses: Not Much Fruit In These `Roll-Ups'
DOC.TEXT: A House subcommittee began an inquiry Wednesday into whether a new version of limited partnerships that can be publicly traded hurt small, often unsophisticated investors. Critics brand the investments, called ``roll-ups,'' as legalized embezzlement and say they should be banned. Industry supporters, meanwhile, concede more disclosure is needed in the often lengthy and baffling documents that accompany a roll-up proposal. ``There isn't one broker on Wall Street who's been in the business maybe two months, who owns a limited partnership. Not one! It is a suicidal investment for idiots,'' Scott Miller told the finance subcommitte of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. Miller, a Houston, Texas, consultant and researcher on limited partnerships, was among several witnesses who called for an outright ban of roll-ups, which are often developed when a limited partnership's earnings sour. Others, like Mark J. Sletten, president of the Real Estate Investment Association, said there should be some modification of the rules but opposed ``the outright prohibition of roll-ups.'' Limited partnerships are investment vehicles, usually sold through brokerage firms, in which investors known as limited partners put up between $5,000 and $10,000. The money often goes towards real estate or oil and natural gas drilling projects. In return they get income, capital gains and tax benefits. The partnerships are usually run by one or more general partners, who bear all the responsibility for running the business in return for management fees and a percentage of the profits. Through the late 1980s, however, many partnerships have been losing propositions because of troubles in the real estate and energy markets. As real estate values have fallen, general partners of several limited partnerships have combined the businesses - the winners and losers - into one entity that is then publicly traded. The move has to be approved by the limited partners. ``Roll-ups may be the only recourse left to general partners in the months ahead if the overall slide in real estate values continues,'' said Christopher L. Davis, president of the Investment Partnership Association. It frees the limited partners from the lengthy obligation to stay in the partnership for five to 10 years. However, shares in the new entity are often hard to sell and the value of the original investment usually drops when they hit the public market. ``As a rule, roll-ups involve fraud, self-dealing, theft of limited partnership assets, and all rolled together theft,'' said economist and writer Benjamin J. Stein of Malibu, Calif. He and other opponents said when the term of the partnership ends, the limited partners get their money back, but in a roll-up, the investment vehicle becomes perpetual and the proceeds are reinvested into the partnership. They also claimed that the deck is stacked against small investors who may not know that the promotional materials and prospectus for the roll-up is being paid for with their money; that the ``independent'' investment banker who has reviewed the roll-up is being paid by the general partner who also pays a commission to brokers who obtain a `yes' vote for the roll-up. And all of this is legal. Davis, the Investment Partnership Association, said rather than eliminate investment partnerships, limited partners should be given all the information they need to make intelligent decisions when voting on a proposed roll-up. That would include: an easilly understandable summary in the first few pages; a comparison of compensation under the exisiting partnership and under the proposed new entity and the ability to sell partnership interest both before and after a roll-up. But in his opening remarks, Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., the subcommittee's chairman, said current information available to investors is hard to wade through. ``It's widely acknowledged on Wall Street and off that disclosure documents have become so complex and convoluted as to become incomprehensible to all but the most sophisticated investors,'' he said. Markey said he and Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., have asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to study the issue and report back to Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Salt Lake City Rated Tops For Business By Fortune Magazine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf to elaborate on how rankings were devised
DOC.TEXT: Salt Lake City, with its well-skilled workers, convenient transportation and low taxes, was rated tops for business in a Fortune Magazine survey released Wednesday. New York, plagued by troubled schools and sky-high wages, was not included in the magazine's top-10 city list this year after ranking No. 6 last year. The current top-10 list, published in Fortune's Oct. 22 issue, will hit most newsstands on Oct. 8. The magazine said the survey was based partly on a poll conducted by the relocation consulting firm of Moran Stahl & Boyer, which queried personnel executives in the 50 largest metropolitan areas. Fortune also said the rankings were based on its own interviews with hundreds of business and community leaders and government officials. Fortune said it changed the criteria from last year to put greater stress on education and the quality of the workforce. Last year's broader quality-of-life criteria put Dallas, Atlanta and Kansas City at the top of the list. This year's leader, Salt Lake City, was singled out for its high literacy rate and overall quality of life. The survey added that its sedate downtown should be invigorated soon by a planned $500 million redevelopment. Others in the top-ten, in order: - Minneapolis-St. Paul - ``among America's cleanest, safest metropolitan areas''; - Atlanta - ``fine climate, affordable housing, first-class international airport and rapid transit, scores of golf courses''; - Sacramento, Calif. - ``homes at half the price of San Francisco and Los Angeles and generally better schools''; - Austin, Texas - ``better schools and lower labor costs than its bigger sisters Dallas and Houston''; - Columbus, Ohio - ``affordable housing and good schools in an ethnically diverse city''; - Dallas-Fort Worth - ``affordable homes, low state and local taxes,andthe smell of economic recovery''; - Phoenix - ``schools excel, workers are well educated, and a large community college system answers business's needs''; - Jacksonville, Fla. - ``schools aren't exceptional...but Florida's generous job training programs and low taxes help compensate''; - Oklahoma City - ``real estate markets are a buyer's paradise...and city and state offer some of America's best job training and adult education.'' Seattle, which didn't make Fortune's list, was rated the best place to locate in an annual survey of 400 business executives released Tuesday by the commercial real estate firm of Cushman & Wakefield. Fortune's No. 1 choice didn't make the Cushman & Wakefield survey.

DOC.HEAD: Doll Maven Madame Alexander Dies at 95
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th to last grafs, bgng `The British ...' with 6 grafs to CORRECT that dolls represented queen and her sister but not their mother and to UPDATE with value of dolls, names of survivors and funeral details. A version also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Beatrice Alexander Behrman, founder of an early U.S. doll company whose handcrafted Madame Alexander dolls became collector's items and were exhibited in museums around the world, died Wednesday at age 95. Mrs. Behrman, who was widely known as Madame Alexander, died of natural causes at her home in Palm Beach, Fla., said spokesman Beau James. She founded the Alexander Doll Co. in 1923 and sold it to two New York businessmen in 1988 but remained a consultant. Madame Alexander dolls take up to three weeks to craft by hand and are the foremost collectible dolls in the world. The company has introduced more than 5,000 different dolls. Her doll collections were based on fantasy, historic events, literature, music art and movies. ``I made dolls for children to play with and learn from of life and of art,'' she said in an interview several years ago. Mrs. Behrman was the daughter of a Russian immigrant who moved to New York and established his own toy shop and the country's first doll hospital. During World War I, she designed and helped make ``Red Cross Nurse'' rag dolls that were sold by her father's company. She was inspired to start her own line of dolls after shipments of European dolls to the United States virtually ceased during World War I. Her husband, Philip Behrman, quit his job with a New York hat company to run the business end of his wife's firm. Mrs. Behrman became known as Madame Alexander in the doll world with the first of her dolls, rag dolls with mask-type features and pressed features that she hand-painted. The emphasis on facial features was a departure from old-fashioned rag dolls with flat faces. By the 1930s, she started making dolls whose heads had painted features and eyes that closed. Madame Alexander dolls emphasized lifelike details, right down to the knuckles of fingers and eyelashes. The dolls also were known for their rooted and elaborately styled hair and stylish clothes. After World War II, she followed the trend to plastic, and made dolls with vinyl heads and vinyl, hard plastic or cloth bodies. In the early 1950s, she won the Fashion Academy Award for her doll clothing designs. Clothes of all sizes, not just miniatures, compete for the award. The British government commissioned a special design of Madame Alexander dolls representing Queen Elizabeth II before and after her coronation in 1953, and her sister, Princess Margaret. In 1968, the Smithsonian Institution chose two dolls to include in its doll collection: the ``Madame'' doll, based on the American Revolution, and the ``Scarlett O'Hara'' doll from ``Gone With the Wind.'' Other well-known dolls were inspired by Alice in Wonderland, the four sisters in ``Little Women,'' and characters from Charles Dickens' books. Her line of ``Portrait Dolls'' began production in the early 1940s. Up to 21 inches tall, the dolls included ``Orphan Annie,'' ``Renoir Girl'' and ``Nancy Drew.'' New dolls range in price from $40 to $500, while collector items sell for as much as $5,000. The Alexander Doll Co., headquartered in Harlem, is that area's largest private employer, with 650 employees. Survivors include Mrs. Behrman's daughter, Mildred, and a grandson. Funeral services will be held Sunday at the Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan.

DOC.HEAD: Matsushita To Send Executives to U.S. To Finalize MCA Buyout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to CLARIFY that Matsushita proposal does not include television stations.
DOC.TEXT: Consumer electronics giant Matsushita Electric Industries Co. said Thursday its executives begin meeting with MCA Inc. officials as the Japanese firm pursues a buyout of the entertainment conglomerate. ``Until now, we have been approached by MCA through a third agent, but we finally reached the stage of direct negotiations,'' said Matsushita spokeswoman Toshiko Inui. She said Matsushita will send its executives to the United States soon to negotiate with MCA representatives for a possible agreement. Ms. Inui would not elaborate on the negotiations. The Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading economic journal, reported Thursday that Matsushita wants to buy MCA's film and music divisions for $6 billion. That leaves out MCA's theme-park business. The Nihon Keizai said MCA has told Matsushita that it wants more than $7.53 billion for all of its divisions except its television stations. If realized, the deal would be the largest purchase of an American firm by a Japanese company. Matsushita said in a press release it is possible that contacts between the two companies may not lead to a merger or even another form of business partnership. With its 163 consolidated subsidiaries, Matsushita Electric is Japan's third largest corporation and the world's 16th largest in 1989, according to Fortune Magazine. The company's annual report forecasts total sales of more than 44 billion dollars this year. Last year, Sony Corp. acquired Columbia Pictures Entertainment, in large part to gain control over the American movie studio's rich library of old films and television shows. Analysts say purchases of film libraries allow consumer electronics companies to release old movies and television shows in the format for videotape recorders they manufacture, a key sales strategy, and also provide material for future high-definition television recordings. MCA's stock rose $3.87{ to $63.50 on the New York Stock Exchange Wednesday. MCA was trading for about $34 per share before reports of a possible deal surfaced Sept. 25. Matsushita's stock has risen to 1,920 yen ($14) on Oct. 3 from 1,630 yen ($12) on Sept. 25 on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

DOC.BYLINE: HIBERNATING INVESTORS: Analysts Diagnose Full-Blown Bear Market
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK - On Oct. 13, 1989, Wall Street was suddenly faced with a problem. A planned buyout of UAL Corp., the big airline holding company, collapsed for want of financing, touching off a ``mini-crash'' in stock prices. Today, nearly a year later, Wall Street still has that problem - plus a long list of others that have since all but overshadowed it. Together, they constitute what analysts have diagnosed as the first full-blown bear market in nearly a decade. Slug BC-Bear Market. By Business Writer Chet Currier. Moved Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Oct. 7. With Graphic.
DOC.HEAD: CAMPEAU REVISITED:
Looking Back On Takeovers A Year After Campeau Failure
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK - It was a year ago that the failure of the $6.7 billion buyout of Federated Department Stores Inc. brought the 1980s takeover boom to a halt, rocked the junk bond and stock markets and led eventually to the collapse of the investment firm Drexel Burnham Lambert. Today, not only has the merger business recovered, but analysts find there was a lot of good among the excesses of the buyout binge. Slug BC-Campeau Anniversary. Business Writer Joyce M. Rosenberg. Moving Wednesday on FFF-news wires for Sunday, Oct. 7. With Graphic.

With BC-Junk Bonds, while the takeover business has recovered, the junk bond market that fueled the 1980s merger boom still lies battered and bruised. But analysts say don't give up on these high-risk, high-yield issues.
DOC.BYLINE: Retailers Bear Scars of Bankruptcy But Customers Can't See Them
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK - When things started looking bleak for Bloomingdale's corporate parent last autumn, a Manhattan movie theater near the famous department store proclaimed on its marquee ``Good Luck Bloomies.'' Now, a photograph of that message hangs on the wall outside the seventh floor board room at the Bloomingdale's headquarters. Luck and a lot of good will by suppliers have helped Bloomingdale's and its eight sister chains of U.S. department stores cope well with life in bankruptcy court. Adaptations have had to be made, but, to customers, nothing much has changed. Slug BC-Campeau-Stigma. By Business Writer Marybeth Nibley. Moving Thursday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Oct. 7. Story delayed until Thursday due to spot developments.
DOC.BYLINE: Heavily Endebted Campeau Fights For Survival
DOC.TEXT: TORONTO - Robert Campeau, ousted chairman of the teetering real estate and retailing empire that bears his name, is struggling to salvage the company he built from scratch. But a source close to the flamboyant Canadian businessman says relations are severely strained with a creditors group which now runs the company. Slug BC-Campeau-The Man. By Jeffrey Ulbrich. Moved Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Oct. 7. With LaserPhoto.
DOC.BYLINE: MOM-AND-POP OPERATIONS: Independent Hotels And Motels Fast Disappearing
DOC.TEXT: CLAY, W.Va. - What's in a name? Plenty, if you're in the hotel or motel business. Small, independent hostelries are fast disappearing, unable to compete with the big franchised operations. Alma Jarrett, who runs the Henry Clay Hotel in West Virginia, can tell you why. Slug BC-Mom and Pop Motels. By Aviva L. Bryant. Moved Monday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Oct. 7. Also moved on AP Newsfeatures. Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo.
DOC.BYLINE: PERSONAL FILE: Federal Judge Kimba Wood Faces Milken Test
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK - Kimba Maureen Wood speaks in a soft, even-handed voice that betrays none of the enormous pressure she's under as a rookie federal judge handling one of the biggest white-collar crime cases in U.S. history. At 46, Wood is only two years older than junk-bond pioneer and admitted securities fraud felon Michael R. Milken, who could spend up to 28 years in prison if she says so. Slug BC-Personal File-Wood. By Business Writer Rick Gladstone. Moving Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Oct. 7. With LaserPhoto.
DOC.BYLINE: GENDER CONTENTION: Should Fertile Women Be Barred from Some Jobs?
DOC.TEXT: MILWAUKEE - Every day, Gloyce Qualls lives with a cruel choice she made six years ago: She traded her fertility for her job. She felt agony then; she feels anger now. ``I regret it all the time,'' she says. ``It's something I had to do to keep my job. I wouldn't do it again. I'd tell them, `Take this job and shove it.' '' Mrs. Qualls works at Milwaukee-based Johnson Controls Inc., the nation's largest auto battery manufacturer, whose policy of barring fertile women from potentially risky jobs has triggered debate from the factory floor up to the U.S. Supreme Court. Slug BC-A Woman's Choice. Two Takes. By Sharon Cohen. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Oct. 7. With LaserPhoto. Also moved on national news wires.
DOC.BYLINE: COUNT ON THEM: SEC Proposing Changes In Accounting Field
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON - The Securities and Exchange Commission wants the accounting profession to change its methods. Whoa! Don't stop reading yet! Changing the way the bean-counters count the beans could mean big differences some day in the way a company reports it financial health. And that could have far reaching effects on your employer, your investments, maybe even your future. Slug BC-Counting the Beans. By Business Writer John M. Doyle. Moving Thursday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct. 8.
DOC.BYLINE: BRANCHING OUT: Citibank Making Push For Japanese Consumers
DOC.TEXT: TOKYO - When Citibank opened its 10th branch in Japan over the summer, it handed out fliers reading, ``Best Bank Citibank,'' and offered crisp $10 bills to the first 1,000 customers opening foreign currency accounts. Such an aggressive marketing strategy is unheard of in this country, where banks usually agree among themselves what is permissible activity. But Citibank has been challenging those rules lately - and shaking up the financial community - as it makes its first major push into consumer banking since establishing itself in Japan nearly a century ago. Slug BC-Japan-Citibank. By Mari Yamaguchi. Moved Monday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct. 8. With LaserPhoto TOK6 of Oct. 2
